HEADLINE: Europeans Follow U.S. Shift to Bonds, for Now

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 24

 BODY:
Like their counterparts in the United States, investors in European markets have been bailing out of stocks this week and putting their money into bonds.
But the economic fundamentals behind the European markets are considerably different from those at play in the United States. And while investors and analysts here said Europe would continue to be influenced by what happens on Wall Street, some said there are still selected opportunities for equity market gains in France, Britain, Germany and other markets. 
 "The European markets are following the U.S., but probably should not be," said Albert B. Morillo, the director of European investments at Scottish Widows Investment Management, a large British pension fund. "The dynamics are different. We are still in the initial phases of a period of reasonable upswing in economic activity."
With the American markets closed today, European markets recovered to varying degrees after their big losses on Wednesday.
In London, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 leading shares closed up 9.1 points at 3,036.60. German shares closed up in extremely light trading, with the DAX index in Frankfurt rising 22.66 to 2,055.97. In Paris, the CAC 40 index jumped 41.59 points to 1,934.68
The timing and strength of Europe's economic recovery differs from country to country, with Britain a year or so behind the United States cycle, and Germany and most other nations on the Continent two years behind.
While the Federal Reserve has been pushing interest rates aggressively higher in the United States since February, raising fears that economic and earnings growth could be choked off, Germany's powerful Bundesbank has continued to cut rates this year. The Bundesbank left rates unchanged after a policy meeting today, but its chairman, Hans Tietmeyer, has left open the possibility of a further reduction.
Among the major European nations, only Britain, Sweden and Italy have raised rates this year to head off inflation, which remains at extremely low levels, especially in Germany.
Although economic growth in most European countries rebounded more strongly earlier this year than many economists had expected, the recovery remains patchy, with few signs of increased employment, wage increases or rising consumer demand.
But at the same time, many big European companies are reaping the benefits of cost-cutting programs, with earnings rebounding sharply. Today, for example, the German chemicals company BASF, a traditionally cyclical stock whose fortunes improve with economic growth, said its third-quarter pretax profit had more than quadrupled, to 526 million marks (about $340 million), from the corresponding period a year earlier.
"In the U.S. you could argue for a scenario where there's a slowdown in earnings, where in Europe we still have the possibility of earnings recoveries," Mr. Morillo said.
The European markets, however, are being unsettled to some degree by the same shift from equities into bonds that has been driving activity on Wall Street this week.
On Wall Street, stock prices had remained relatively strong until this week, while the bond markets in the United States had collapsed when the Fed began raising rates. In Europe, stock prices have been tumbling all year along with bond prices. In London and Frankfurt, the markets have fallen nearly 10 percent this year, while the Paris market is down 16 percent. Yields on benchmark 10-year bonds in Germany, France, Britain and other countries are all up between half a point and more than a point in the last six months.
In the last several months, though, investors in Europe have taken a new look at bond valuations, and that could spell a little trouble for stock markets. The investors began deciding that with inflation low and economic growth moderate, the selloff in bonds had probably gone too far, creating more buying interest.
"There is a much more positive attitude towards bonds, but I think it's largely because the market has fallen so far in price," said Stephen Hannah, the head of research at IBJ International in London. "I don't think it's a fundamental shift."
Morgan Stanley's London office recommended on Wednesday that clients reduce their European equity holdings to 50 percent of their portfolios from 58 percent and move the funds into bonds.
Joe Rooney, the investment strategist at Lehman Brothers in London, said he had been telling clients since the end of June to move to an overweighted position in bonds.
Cyclical European stocks, like chemical and construction companies, performed well earlier this year because they rose on the hopes for a rebound in European economies. But Mr. Rooney now thinks that they are overvalued and that financial stocks, like banks, may now be a better bet.
"It's difficult to see how sentiment towards equities could get any worse," he said.
Mike Young, the director of European investment strategy at Merrill Lynch in London, said that with 10-year bond yields 2.1 times the dividend on equities in Germany, 1.9 times in Britain, 2.2 times in France and 5 times in Italy, it was not surprising that funds were flowing into bonds.
"There's still another step of relative outperformance of cyclical stocks in Europe because we think people will be surprised at how strong the earnings recovery will be in cyclicals," Mr. Young said. "Having said that, the general outlook for the market is not all that great. The next step in bonds and equities could well be down in terms of asset prices, but many people would prefer to be in bonds because the high coupon in many markets allows you to overcome the capital decline relatively quickly."

HEADLINE: U.S. Study Shows Half of Food-Stamp Recipients Are Children

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24

 BODY:
As House Republicans push a plan for changing the welfare system that includes dismantling Federal nutrition programs, the Clinton Administration has issued a new study showing that half of the food stamp recipients are children in poverty.
The Agriculture Department's Food and Consumer Service, which runs the Government's largest nutrition programs, released the study this week as the debate intensified over the Republican proposal. 
 Republicans preparing to take control of the House want to consolidate several nutrition programs for the poor -- including food stamps, school lunches and the supplemental feeding program for women, infants and children -- and give the money to the states in a lump sum.
Under their plan, spending on nutrition assistance would be limited, and low-income families would no longer be automatically entitled to receive benefits.
Republican lawmakers say that their proposal would end duplication among programs and give the states greater flexibility to distribute aid for food to poor families. The block grant would save $11 billion over five years, they say.
Advocates for the poor say the plan, if it becomes law, could lead to increased hunger and homelessness among American families because spending could not grow automatically in times of recession and rising poverty.
They also say families could be taken off the welfare rolls or put in waiting lines for benefits. They seized on the new study to make their case that the Republican plan would hit children, the elderly and the working poor especially hard.
"This underscores how heavily targeted the Republican welfare reform plan will fall on children, including very poor and often very hungry children," said Robert J. Fersh, president of the Food Research and Action Center, an advocacy group in Washington.
The Agriculture Department report, dated Oct. 27 and released this week without any comment from the Administration, profiled the population that receives food stamps in the summer of 1993.
The program then served an average of 27.3 million people in almost 11 million households. More than half of the people in the program, 51.4 percent, were children. Seven percent were elderly, and the rest were adults ages 18 to 59.
The study found that food stamps were about a fourth of a family's total income. The average benefit per household was $170 a month.
The study also found that a fifth of the families receiving food stamps were working, but not earning enough to escape poverty.
Darold Johnson, deputy director for programs and policy at the Children's Defense Fund, said the block grant was a bad idea because it replaced coupons, which must be used to purchase food, with cash, which could be used for other purposes like rent and utilities.
"The decision between heating and eating is one that low-income families make constantly," he said.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
For Stocks, New Fears Of a Slowing Economy

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
The stock market is suddenly becoming worried about the health of the economy.
The plunge in prices this month, and particularly in the last few days, has hit the cyclical stocks -- the issues most dependent on a strong economy -- the hardest. At the same time, the battered bond market has suddenly gained strength. 
 "What the cyclical stocks are telling us is that a slowdown is imminent," said Ed Goldfarb, a strategist at Aeltus Investment Management. "I think that is what broke the back of the market this week, without any real confirming economic data."
Whether the plunge continues, or mimics this year's earlier slides and reverses, depends in part on whether investors return from the Thanksgiving holiday less pessimistic about the economy. A string of important economic data next week, including reports on the gross domestic product, unemployment, factory orders and the leading indicators, might help convince them that they overreacted.
So far this month, the Morgan Stanley index of cyclical stocks has plunged 10.4 percent, while a similar measure of consumer stocks -- companies that make products far less sensitive to overall economic data -- has slipped just 1.2 percent. During the same stretch, the Dow Jones industrial average has lost 6 percent, including a fall of 4.4 percent in the last five trading days, all of which have seen the index fall.
"What you have seen is fear that the economy is headed into a recession," said Abby Joseph Cohen, co-chair of the investment policy committee at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "There has been a notable rotation away from stocks whose earnings are economically sensitive."
For much of the last two years, cyclical stocks led the stock market. Their strength predated most economists' discovery that the economy was growing surprisingly strongly.
Now they are turning down, reflecting worry that the Federal Reserve, which has raised short-term interest rates six times this year, will go too far. The most recent rise was last week, when the Fed pushed up the rates that banks pay on overnight loans from other banks by 75 basis points, or three-quarters of a percentage point.
"With the move to 75 basis points by the Fed, in effect what they are telling us is that 'we're going to do whatever it takes to dampen your enthusiasm about the economy,' " said Robert Barbera, an economic consultant in Greenwich, Conn.
The stock market has long had a reputation for getting spooked about the economy whether such a mood was wise or not; one of Professor Paul Samuelson's most famous remarks was to note that the stock market had forecast many more recessions than had actually occurred. And there are few indications that business is in danger of seriously slowing.
That is one reason some analysts, including Mrs. Cohen of Goldman, Sachs, view the current plunge in prices as a buying opportunity and suggest that investors will grow more encouraged when they see that the economy and corporate profits will not falter significantly next year.
One of the stock market's great strengths since 1988 has been the willingness of individual investors, particularly mutual fund buyers, to view dips as buying opportunities, rather than as cause for panic. While stock fund buyers have been losing enthusiasm, so far there is no sign of a widespread run for the exits.
But Byron Wien, the chief United States equity strategist for Morgan Stanley, predicts that a change may be coming. On Monday, just before the worst part of the plunge, he recommended that all-stock portfolios raise their cash levels to 15 percent, from 3 percent.
He pointed to evidence that households may not have enough spare cash to keep up the flow in any case, and added that he feared the Dow would fall below 3,600 and the redemptions, or withdrawals from mutual funds, would start.
"The most important secular event" of this market cycle, he said, "has been the zeal of the public for equity mutual funds." Unfortunately, he added, "the market rarely rewards zeal of that intensity."
In the last decade, the public has put a net $300 billion into stock mutual funds, and during that stretch the Dow industrials have tripled, from 1,200. But most of that money has come in during the last two years.
Most of the recent buyers now show little if any profit, and it is possible that some will flee if the losses begin to mount.
The biggest and most-watched averages, including the Dow industrials and the Standard & Poor's 500, have stayed within relatively narrow trading ranges this year, and have yet to break below them. The lows for the Dow and the S.& P. are about 2 percent lower than current levels.
But other less-watched indexes have done much worse. The more economically sensitive Dow Jones transportation average, composed of airlines, railroads and trucking companies, fell on Wednesday to its lowest level since Dec. 16, 1992, and is down 23.6 percent from its peak in early February. By contrast, the Dow industrials are only 7.6 percent off their high, set a couple of days earlier.
The Dow Jones utility average, which is dominated by electric utilities and is highly sensitive to interest rates, has done even worse. On Tuesday, it closed at 173.94, its lowest level since 1988 and down 32.2 percent since its peak in the fall of 1993. But that index came roaring back on Wednesday, rising 2 percent, to 177.50.
That recovery reflected the new optimism about interest rates that had accompanied the recent slide in stocks. Valuation models now generally indicate that bonds are a better buy than stocks, and consequently some big traders seem to have moved money to bonds from stocks.
A belief that the economy was slowing would tend to buoy the bond market, by making further Fed tightening less likely and by reducing the demand for credit.
The yield on 30-year Treasury bonds peaked earlier this month at 8.16 percent, and has since fallen to 7.94 percent. Bond investors, reeling from bad news for most of the year, are suddenly making money.
In what is still a minority opinion on Wall Street, Chuck Clough, chief strategist at Merrill Lynch, argues that after a long string of positive earnings surprises, the earnings news may be about to sour for a lot of companies, with retailers the next to be hit.
"Corporate earnings could really be in trouble," he said on Wednesday, adding that rising costs were not being passed along by many companies, and further that with adjustable-rate mortgages gaining in popularity the effects of the Fed's tightening were starting to be felt by many consumers.
"That will probably be the biggest surprise of all," he said.

HEADLINE: Plan for Toxic Dump Off Coney I. Is Attacked

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
Rebuffed in its bid to dump 150,000 tons of dioxin-tainted sand in the ocean six miles off Sandy Hook, N.J., the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is considering a plan to deposit the material in a pit a half mile off Coney Island.
 Residents of Coney Island and Staten Island have begun letter-writing and petition drives against the plan and nearly 300 people showed up at a recent protest meeting in Sheepshead Bay. Community Board 3, which oversees most of Staten Island's recreational beaches, has passed a motion condemning the plan. And fisherman say the area around the pit is teeming with fish that could be poisoned, destroying the catch of charter boats and commercial fisherman, many of whom sell at the Fulton Fish Market. 
 "If they go ahead and dump, the fleet there might as well pack it in and sell their boats," said Ralph Pastore, director of the 8,500-member United Fishermen's Association of New York.
 Environmentalists, including opponents of the plan, say the major danger would be to people eating the fish and clams poisoned through the food chain.
 Officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the Army Corps of Engineers believe the concerns are ill-founded. They say the plan has been carefully evaluated and is not only safe but will actually encase contaminants that already pollute New York Harbor.
 The proposal is just a first, interim step in a long quest to dredge up to seven million tons of sediment a year from 32 sites in the harbor and its estuaries by the end of the century to open sea lanes that are too shallow for the deep-hulled cargo vessels that now ply the seas. Both sides in the dispute agree that opening up the harbor to deep-hulled vessels is essential to restoring economic vitality to what was once one of the world's premier cargo ports.
 "It's a worthy goal, and I understand that," said Assemblyman Daniel L. Feldman, Democrat of Brooklyn, a leader in the fight to find another solution. "But I'm more than a little concerned about this potential poisoning of my constituents."
 Peter Shugert, a spokesman for the Corps of Engineers, which would oversee the operation, said he understands that "this is an emotional issue," because dioxins are involved. But, he said: "We've gotten to the point where we've got to apply something. After a careful and exhaustive scientific search, this is one proposal that we feel is solid, that works."
 Immediately at issue is what to do with the 152,000 tons of sediment the Port Authority wants to dredge from Howland Hook, a long-dormant marine terminal facing the Arthur Kill on the northwest shore of Staten Island. Howland Hook has long been a repository for a dioxin-laced byproduct dumped into the nearby Passaic River during 25 years of Agent Orange production by the defunct Diamond Shamrock Corporation.
 The 187-acre site was supposed to have been deepened, from 31 feet to about 40 feet, so ships could start docking there by the end of the year. The sediment was to be deposited in what is called the Mud Dump, a Federally regulated site off Sandy Hook. But last week, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency barred the use of the Mud Dump after tests determined that the Howland Hook sediments fall into category 3, the highest level of toxicity.
 In a statement released last Tuesday after the E.P.A. test results were announced, the director of the Port Authority's port department, Lillian C. Liburdi, said the authority is looking for an alternate dumping site in what is called a "borrow pit" -- a pit that is the product of previous sand-mining operations. She said the pit should be "in the floor of coastal waters where the material could be isolated and capped with a thick layer of protective material."
 One of the largest borrow pits in the harbor, and the one suggested by the Port Authority with the approval of the Corps of Engineers, is East Bank Pit No. 6 -- a squiggle-shaped, 70-foot-deep, one-and-a half-mile-long gouge in the sea bottom, a half mile south of Sea Gate on Coney Island. On its western side, the pit slopes toward Staten Island's beaches, three miles away.
 On Wednesday, the executive director of the Port Authority, Stanley Brezenoff, said: "We believe firmly that borrow pits are environmentally safe, technologically sound and, therefore, an alternative that has to be one of several things available to us for the disposal of dredged material. We have consistently said that, as a public agency, we would not promote anything that was harmful to the environment."
 In her statement, Ms. Liburdi also said, "We must not allow a dispute over trace levels of contaminants to jeopardize a project of great significance to the Port of New York and New Jersey."
 Environmentalists and opponents of the plan are troubled by Ms. Liburdi's use of the phrase, "trace levels."
 "Trace doesn't mean trivial," Assemblyman Feldman said.
 Dr. Angela Cristini, a professor of biology at Ramapo College and a member of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's Dredge Management Team, said: "People at the Port Authority talk about trace amounts, but they are used to dealing with millions of tons. As a biologist, I know that the cells in our body deal in parts per trillion or even quadrillion. That's not very much, and not very much can cause a problem."
 Dioxin is actually a group of about 200 closely related chemical compounds considered the most potent of all the human-made carcinogens. It accumulates in body fat over a lifetime, gradually increasing the risk of cancer, scientists say. And it mimicks hormones, which can lead to birth defects.
 Dr. Barry Commoner, director of the Center for the Biology of Natural Systems at Queens College, said the E.P.A. regards 1 to 10 in a million as an acceptable risk that a person might get cancer during his or her lifetime from general exposure to the environment. Dioxin, by itself, the E.P.A. has determined, poses a risk of 500 to 1000 in a million.
 The Port Authority maintains that because the material will be dumped at sea and capped, there is little, if any, danger that residents of surrounding areas will be directly exposed to dioxins. Their proposal calls for capping the contaminants from Howland Hook with a 3-foot-deep layer of sand.
 "What should comfort the people of Coney Island and environmentalists," said Mr. Shugert, the Corps of Engineers spokesman, "is the fact that this material will be isolated from the environment that it comes in contact with now."
 Mr. Shugert said capping the sediment with three feet of sand "is a technique used throughout the country that is endorsed by all the Federal agencies." Opponents contended that a storm could breach the sand-cap. "That hasn't been proven," Mr. Shugert said.
 Other alternatives have been proposed. "The only safe way is to seal it in something like a concrete enclosure," Mr. Commoner said. Construction of bulkheaded containment islands in Lower New York Bay is another possibility, Mr. Shugert said.
 Dr. Cristini suggested digging a pit out of the clay bottom in parts of Newark Bay, with the clay used to form a more stable cap. But to deal with the long-term problem of handling the vast amounts of material that must be dredged from the harbor, a combination of solutions is needed, she said, including construction of plants that chemically decontaminate the sediment.
 "You can either use that sand for landfill," Dr. Cristini said, "or dump it in the ocean without any problem."

HEADLINE: Flexing Fiscal Muscles: Mayor and Council at Loggerheads

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

 BODY:
For 11 months, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has had near total dominion at City Hall, with the Democratic-controlled City Council resignedly giving its approval to the Republican's austere $31.6 billion budget and vision of a far smaller government.
 But now a slow accumulation of citizen pressure over continuing spending cuts, legislative grievances over Mr. Giuliani's all-or-nothing style, and a sense that the Mayor has become vulnerable in the wake of the election of George E. Pataki as Governor have started to change the relationship between Mr. Giuliani and the 51-member Council. 
 In one defiant day, the Council displayed its independence on Wednesday by voting with a vetoproof margin to create a permanent outside agency to monitor police corruption over Mr. Giuliani's objections. It also moved to test the limits of its fiscal powers by voting to restore to the budget funds that the Mayor had intended to cut -- money to care for the mentally retarded, to keep open emergency soup kitchens and to prevent deeper reductions in teachers and school supplies.
 What happens now that the Council has tried to substitute its own spending priorities for the Mayor's is far from clear. The two sides might yet negotiate an agreement, the Council having demonstrated that it can flex its muscles. Or the vote could end in a court test of the balance of power between the two branches of government when it comes to setting fiscal policy. Mr. Giuliani, who started out on Wednesday saying a midyear Council budget vote violated the City Charter and would be "null and void," unexpectedly bought time for compromise after the vote against him by saying he would wait five days, then veto the budget measure.
 But whatever the outcome, Wednesday's two votes were warning signs to the Mayor that the support he will need in the Council to carry out his program is eroding as he nears his second year in office. In fact, despite the last-minute lobbying of Deputy Mayor Peter J. Powers, six of the seven Republicans on the Council defied the Mayor and joined with the Democratic Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, on the budget vote to send their own message of independence.
 "It's always the Council that acquiesces, and I think that somewhere along the line you have to become assertive, and I understood Speaker Vallone's position," said Councilman Thomas V. Ognibene, the Queens Republican who became minority leader this week by deposing Michael J. Abel, who had been installed earlier in the year with the help of the Mayor.
 In part, Mr. Giuliani's loss of support stems from his style. In his first year in office, Mr. Giuliani has shown streaks of political brilliance, especially in his ability to reach out and communicate to constituents with the right political message and sound bite. He was already at work on Wednesday after his legislative defeat depicting the Council as "irresponsible" and profligate.
 "It's really an attempt not to make the difficult decision," said Mr. Giuliani at Gracie Mansion. "I would have preferred the City Council to act as partners, but they didn't seem to be up to it."
 But in the equally important realm of back-room politics with fellow elected officials, Mr. Giuliani's tendency to try to crush any opposition is starting to carry costs, just as his furious campaign against Mr. Pataki left many in his own party determined to pay him back.
 "He mustn't constantly take the position that it's my way or the highway," said Councilman Anthony D. Weiner, a Brooklyn Democrat, reflecting widespread sentiment among Democrats and Republicans alike.
 The Mayor's aides have often said that only by being focused and unyielding will they be able to change the direction of a city largely dominated by Democrats. Mr. Giuliani's face-off with Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines won him the budget cuts he wanted in the spring. And his threat to cut off funds for the Legal Aid Society brought striking lawyers back to work this fall.
 But many Council members said they thought the Mayor had shown contempt for them when -- in his search for ways to deal with a more than $1 billion gap that had opened in the budget -- he cut out $40 million of the $75 million in programs that the Council had restored to his budget during negotiations in June. It was those very programs that had allowed Mr. Vallone, a conservative Democrat who shares many of Mr. Giuliani's own priorities, to assemble enough votes to pass the budget. "That is an in-your-face move," Mr. Vallone complained.
 Beyond its anger at the Mayor, the Council was responding to its own political needs. In pressing for the monitoring agency, Mr. Vallone knew that a strong stand against police corruption was an important priority for the 22 black and Hispanic members of the Council as the last few years have brought revelations of rogue bands of police officers abusing citizens and shaking down drug dealers.
 In addition, lawmakers said that with the second round of budget cuts presented to them by the Mayor, they were starting to hear many protests not just from advocates for the poor but also from middle-class constituents worried about more cuts for their schools or uncertain how they would be able to cope with a severely retarded or developmentally disabled child if government programs disappeared.
 "How Dickensian do we want this city to become?" asked Councilwoman Kathryn E. Freed, a Manhattan Democrat, as she voted for the Council's alternative budget plan.
 Despite the Council's show of defiance, there was little sign that the Democrats, as loath as Mr. Giuliani to raise taxes, had come up with a coherent long-term plan to deal with the multibillion-dollar deficits looming for years to come.
 While the Council made alternative budget cuts to pay for the programs it restored, many of the cuts seemed intended to pique Mr. Giuliani. The Council proposed slashing much of the Mayor's own staff, as well as lawyers in the Corporation Counsel's office and the Department of Investigation, and called for big reductions in overtime pay for police, firefighters and sanitation workers.
 But simply estimating that the overtime cost will be millions of dollars less than it has traditionally been will not necessarily result in savings, but more likely in a deficit that will have to be addressed later in the year. The Mayor's budget director, Abraham M. Lackman, referred to the Council's alternative budget cuts as "Alice in Wonderland." And the administration pointed out that the Council had cut not one penny from its own budget.
 Serene in the almost unrivaled power that the City Charter grants the Mayor to manage fiscal affairs once a city budget is enacted, Mr. Giuliani said this week that, if need be, he would cut from the $31.6 billion budget on his own to prevent a gap. "If I have to do it alone, I'll do it alone," he said.
 But come next year when he has to win Council approval for his second budget, that approach won't suffice.

HEADLINE: TV WEEKEND;
Revisiting the World Of Rebels and Redcoats

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
Let's get the invidious comparisons out of the way. "The American Revolution" is not "The Civil War." Momentous though it was, the war that began the United States does not grip the imagination like the war that might have ended it. For 20th-century Americans, the Revolution does not have the dramatic force, the emotional resonance, the painful relevance of the Civil War, and the six-hour history that begins on Sunday does not pretend otherwise.
What "The American Revolution" does do is trace the background, dramatize the high moments and sketch some of the personalities and achievements of the remarkable company that gave us the Declaration of Independence, the Constitution and political ideals that have never lost their glow. 
 In the absence of contributions by Matthew Brady, effective use is made of re-enacted battle scenes -- red coats against motley -- with plenty of smoke and commotion; drawings and paintings are melded into the tale. At times the screen seems transparent and the motion is often slow as historical figures (David Warner doing George III) flow in and out like ghosts. The resident historians seem like analysts of a dream as they offer their nonrevolutionary interpretations.
Sunday's two hours open with, yes, the ride of Paul Revere, and the first fatal encounter between British troops and American militiamen at Lexington, Mass. "Somehow," a historian says, "someone fired a shot and started a war." There are introductions to those great American agitators Samuel Adams, John Adams, Patrick Henry and Tom Paine, whose resounding words put today's political sound-biters to shame. And there is a look back at the French and Indian War, which freed the Americans from the threat of invasion by France and so allowed them to concentrate on ridding themselves of the British, and which not incidentally brought to the fore George Washington (voice by Cliff Robertson).
Also mentioned, in the spirit of diversity, are Abigail Adams (encouraging husband John to give "particular care and attention to the ladies" in the new republic) and Crispus Attucks, the black man killed during the Boston Massacre. Presumably as a dash of human interest, periodic attention is given to Benjamin Franklin's bitter falling out with his Tory son, William. More deservingly, Benedict Arnold, that hero-traitor, receives special notice.
The historians do not fail to point out that despite the ringing demands for liberty, Thomas Jefferson's call for ending the slave trade was excised from the Declaration of Independence, in deference to both Southern and Northern economic interests. They also note that British rule was hardly onerous and that this was no uprising of an oppressed class, many of the American revolutionists being quite well to do.
Despite the frequent commerical breaks, this preview of the History Channel, a new 24-hour programming service that is to begin on Jan. 1, invites family watching, and teachers should find it of use in helping students envision the Boston Tea Party and remember who said, "Don't one of you fire until you see the whites of their eyes," and why. (The program credits Israel Putnam; my Bartlett's says it might have been William Prescott.)
New York City and environs figure prominently in the first episode, as the British beat the Americans from Kip's Bay to Harlem Heights to Fort Lee, N.J., to White Plains. These two hours end with General Washington's soul being tried and Valley Forge still ahead. But not to worry, things will turn around by Tuesday.
 
THE AMERICAN REVOLUTION
A&E, Sunday at 8 P.M.

HEADLINE: $25 and Under

BYLINE: By Eric Asimov 

 BODY:
More Than Coffee
From the street, the Cake Bar and Cafe looks like just another bakery and coffee bar. Well, maybe more stylish than most with its sleek, bright, stripped-down look and shiny cases displaying delectable pastries. But there's another dimension to the Cake Bar. An excellent little menu, more ambitious than you might expect, takes the cafe from the realm of fanciful dessert to solid main course. 
 The full meals are served in a spacious, loftlike brick dining room on the second floor. With its haphazard collection of tables -- some industrial metal, some farmhouse wooden -- the room looks at first like the eclectic result of a year spent at yard sales, but closer observation reveals a quirky sensibility at work. The high ceiling is not made of pressed tin, but dozens of silver baking trays. The wall sconces are actually French aspic molds, and metal Art Nouveau vines creep along the walls. Big plate-glass windows stare down on 13th Street. Most of the tables have wooden school chairs, but at one end are tables with club chairs that make you wish you could spend a year sitting at a back table writing a dissertation.
The design and the food are the collaboration of Susan Povich, daughter of the television personality Maury Povich, and Jude Quintiere. The two met while taking classes at the French Culinary Institute in Manhattan, and the Cake Bar is their first venture. Ms. Povich handles the food, a melange of Mediterranean and American dishes, and the pies, while Mr. Quintiere prepares the pastries and cakes.
Most main courses come with a nice green salad, which makes for a most economical meal. A huge helping of couscous ($8.50), aromatic with cinnamon and cumin, is topped with strips of moist grilled chicken. A special, large ravioli stuffed with corn and sausage ($9.25), was truly special, with a wonderfully complex sauce of reduced chicken stock and pureed grapes offering a contrast to the savory filling. A juicy Cornish hen ($6.95), stuffed with sweet pork sausage and leeks, comes with a nutty wild rice pilaf flavored with orange. Ms. Povich loves sausages and makes a mean merguez ($9), served with rice and full-flavored roasted peppers. Sauteed shrimp ($9) are scented with lemon and served on a puree of split peas with an intense port wine sauce.
Lighter fare includes an unusual pissaladiere, a mass of caramelized onions, olives and anchovies served on a pale, flat crust made of bread dough ($3), and sandwiches like thick, moist slices of turkey breast with arugula and tomato on whole-grain bread spread with a carrot-soy puree ($5.50). The Cake Bar is expecting a wine-and-beer license soon, but for now fresh-squeezed juices are available.
Did somebody say dessert? There are many attractive choices, including Linzer cookies ($2.25), eclairs (two for $1.50) and a beautiful pyramid made of dark chocolate, filled with passion fruit mousse and coconut ($4.50). But my absolute favorite is raspberry mousse cake ($4), a small, football-shaped pastry filled with mousse so richly flavored you can taste it with your whole body. Call it the icing on the Cake Bar.
 
More Than Tea
 Right across the street from the Cake Bar is the much smaller The Adore, a charming little tea room that also has an upstairs-downstairs design. And in contrast to the Cake Bar's self-consciously modern design, The Adore, which is three years older, is pure farmhouse, with wooden tables, old law-office wooden chairs, plank floors and old wooden cabinets.
The menu includes many interesting sandwiches and salads, like smoked mackerel, served with cucumber, tomato and onion on thick slabs of white bread swabbed with a sharp horseradish sauce. With a cup of leek-and-potato soup, (very leeky, with lots of pepper), it cost $7.50. The menu includes a wide selection of teas, though not all are always available. A pot of a fruity, almost hibiscus-flavored tea with the improbable name of eros was $2.50. The Adore is at 17 East 13th Street, in Greenwich Village, (212) 243-8742.
 
Cake Bar and Cafe
22 East 13th Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 807-1313.
Best dishes: Couscous with chicken, ravioli with corn and sausage, Cornish hen, merguez, sauteed shrimp, pissaladiere, turkey sandwich, chocolate pyramid, raspberry mousse cake.
Price range: $5 to $18.
Credit cards: Mastercard and Visa.
Hours: 7:30 A.M. to 9:30 P.M. Mondays through Fridays, 9 A.M. to 9:30 P.M. Saturdays. Closed Sundays.
Wheelchair access: Entrance is three steps down from street; bathroom is available on the first floor.

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE REVIEW;
Evoking Moses' Vision of New York

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
THE Panorama of the City of New York is a meeting of two minds: yours and Robert Moses'. Oh, yes, the vast scale model looks remarkably like a city: five boroughs worth of miniature buildings, streets, parks and bridges. But don't be fooled. All that physical apparatus is just a scaffold for what can become an intensely emotional mental exchange. Here, you will enter the mind of one of the greatest master planners of all time. You will survey the city through the eyes of the man who transformed it.
Then, moments after stepping inside that legendarily imperial dome, you may begin to discern an urban vision of your own. Memories, hopes, triumphs, disappointments: these are among the landmarks on the private map that begins to take shape as you look around the Panorama. The places you've lived, or wanted to. The good or bad times you had there. The connections and disconnections of a life lived in New York City. 
 All that, and Trump Tower, too. Patched up, repainted, brought up to date with the addition of hundreds of new scale models, the Panorama reopened this week in a sparkling new setting in the Queens Museum of Art, the same location where it first went on view 30 years ago as a featured attraction at the 1964-65 New York World's Fair. The helicopter ride is gone, and so is the boosterish Lowell Thomas narration that boomed through the speakers of the ride's molded plastic cabs.
But a new installation (part of the just-completed three-year, $15 million remodeling of the museum, designed by Rafael Vinoly) has brought architectural distinction to a place where fairground festivity once prevailed. And the change in tone is apt, for the Panorama was originally conceived as a serious tool for urban planning.
Created at a cost of nearly $700,000, the original 9,335-square-foot model took nearly three years to build. It reproduces New York City's 320 square miles at the scale of 1 inch to 100 feet (the Empire State Building rises a lofty 15 inches). Proclaimed as the largest scale model in the world, it was something of a last hurrah for Moses, the long-time head of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority. Moses, who built many of the public works depicted on the Panorama, was nearing the end of his reign when he became president of the 1964-65 World's Fair. Two years before the fair opened, he had been stripped of most of the power he had wielded over the city for half a century. The Panorama was at once a summing up of his achievement and a bequest to the city's future.
Orchard Beach, the Triborough, Throgs Neck and Verrazano-Narrows Bridges, Lincoln Center, Shea Stadium, the Grand Central and Belt Parkways, Stuyvesant Town, Co-op City: these and scores of other projects realized by Moses are, of course, represented on the model. Indeed, to make them stand out from the wood and plastic versions of the city's other buildings, Moses had many of the models for his projects cast in brass. But the legacy he wished to leave to the future was more than the sum of its architectural parts. It was his panoramic vision, an overview sufficiently encompassing to embrace all the parts within one massive urban whole. This was his gift to city planning. He could not conceive of building a city any other way.
In the age of computer simulation, the Panorama comes across as a very primitive planning tool. A school child with a Sim City program can erect a metropolis in a fraction of the time, and at a fraction of the cost, that it took to create this metropolis in miniature. But even when the Panorama was new, the way of thinking it reflected had become outmoded. The future rejected the sweeping vision Moses tried to bestow upon it.
By 1964, the concept of master planning had fallen into disrepute. Critics like Jane Jacobs fought successfully against huge urban renewal projects for housing and transportation. The bridges and parkways planned by Moses, once symbols of the heroic builder, came to represent his abandonment of mass transit. The God's-eye view represented in the Panorama had come to represent an arrogance that citizens were no longer willing to tolerate. Instead of concentrating power in one man's hands, the city began to decentralize authority with newly empowered community boards and citizen groups, who took as their focus the neighborhood, the street, and the connective urban tissue Moses and his bulldozers had ripped to shreds.
Today, 30 years later, many people are less inclined to judge Moses so harshly. The decay of the city's infrastructure has made it easier to look back with appreciation at a figure who was able to get so many public-works projects off the drawing boards. It is wonderful, of course, that New Yorkers get to see their Panorama all patched up. But when will we see the overhaul of the city it represents?
Although the Panorama never had much future as a planning tool, its usefulness as a city of memories and dreams has increased with the years. Looking down on it from the vertiginous ramps that Mr. Vinoly has suspended along the museum walls, one is reminded of the feeling one gets sometimes while looking at the Manhattan skyline from the window of a plane: the relief of getting away from it all, or of coming back home determined to shrink yesterday's mountains into mole hills.
But visitors walking along the ramps can gaze down into wistfulness also, as the memory follows the eye along those miniature avenues, zooming down into neighborhoods that have irrevocably changed (should preservation laws apply to toy towns?), scanning streets once walked along with yearning. It's always back to the drawing board in New York.
Restoration of the Panorama, which took two years and cost $1 million, was performed by Lester Associates, the West Nyack, N.Y., firm that originally built it. Maps and aerial photographs were consulted to bring the model up to date. In 1964, the model contained more than 800,000 buildings; this inventory has now been increased by nearly 95,000 new structures, including a number of scale models donated by architectural firms during the building boom of the 1980's.
The buildings are mounted on 275 panels, of Formica and foam, which have been cleaned and repainted. Thousands of lights, originally color-coded to identify hospitals, schools and other municipal services, have been incorporated into the Panorama's night scene. All the buildings have been recoated with ultraviolet paint to create a glowing glimpse of New York after dark.
Perhaps the most conspicuous change documented by the renovation is the explosion of development on Staten Island. Thirty years ago, it was still possible to think of the island as a rural enclave. Today, as the eye scans an almost seamless carpet of suburban houses, it is easy to see why many Staten Island residents would want to secede from New York City. They're already living in another world. (But why, some Manhattan chauvinists will be tempted to grumble, doesn't their island pull out first?)
The restored Panorama is only one portion of a master plan that has been slowly transforming the Queens Museum of Art into one of the city's handsomest places for viewing art. New galleries, an auditorium and a ravishing sense of open, flowing space are among the features of Mr. Vinoly's superb design. The museum, which houses a public ice-skating rink in its eastern wing, still serves as a repository for the Metropolitan Museum of Art's collection of plaster cast sculptures. Some of these are displayed on a mezzanine overlooking the Unisphere, now clearly visible through new plate-glass windows in the museum's main facade.
The Unisphere itself was renovated earlier this year, and, for those who actually visited the 1964-65 World's Fair, it can be a remarkable jolt to walk out of the Panorama and behold the great steel globe gleaming in the autumn sun, like a polished piece of memory brought back to the light of day.
 
 
Where and When
 Back on permanent display after a two-year restoration is the Panorama of the City of New York at the Queens Museum of Art, New York City Building, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park. In addition, the history of the museum's site is told with photographs, prints and other memorabilia in the new permanent exhibition "A Panoramic View: The History of the New York City Building and Its Site."
Museum hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 5 P.M. Admission: $4; $1.50 for students and the elderly; free for members and those under 5. Information: (718) 592-9700.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Five boroughs worth of miniature buildings, streets, parks and bridges: The new installation of the Panorama, originally conceived as a serious tool for urban planning, is now on view. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times) (pg. C7)

HEADLINE: The G.O.P. Assault on Welfare

 BODY:
The welfare reform proposal drafted by House Republicans would violate good sense by turning welfare programs over to the states. It would violate common decency by victimizing millions of children, including legal immigrants. It would even violate the reasonable notion that Government should help needy Americans willing to work.
What the House Republicans have in mind is not reform but a grotesque assault on the poor for the sake of honoring their ideological war on Government. Its punitive measures go way beyond what conservative Democrats and Republicans, let alone President Clinton, have recently proposed. 
 The draft's overriding theme is that welfare spending should be largely controlled by states. This is exactly wrong. States may be the right places to locate many programs Washington now runs, but welfare is not one of them. States have a huge financial incentive to skimp on benefits -- to drive poor residents out and persuade the poor from other states never to enter. Note that states eviscerated welfare benefits during the 1970's and 1980's while Washington kept Federal benefits whole.
The draft would tear holes in the social safety net that has been built in stages, with strong bipartisan support, since the Depression. Food stamps and cash benefits are Federal entitlements for every eligible family. The House Republicans would rip up this sacred contract, putting an annual limit on Federal expenditures. The change would be profound: come a recession, when the number of families qualifying for food stamps and welfare rises, Washington would not spend an extra dime.
Private charities might pick up the slack. States might spend their own money -- though few will rush to raise taxes during recessions. More probably, the needy will go empty handed. A long-term female worker who loses her job during a recession will be put on a waiting list for welfare -- though she paid taxes for years. Federal welfare was started during the Depression to save children no matter where they lived. The need remains.
The Republicans plan to cut Federal spending on welfare, food, housing and nutrition by about $60 billion over four years. The biggest reduction is aimed at legal immigrants, who would become ineligible. Even Proposition 187, passed in California this month, did not go after legal immigrants, who work and pay taxes like everyone else.
There has been a huge increase in the number of elderly immigrants on welfare. But that problem could be solved humanely, as Mr. Clinton proposes, by extending the period during which an immigrant's sponsor would be financially responsible.
The Republicans say their aim is to allow people to climb out of poverty by no longer providing a perpetual meal ticket. But they have no compunction about sawing off the ladder. They omit requirements that states provide education and training. They allow states to cut off welfare after two years -- and require a cutoff after five years -- to mothers who are working at public jobs but cannot find private sector jobs. Mr. Clinton would continue subsidized work as long as necessary.
The draft proposal would also cut off children born out of wedlock and children whose paternity had not been legally established -- even if the mother had supplied the name. Newt Gingrich, the next Speaker, glibly assumes that people thus excluded will find refuge in private charities or public orphanages.
But if Mr. Gingrich is wrong, consider the outcomes: A 30-year-old mother gets laid off but is permanently ineligible for welfare because she exhausted her two-year limit as a teen-ager. A young mother and her child go hungry because the state bureaucracy dawdles in establishing paternity.
The Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a think tank that studies poverty programs, estimates that the proposal would knock five million children -- about half the current caseload -- off welfare. That is not reform. That is carnage.

HEADLINE: Fed Raises Interest Rates on Dubious Grounds;
Slow the Money Supply

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Who really believes the nonsense from the Federal Reserve when it says that increasing its interest rates will somehow decrease inflation ("Misplaced Fears About the Fed," editorial, Nov. 17)? 
 A different power of the Federal Reserve has a much greater impact on inflation. That is the ability to make the money supply grow at rates higher or lower than the growth of the economy in general. Economists know that inflation is mainly the result of the money supply's growing faster than the economy. If the Fed were truly serious about reducing inflation, it would mandate that the money supply grow only as fast as the economy, say 2 or 3 percent a year.
This would be a welcome safeguard. Unfortunately, in 90 years the Fed has refused to offer the American public this guarantee. Instead, it seems to want to inflict inflation and deflation at will.
 
CARL OLSON
Chairman
Fund for Stockowners Rights
Washington, Nov. 18, 1994

HEADLINE: Unable to Protect Product Trademarks, Manufacturers Copyright the Boxes

BYLINE: By SALLIE HOFMEISTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 24

 BODY:
If Parfums Givenchy and other premium-product makers continue to prevail in their use of copyright law, consumers could find fewer cut-rate deals on prestige perfume, cosmetics, crystal ware and other luxury goods at their local discount stores.
 That, at least, is the implication of a Federal appeals court ruling here last month that stopped Drug Emporium Inc., the discount-drugstore chain, from selling Givenchy's Amarige scent at prices as much as 35 percent below suggested retail. Drug Emporium has asked for a new hearing. 
 Drug Emporium is one of thousands of unauthorized distributors of "gray goods," high-priced brand-name products that escape their manufacturers' distribution systems and find their way into discount and off-price stores.
 Givenchy's legal success hinged on its novel use of an obscure section of copyright law that prohibits the unauthorized importing into the United States of copyrighted goods made for other markets. Since only original text, recordings and designs can be copyrighted, Givenchy protected its imported fragrance by copyrighting the design of the box.
 The decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, to uphold this use of copyright could set off an avalanche of suits, threatening discount retailers that rely on importers for their bargains.
 "This is going to go far beyond cosmetics," said R. Lawrence Bonner, a lawyer with Greer, Homer & Bonner in Miami, who represents Drug Emporium. "Every product manufactured overseas that comes in a box can use this approach if their boxes are found to have artistic merit, and that has grave implications for consumers. A huge portion of the products at stores like Kmart and 47th Street Photo are bought from unauthorized importers."
 A Federal district court in Los Angeles recently ruled in favor of Lladro Inc., a Spanish manufacturer of porcelain figurines, in a copyright-infringement case against a company now called Price/Costco. Curtis A. Bradley, a lawyer at Covington & Burling in Washington, who represents Lladro and Givenchy, said he expected the court to issue an injunction barring Costco from selling the figurines.
 Already, the case has reignited a long-simmering debate in legal and marketing circles that pits consumers' interest in low prices against the right of manufacturers to protect their markets and the quality of their products.
 "Why should U.S. consumers pay higher prices than the rest of the world?" asked David Stewart, a marketing professor at the University of Southern California in Los Angeles. "That is price discrimination that would be illegal if it happened within the United States."
 But manufacturers argue that they should be able to charge whatever local markets will bear without goods' being diverted to the discount aisles, costing them millions of dollars in revenue. Such sales, the manufacturers contend, also tarnish their image and that of their products -- which, sold like cheap trinkets, may be damaged and without valid warranties.
 Givenchy, for example, says unauthorized distributors have sold perfume that spoiled from sitting too long on foreign docks in the hot sun. "As the manufacturer, we're the one who is culpable in the consumer's mind," said Robert Brady, president of Parfums Givenchy Inc., the American subsidiary of Parfums Givenchy S.A. "It's very damaging to the image of quality we have spent millions to build."
 No one knows how many goods made for other markets migrate back into the United States without the makers' consent, but the manufacturers have estimated that they lose as much as $15 billion a year to the gray market. As much as 25 percent of the fragrances sold in the United States are gray goods, according to the Coalition to Preserve the Integrity of American Trademarks in Washington, whose members include Ford, Givenchy, Benetton, Chanel, Macy's and Procter & Gamble.
 Many manufacturers hope that the Givenchy victory marks a turning point in the gray-market wars. Earlier this month, the company broadened its attack beyond Drug Emporium by filing copyright-infringement lawsuits against a band of unauthorized distributors, including Wal-Mart, Sears and Kmart.
 Swarovski America Ltd., a subsidiary of the Austrian crystal company, has a pending copyright-infringement suit against Price/Costco. And copyright lawyers say several cosmetics companies are considering similar actions. The Lancaster Group U.S.A., for example, has copyrighted the bottles and boxes of its fragrances, including Cool Water and Joop!
 Because gray goods are usually authentic, not counterfeit, the Supreme Court ruled in 1988 that the Customs Service cannot stop them from entering the country. Trademark laws are ineffective because they require manufacturers to show that the imports differ from the domestic brands and therefore confuse consumers. Such distinctions can be impossible to prove since many companies are manufacturing the same product lines worldwide to increase efficiency.
 But in overhauling the copyright laws in 1976, Congress responded to lobbying efforts of the book and record industries and wrote a provision, Section 602, aimed at helping manufacturers combat the gray market.
 As the gray market has grown, so has the law's use. But its reliability as a weapon for packaged-goods companies was sealed with the Givenchy decision.
 The appeals court rejected Drug Emporium's use of the "first sale" doctrine, in which the discounter argued that Givenchy had given up its rights to protection once it sold its perfumes to suppliers abroad. The doctrine is based on the principle that the copyright owner has benefited economically from a first sale and cannot further control sales of the product.
 Judge Mariana F. Pfaelzer ruled that the first sale doctrine applies only to sales in the United States and that Givenchy had been deprived of such sales because of the unauthorized distribution by Drug Emporium.

LENGTH: 1506 words

HEADLINE: Oregon's 'Out-of-Step' Senator Steps Forward

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 20

 BODY:
Term limits, a balanced budget amendment, school prayer -- these are "phony" solutions to the nation's problems. The military budget needs to be cut. The death penalty violates Christian principles. And there is nothing wrong with being a liberal.
Senator Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon, the man espousing those post-election heresies, is a lifelong Republican who is nearing the end of his third full decade in the Senate. He says, proudly, that he spent most of the years under President Reagan trying to undermine his program, and that he is the only active senator who has never voted for a military authorization bill. 
 "I've been out of step most of my political life," said Mr. Hatfield, looking down at the sweep of the Willamette River from his office here. "What else is new?"
What's new is that the Senate Appropriations Committee will once again be in the hands of Mr. Hatfield, who is perhaps the closest thing in Congress to a pacifist -- or "a McGovern-nik," to use the words of House Speaker-to-be Newt Gingrich of Georgia.
In fact, George McGovern was once Senator Hatfield's closest ally on military matters, joining forces with him long ago to propose a legislative amendment to end the Vietnam War.
As a young Navy officer in World War II, Mr. Hatfield was one of the first Americans to see Hiroshima after the atomic bomb was dropped on it in 1945. The horror lives with him, he said, and resonates in such actions as his lone vote in the Senate against both military action and economic sanctions in the Persian Gulf war of 1991.
At age 72, Mr. Hatfield has long been known as the politician of peace and pork from faraway Oregon, a state where there is no better compliment than being called a maverick.
It seems 1995 may just be Oregon's year. The Ducks, from the University of Oregon, will start the New Year in the Rose Bowl, a West Coast football champion for the first time since 1958. And every penny that will be spent by the Federal Government, outside of Social Security and other so-called entitlements, will have to pass through the committee led by a man from a state with less than 2 percent of the nation's population. Oregon's other Republican Senator, Bob Packwood, weakened two years ago by accusations of sexual misconduct, will be back in charge of rewriting the nation's tax laws as chairman of the Finance Committee, which he headed in the early 1980's.
While the galloping elephants of the new Republican-controlled Congress have been hailing the dawn of a conservative era, Mr. Hatfield has been sitting back in Oregon, newly energized, a large grin on his face. The Clinton Administration has certainly noticed; a day after the election, six Cabinet members called him.
"I'm prepared to work with the White House," he said. "I can't afford to be a partisan guerrilla." Thwarting the expected attack on domestic programs and attempt to raise military spending will require "bridge-building" with a lot of Democrats, he said.
From 1981 to 1987, the last time Mr. Hatfield served as chairman of the Appropriations panel, he was able to divert $100 billion that President Reagan wanted for the Pentagon into social programs instead. He fought the proposed "Stars Wars" missile defense system with passion, urging Democrats to join him in opposing "this madness," as he called it.
This time around it will be much harder to accomplish such changes in spending.
"These Republicans are talking about building a fire wall between discretionary defense and discretionary nondefense programs, meaning that if we had the votes, we couldn't turn it over like we did in the 1980's," he said.
But that does not mean Mr. Hatfield will not try to shrink the military budget. With the cold war over, there is no reason for spending billions on elaborate weapons systems, he said.
"The way to do this is to point out all the redundancies in our arsenal," he said. "They used to say, 'What about the Russians?' Well, who are the Russians this time?"
When Iraq was mentioned, he laughed. "I don't look at Saddam Hussein as a threat," he said. "I see diminishing oil supply as a threat, and Saddam is a symbol of that."
He said the military budget could be cut by reducing the Pentagon's civilian work force by 15,000 employees and by turning down new weapons systems.
Mr. Hatfield's staunchest opponents are likely to be from his own party. The Appropriations defense subcommittee includes Republicans like Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, Phil Gramm of Texas and Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, none of them wallflowers when it comes to advocating military might. Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska will be the chairman.
"We have voted against each other in the past," said Senator Stevens, when asked about how he would try to steer the subcommittee around Senator Hatfield. "But we have never had an open fight."
Mr. Stevens added: "I respect his position. It is deeply felt. But he knows how I feel about the defense structure."
On other matters, Mr. Hatfield seems to relish being the spoiler at the Republican garden party. He rolled his eyes when asked about Mr. Gingrich's "Contract With America," the blueprint for the Republican Congress.
A deeply religious man who has written three books about matters of faith, Mr. Hatfield opposes a constitutional amendment to allow officially sanctioned prayer in public schools. He also thinks mandatory term limits for elected officials are not needed. "Look at what happened to Tom Foley," he said of his Northwest colleague, ousted by voters in Washington state this month after 30 years in the House. And he opposes a constitutional amendment to require a balanced budget.
"These are all symbols, and the Republicans will beat the drums and get a lot of pizazz going because they have fed the public a line about these things," he said. "But to present them as if they are the answers and solutions to our problems is just phony."
He sees parallels between the proposed amendments and President Reagan's tax cuts in the 1980's. "The biggest increase in our deficit in history took place in those years under a man presented as the high priest of conservatism," Mr. Hatfield said. "It was another example of imagery versus substance."
Mr. Hatfield is not always on the liberal side; he has opposed abortion, for example. But with all the positions he has staked out to the left of his party, it is a wonder he is still a Republican. He said he became one in the 1940's because he believed in civil rights and considered the Southern Democrats who controlled so much of Congress to be racists. Among current Republican Senators, only Strom Thurmond of South Carolina has served longer than Mr. Hatfield.
Senator Hatfield says he is proud to be called a liberal Republican. "Lincoln was a liberal," he said.
He has struggled through some low points, being formally rebuked by the Senate Ethics Committee in 1992 for failing to disclose gifts worth more than $43,000.
Long considered a friend of environmentalists, he said he was hurt by insults hurled at him in the fight over Northwest forests. "They called me a pimp of the timber industry," he said. "We have 43 wild and scenic rivers in this state, more than two million acres of wilderness, and nobody can match my record on these things."
But now, with the election having made Mr. Hatfield perhaps the most powerful friend of the environment in Congress, environmentalists are coming to him on bended knee, looking to him as the savior of public land in the Pacific Northwest. He said he will try for no more than "fine-tuning" of the Endangered Species Act, considered the most powerful environmental law on the books. And he will not try to force the Forest Service to allow more timber cutting than provided by law -- a tack he tried in the mid-1980's.
"The halo is back on Mark Hatfield," said James Moore, a professor of political science at the University of Portland. "Even with that ethics lapse, he has been remarkably consistent."
With two years to go in his fifth term, Mr. Hatfield was thought to be contemplating retirement, after nearly 50 years in Oregon politics, from state legislator to Governor to the Senate. Now, back in power and in the limelight, he is not so sure.
"I only have $30,000 in the bank," he said. "But you know what: I've decided to hold a fund-raiser next month."
 
Senator Mark O. Hatfield
 
BORN: July 12, 1922, in Dallas, Ore.
 
 EDUCATION: Salem High School; B.A., 1943, Willamette University, political science; M.A., 1948, Stanford University, political science.
 
 MILITARY: As Navy lieutenant during World War II, commanded landing craft at Iwo Jima and Okinawa.
 
 EARLY CAREER: Associate professor of political science and dean of students at Willamette University, 1949-1956.
 
 POLITICAL CAREER: Various Oregon state offices; Governor, 1958-66. First elected to Senate in 1966.
 
 FAMILY: Wife, Antoinette; four children, three grandchildren.
 
 HOBBIES: Rare books, Presidential history.

Companies
 
The chairman who turned Sony into an innovative power resigned. Sony said Akio Morita, 73, who co-founded the Japanese company, was stepping down because of health problems. During his 22 years as chairman, Sony achieved spectacular successes with its television sets, stereo equipment, video cameras and the much-imitated Walkman tape player. [Page 39.]
 
Goldman, Sachs will coordinate the sale of Deutsche Telekom to investors outside Germany. The sale of Germany's telephone company is the largest privatization ever in Europe. The appointment as one of three global coordinators is a coup for Goldman, which will reap huge investment banking fees. [39.]
 
The Westin Hotel Company will be sold in a $561 million deal to a joint venture formed by Starwood Capital; Goldman, Sachs, and the Edward Thomas Companies of Beverly Hills, Calif. [39.]
 
Mayflower Group is in talks to sell its household-moving business to the private company that operates United Van Lines. Shares of Mayflower jumped 15 percent after the announcement. [41.]
 
Two of Britain's biggest home-lending companies plan to merge and go public, creating a $140.6 billion banking company. [41.]
 
In an unusual move, Maine helped Central Maine Power buy an independent plant that provided it with electricity. [41.]
 
The German financier who runs Lonrho sold a stake in the Kempinski hotel chain to a Thai joint venture for $83.5 million. Dieter Bock is shedding his holdings to focus on Lonrho. [41.]
 
 
The Economy
 
The holiday shopping season began, even if many people did not begin shopping. For now, many shoppers are still looking for bargains rather than loading up on presents. [39.]
 
Created to stop racial discrimination in the workplace, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission is choking on bureaucracy and a mounting backlog of discrimination charges. [1.]
 
 
Markets
 
Stock prices recovered some ground in light, post-holiday trading. But stocks fell across Europe, hurt by expectations that when most of Wall Street returns on Monday, stock prices will continue their slide. The Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 2.36 points. [39.]
 
Treasury prices were mixed after two sessions of strong gains. Investors who had fled stocks for bonds earlier this week apparently decided that the selloff in stocks had subsided. [47.]
 
Uncovered short sales in stocks traded on the Nasdaq system fell for the third consecutive month. [50.]
 
The dollar was little changed in quiet trading. The Italian lira continued to slide against the German mark and the dollar. [51.]
 
Soybean, corn and pork prices were higher on a day when most commodity markets were closed. [51.]
 
 
Your Money
 
Investor gloom is a silver lining for some investment advisers. After this week's sharp decline in stocks, many investors expect the worse, which means, these contrarians argue, that the smallest ray of hope can make the market climb. [36.]
 
Cyclical stocks are a disparate group of issues, united only by a general tendency to mirror the direction of the economy. But cyclical stocks manage eventually to go in one direction, as the Morgan Stanley Cyclical Index shows. [36.]
 
Tuesday will be an important date for investors who plan to close out losing investment positions before the year ends. [36.]
 
Money transfer services have grown in recent years. Generally, the faster the service, the more expensive it is. [38.]

HEADLINE: Short Day Gives Dow 33.64 Gain

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The stock market recovered yesterday about a fifth of the ground it has lost since Nov. 16. The few traders on the floor in a shortened session on the day after Thanksgiving tended to buy interest rate-sensitive stocks whose prices had fallen because of the Federal Reserve's six increases in short-term interest rates so far this year.
 Bond prices were mixed, and the dollar was little changed. European stock traders bid down prices overseas yesterday, convinced that when most of Wall Street returns on Monday, stock prices in the United States will continue their slide.
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 33.64 points, to 3,708.27, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 rose 2.36 points, to 452.29. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 5.82 points, to 742.52.
 Still, the Dow had fallen for five sessions in a row before yesterday, for a total drop of more than 170 points. Yesterday's advance meant about a 20 percent recovery in the Dow.
 "I had been expecting something of a snapback," said James B. Macko, vice president for equity trading at McDonald & Company Investments in Cleveland. "But I had expected it next week. Today may be a small portion of that snapback."
 Broader indexes have also fallen. The S.& P. 500 had fallen 15.69 points in five sessions, and with yesterday's advance had recovered about 15 percent. The Nasdaq index dropped 32.94 points for the same period and gained back nearly 18 percent. Even one of the broadest possible measures, the Wilshire index of 5,000 stocks, had dropped 165.55 points, but recovered nearly 17 percent.
 Yesterday, seven stocks advanced for every three that declined, or 1,496 winning stocks and 564 losing stocks on the New York Stock Exchange.
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was far below normal at 113.9 million shares because the exchange closed at 1 P.M., instead of 4 P.M.
 In Europe, British stock prices fell one-tenth of 1 percent, German stocks fell two-tenths of 1 percent, but French stocks rose six-tenths of 1 percent. While local issues affected the outcome, most traders cited uncertainty in American financial markets as a drag on their markets.
 In Britain, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 issues fell 3.1 points, to 3,033.5, in part because Prime Minister John Major faced a parlimentary vote on Monday on payments to the European Union that threatens to bring down his Government. In Germany, the DAX index of 30 stocks fell 4.35 points, to 2,051.62, as some investors started shifting investments to bonds out of stocks. But in France, the CAC index of 40 stocks rose 11.21 points, to 1945.89.
 In the United States, most stocks that advanced were those that investors had shunned at earlier points in the year because of the Fed's tightening of interest rates. These groups included chemical companies, drug manufacturers, retailers, computer software developers, electric utilities, computer makers and banks.
 American depository receipts of Sony rose 1 1/4, to 51 3/4, despite a large write-off for its movie-studio operations and yesterday's resignation of its co-founder, Akio Morita. Mr. Morita suffered a cerebral hemorrhage a year ago.
 Musicland Stores established a 52-week low of 12 3/8, down 2. A Smith Barney analyst lowered her assessment of the speciality retailer to "underperform" from "neutral, " citing discount pricing and higher advertising costs.
 The most active stock, at 2.4 million shares, was Intel, which fell 1 1/4, to 63 7/8. The company has acknowledged that its Pentium computer chip could cause inaccurate results in rare cases in complex scientific calculations and that newer chips have been corrected.
 Shares of Gibson Greetings rose 1 1/8, to 13 7/8. Gibson and Bankers Trust announced on Wednesday that they had agreed to settle Gibson's lawsuit accusing the bank of improperly leading the company to engage in risky financial trades. Bankers Trust shares rose 3/8, to 57 1/8.
 The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 1.42 points, to 247.60, and the American Stock Exchange market value index gained 2.29 points, to 434.69.
 Of the 30 component stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 21 rose, led by Alcoa, which rose 2 3/8, to 80 3/8. Of the 500 component stocks that make up the S.& P. 500, 286 rose, led by Merck, which gained 3/4, to 36 5/8.
 In Tokyo, stocks were slightly lower. The Nikkei index of 225 issues lost 34.31 points, or two-tenths of 1 percent, at 18,666.93. For the week, which was shortened by a national holiday on Wednesday, the Nikkei was down 635.63 points.
