HEADLINE: Five Years Later: Eastern Europe, Post-Cummunism -- A special report;
Ethnic and Religious Conflicts Now Threaten Europe's Stability

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina

 BODY:
Five years after the fall of the Berlin wall, Checkpoint Charlie has moved 600 miles southeast to a bridge over the Miljacka River in Sarajevo, where coils of barbed wire and occasional tearful family reunions testify to the new divisions of Europe.
Here at the bridge, Benjamin Hamidovic, a Bosnian Muslim, stands guard. He gazes out, past the wire and the French United Nations soldiers in their blue helmets, to the far side, held and guarded by Bosnian Serbs. It is very close, the other bank, but eerily distant -- another land in a severed city. 
 The division at this bridge is new but no less treacherous than the old one between cold-war ideologies. Mr. Hamidovic is one of the myriad people who have already fallen victim to the ethnic and religious conflicts that lurked beneath the clamp of Communism and have since erupted, revealing the fragility of the societies and borders once behind the Iron Curtain.
As yet, the West has no coherent response to these conflicts; indeed, the United States and Western Europe have been divided by them. Their failure to work together to end the Bosnian war suggests that the security of Europe, now lacking effective guarantees, will be uncertain for many years.
Economic progress and political opening were supposed to follow Communism in Eastern Europe. They were the logical consequence of what the West saw as its victory over totalitarianism. Instead the Caucasus has erupted, and Yugoslavia has seen an atavistic retreat into nationalist fury that has cast the shadow of concentration camps and the Serbian slaughter of Bosnia's Muslims across the European Continent.
Against this madness, grand Wilsonian principles like the self-determination of peoples and grand institutions like the United Nations and NATO have proved no insurance. All of them will probably have to be rethought after the death of 250,000 people and the displacement of two million in a Bosnian conflict born of old grievances, economic stagnation, the cynical leadership of Communists-turned-nationalists and Western disarray.
Certainly, the gloom of Bosnia has come not only from the fighting. It has also stemmed from the way NATO, the European Union and the United Nations have been revealed as cumbersome and divided before the ethnic conflicts of post-Communist Europe.
In July, President Clinton was celebrating cooperation between the United States and Europe during the cold war. "No wall can forever contain the mighty power of freedom," he intoned in Berlin, at the site of the wall that once divided the city. But he did not mention the divided city of Sarajevo, where American soldiers have been as conspicuously absent as they were decisively present in Berlin, and his words rang hollow in a Europe now increasingly bereft of American leadership.
Of course Sarajevo is not Berlin, at least not yet; a division of the world into hostile blocs does not lurk behind the city's barriers. But it is far from clear that Europe's new cleavages, rooted in the vagaries of tribal allegiance, are less menacing than those of the cold war. Already, the potential of Bosnia's rival armies to be proxies for a resurgent Islam and for pan-Slavic sentiment is apparent.
Across the Miljacka River bridge, in the Grbavica section of Sarajevo, Mr. Hamidovic had his house until old suspicions between Bosnian Serbs and Muslims erupted into war in 1992. He and his Serbian wife fled in June, 1992, sending their 12-year-old daughter to her grandmother in Belgrade for what they imagined would be a brief sojourn. They have not seen her since.
"I've tried to talk to her on a ham radio, but her voice sounds so terrible," Mr. Hamidovic said, shaking his head. "I really feel totally crazy."
 
Disintegration
Ethnic Memories Foster Disunity
 Already the three states in Eastern Europe without a clear ethnic identity -- the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia and Yugoslavia -- have disintegrated since the fall of Communism five years ago.
But fertile soil for the Yugoslav disease exists elsewhere in Eastern Europe and the Balkans. Long subservience to alien empires or Communist rulers, economic backwardness, historical grievances and the general absence of democratic tradition have created receptive audiences for militant nationalism, which has a facile appeal in that it promises a glorious future on the basis of a supposedly glorious past.
There are more than 25 million ethnic Russians outside Russia, at least 2.3 million ethnic Hungarians outside Hungary, at least 2.2 million ethnic Albanians in Macedonia and the Kosovo region of Serbia, a vociferous Greek minority in Albania and a large Turkish minority in Bulgaria.
If Serbian claims to territory could bring an intractable war to the Balkans, what of an eventual explosion of Russian nationalism under Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, or an Albanian drive to unite its people in a single country or a sudden Hungarian itch to recover the large swaths of territory lost to Romania, Yugoslavia and Czechoslovakia after World War I?
Unease is evident. Ethnic Albanians vow to achieve autonomy, or even independent states, in Kosovo and western Macedonia. Greece has expelled more than 50,000 ethnic Albanians in reprisal for the arrest of five ethnic Greeks in Albania. The ethnic Russians in the Baltic states and the Ukraine are a lingering source of tension.
Romania's Hungarian minority is fuming over a recent decision by the local authorities to remove a bronze statue of the 15th-century king Mathias from the Transylvanian city of Cluj because, some Romanians say, he symbolizes 500 years of Hungarian oppression before Transylvania became Romanian after World War I.
Averting these dangers is arduous. The Iron Curtain was all of a piece: it could be policed, and American troops, among others, did so. But the jagged fragments of old enmities are a mined and scattered terrain.
"The Yugoslav war has revealed Western institutions as bungling, incompetent and powerless," said Jonathan Eyal, the director of studies at the Institute of Strategic Studies in London. "We thought we could bark and people in the Balkans would listen, but they defied us and found us naked. The message that sends is terrible. The only question now is how violent the Bosnian war will be and how far will it spread?"
 
The 'Freezer'
Brief Stability In Communism
 It is now clear that if Communism brought oppression to the people of Central and Eastern Europe, it also brought stability to the group of countries that emerged with the collapse of the Russian, Ottoman, Austro-Hungarian and German empires after World War I. Yugoslavia was formed as the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes, Czechoslovakia was created from the ashes of the Hapsburg Empire, Poland was reborn, Hungary was drastically diminished by the Trianon treaty, and Romania was enlarged at Hungary's expense.
But these new or extensively remodeled countries were promptly savaged by the Depression, then by World War II, and never had time to develop democratic institutions or a secure identity.
From the start, this insecurity found expression in ethnic tensions and the persecution of minorities. Throughout the area, Jews were often the object of discrimination, rendering Nazi Germany's program of extermination much easier to carry out when Hitler's forces overran or subdued most of Eastern Europe.
In this sense, the latest outbreak of ethnic violence and bigotry on the volatile soil of Eastern Europe should have come as no surprise. But a kind of complacency among Western leaders -- a New-World-Order fogginess, even a vague notion that history was ending -- may have blurred the fact that history was really beginning again, and at full throttle, with the disappearance of Communism.
"Communism was a freezer," said Dominique Moisi, the deputy director of the French Institute for International Studies. "It simply froze old hatreds. Unfortunately the hatreds thawed before the European Union was strong enough to provide a concerted response in the absence of real American leadership in Europe."
 
Yugoslavia
Buried by Tito, The Past Rises
 People in Eastern Europe were keenly aware of the dangers. "Each nation naturally wanted to look to the moment in history when it was strongest to prove its territorial point," said Branko Crvenkovski, the Prime Minister of a vulnerable new state, Macedonia.
Among the Serbs, the obsession was particularly acute.
Like many Bosnian Serbs, Milorad Ekmecic, a historian at Sarajevo University, was caught up in tragedy as a civil war raged in Yugoslavia during World War II.
By mid-1941, Croatia was under the control of the Nazi-puppet Fascists known as the Ustashe; Serbia was divided between Nazi collaborators and a royalist resistance known as the Chetniks; and Josip Broz, a Croat who went by the nom de guerre Tito, was emerging as leader of the ethnically mixed Communist Partisans fighting the Germans from a power base in Bosnia.
A civil war that would claim more than half of the roughly 1.5 million Yugoslavs killed in World War II had begun, amid a Ustashe campaign of extermination -- sometimes supported by Bosnian Muslims -- against Serbs, Jews and Gypsies, and a Chetnik rampage against Muslims in eastern Bosnia.
"I remember standing in the garden with my father, and the Croats and Muslims were throwing rocks at us," Mr. Ekmecic said. "Then -- it was the day after Germany invaded Russia -- my father went to work as usual at a tobacco plant. He never came home. Later, I discovered he had been taken away by the Ustashe and shot by a Muslim who worked with him."
By the end of the war, the Serbian population of the Capljina area had been halved. Mr. Ekmecic's mother, who joined the Partisans after her husband's death, was executed by the Nazis in 1943.
But when Tito, as victor, came to power after the war, his chief concern -- in the overriding interest of Yugoslav unity -- was to place a seal over Yugoslavia's civil strife and the myriad killings like that of Mr. Ekmecic's father.
In some cases, this sealing of history was quite literal. Concrete was poured over the pits in Herzegovina where the bones of countless executed Serbs lay. In other cases, history was simply ignored in the hope that it would disappear: Tito never visited the Jasenovac concentration camp, scene of the worst Ustashe crimes against the Serbs.
In official parlance, Yugoslavia's civil war became a war of liberation fought by the Yugoslavs against the Nazi invader. But the truth lay elsewhere, and as recent events show, the truth has a way of exacting a heavy price.
"The reality is that the Communists defeated Serbian and Croatian nationalism as well as the Nazis," said Milovan Djilas, one of Tito's closest aides until he broke with him in the mid-1950's over the failure to introduce democratic reform. "Yugoslav Communism alone resolved the national question after World War II. Tito was acutely aware of this, and to the end, he was afraid that Yugoslavia might break up."
But the dangers inherent in Tito's policy of burying the past are now clear. The inter-ethnic warfare of World War II, never acknowledged, never judged officially, lived on beneath the surface, ready to explode at the slightest provocation.
"A forged and false history created feelings of frustration and hatred," said Dejan Medakovic, a member of the Serbian Academy of Arts and Sciences.
Moreover, the rewriting of history could perhaps have been carried out only by a dictator. Instead of moving toward greater democracy after his break with Stalin in 1948, Tito began the elaborate balancing act that he would maintain until the end of his long life in 1980.
This policy involved offering ever greater autonomy to Yugoslavia's constituent nations and placing himself at the fulcrum, rather than extending the individual liberties, the democratic institutions and the scope for personal economic initiative that alone might have cemented Yugoslavia.
The culmination of this policy, in the 1974 Constitution, was the raising of Bosnia's Muslims to the status of a constituent nation -- a decision that gave Tito one more piece to manipulate in his balancing game.
But all games come to an end. Nationalist parties in Croatia, Serbia and Bosnia were easily able to exploit the resentments and frustrated ambitions, especially after economic stagnation in the 1980's. Yugoslavs were looking back rather than forward.
<PHB>The Prospects
Will Ethnic War Keep Spreading?
 On Aug. 4, 1990, Mr. Ekmecic went to Prebilovci in Herzegovina to exhume from a pit the bones of about 800 Serbs massacred by the Ustashe. Work began on an Orthodox monastery at the site, but its foundations were later blown up by the Catholic Croats during the Bosnian war.
Mr. Eckmecic joined the Serbian nationalist party in Bosnia because, he said, "I was terribly frightened that Yugoslavia was coming into a situation similar to the one my family passed through in 1941-45."
Fear, long frustration, deep anger -- part rational, part psychosis -- appear to have been pervasive among the substantial Serbian minorities of Croatia and Bosnia as these two former Yugoslav nations pressed for and then gained independence in 1991 and 1992, against the will of the Serbs.
In Bosnia, a murderous Serbian rampage against Muslim civilians ensued, matching horrors suffered between 1941 and 1945: concentration camps, rapes, mass executions, mutilation, evictions.
And yet, it should not have been hard to see the warning signs -- first in Croatia, and then, even more after the Croatian war, in Bosnia. The unresolved issue of the Serbian minorities was conspicuous.
James A. Baker, then United States Secretary of State, visited Belgrade in June 1991. His message, in essence, was that the United States was opposed to the breakup of Yugoslavia and opposed to the use of force to hold it together.
"It was a little too subtle for these guys," a United States official said. Shortly after Mr. Baker left, Croatia and Slovenia declared their independence.
The official added: "We were up against two conflicting principles: the inviolability of Yugoslavia's borders and self-determination. Well, the Europeans wanted the problem, so we decided to hand it over. That, of course, was a departure."
The Europeans, with pretensions to a united foreign policy but no army to make foreign policy mean anything, were incapable of any coherent approach to ethnic war on their doorstep.
By December 1991, their veneer of unity had fallen away altogether with Germany's extraordinary, unilateral recognition of Croatia and Slovenia.
When the rest of the European Union, and ultimately the United States, decided there was no way back from this German decision, the die was cast. The world was officially committed to Tito's internal borders in Yugoslavia even though they were still being disputed on the ground by rival armies of Serbs, Muslims and Croats. The issues thus raised remain unresolved.
As the Bosnian war festers, Western nations have been trying to deal better with the specter of ethnic conflict elsewhere.
At the initiative of France , nine countries -- Bulgaria, the Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Romania and Slovakia -- did commit themselves this year to negotiated solutions to any ethnic or border disputes.
The United States, meanwhile, has sent a battalion of troops to Macedonia, another small ex-Yugoslav nation, like Bosnia, born through the principle of self-determination as expressed through a referendum, but lacking any ethnic coherence or recent history as an independent state.
The troops are doing something new for American soldiers abroad: trying to stop a war from starting. That is, they are trying to stop Macedonia -- peopled by Macedonians, Albanians, Serbs, Turks, Vlachs, Greeks, Bulgarians and others -- from disintegrating like Yugoslavia, Czechoslovakia, the Soviet Union and Bosnia.
Their task is arduous. As in Bosnia, principles brought Macedonia into existence, but history and facts are against it.
Aside from internal tensions, none of Macedonia's neighbors is favorable to its existence. Greece claims exclusivity over the name Macedonia; Bulgaria says Macedonians are really Bulgarians; Serbia would be happy to absorb the country into the remains of the Yugoslav federation, and Albania sides with the aspirations for autonomy, or independence, of the large Albanian minority.
In fact, while American soldiers dutifully monitor the Macedonian-Serbian border, the real danger in Macedonia lies in the Albanians, accounting for about 30 percent of the population. In their stronghold of Tetovo, feeling is running high.
"If we don't get at least autonomy, Macedonia will not exist," said Alivebi Aboulahu, a chemistry professor. "I am certain that a Bosnian explosion will come here. Why should we be suppressed by the Macedonians in land that was always ours?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: People crossing the Miljacka River bridge in Sarajevo in the presence of a United Nations soldier earlier this year. The bridge's barbed wire, with Muslim forces at one end and Serbs on the other, testifies to the new divisions of Europe. (Laurent Sazy/Gamma-Liaison)
 
Map: "The Region Historically"
Yugoslavia, founded in 1918as the Kingdom of the Serbs, Croats and Slovenes, was the expression of the desire of the south Slav people for independence from long imperial domination -- the Austro-Hungarian empire in the western part of the territory, the Ottoman Turkish empire to the east.
 
Its problem from the outset was Serbian numerical and political domination.
 
The forebears of the Croats and Serbs settled the area in the 7th century. But tghe line of the Great Schism that divided the Eastern and Roman Churches in 1054 came between them: Croats are now Roman Catholic, Serbs Eastern Orthodox.
 
Muslims, the majority of whom live in Bosnia, were Slave who converted to Islam during the Ottoman Turkish rule of Bosnia, which lasted from 1463 to 1978, when Bosnia came under Austro-Hungarian administration.
 
When Slovenia and Croatia declared independance in 1991, followed by Bosnia in 1992, the chief political problem was the large Serbian minorities in Croatia and in Bosnia and Herzegovina. They opposed independence, and with the help of the Serb-controlled Yugoslav Army they seized large swaths of each country.

HEADLINE: Willem J. Luyten, 95, Expert on Stellar Motion

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Dr. Willem Jacob Luyten, an astronomer whose work expanded the understanding of stellar motion, dying white dwarfs and the origin of the solar system, died on Monday at his home in Minneapolis. He was 95.
 The cause was heart failure, his family said. 
 Born on Java, Dr. Luyten (pronounced LOY-ten) spent much of his career at the University of Minnesota. He started in 1930 as an assistant professor and served as professor of astronomy and department chairman for many years before reaching emeritus status in 1967.
 He was noted for his work with the photographic-plate scanner and a computerized version of the device that he developed in the 1960's. He was aided in that ambitious undertaking by financing from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the expertise of engineers of the Control Data Corporation.
 The computerized version, which was a laser scanner and measuring device, tracked stars on plates taken several years apart with the same telescope. It automated what had been a highly cumbersome process of studying star motions.
 The computerized scanner produced more than 400,000 new stellar motions from images made for the Palomar-National Geographic Survey, including more than 6,000 of the stars known as white dwarfs. Dr. Luyten found some 90 percent of the white dwarfs known to exist at the time.
 A white dwarf is an exotic stellar species of enormous density that gives off little light; it is considered the final stage of evolution of most stars. For his work in that area, colleagues sometimes referred to Dr. Luyten as the "stellar mortician."
 His favorite anecdote on the subject concerned the time he asked the National Science Foundation for financial help in organizing a conference on white dwarfs. He said his request prompted a letter from the Surgeon General "that human subjects couldn't be used for experimentation and that Federal money could not be used for race discrimination."
 The University of Minnesota did not have observational equipment, but Dr. Luyten received much help from observatories in this country and abroad. He said that international cooperation was essential among astronomers, and he liked to call himself the most successful parasite in the field.
 He was born in Semarang on Java, then part of the Dutch East Indies. As a boy, he become curious about astronomy when an uncle awakened him to marvel at Halley's Comet in 1910 as it lit up the sky, bright enough to cast a shadow. "A sight you don't forget," he said. He graduated from the University of Amsterdam and earned a doctorate in astronomy at the University of Leiden in 1921.
 He also studied at the Royal Observatory in England and the Lick Observatory of the University of California. From 1923 to 1930 he worked as an astronomer and assistant professor at Harvard University before moving to Minneapolis. He published 490 articles in 71 years of research.
 In the 1920's, while at Lick and Harvard, he also reported for The New York Times on events like the total solar eclipse of January 1925. He went up in a plane to report on the dramatic scene and photograph the moon's shadow as it moved across Manhattan.
 Dr. Luyten is survived by his wife of 64 years, Willemina Miedema Luyten; two daughters, Mona L. Coetzee of Pittsburgh, and Ann L. Dieperink of Afton, Minn.; a son, Dr. James R. Luyten of Falmouth, Mass.; seven grandchildren, and one great-granddaughter.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Shows Little Change In Holiday-Slowed Trading

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar was little changed in light, post-holiday activity yesterday.
 With a dearth of economic news and many currency dealers absent after the Thanksgiving holiday, market participants monitored American stock and bond markets to determine the direction of the dollar. 
 Hugh Walsh, currency trader at ING Capital Markets in New York, said: "Stocks performed quite well, and bonds were up a little bit. That lent support to the dollar."
 But with stocks having fallen so far earlier in the week, "it seems like the topside is limited for the dollar," said Charles Spence, director of treasury marketing at Standard Chartered Bank in New York. Currency dealers watch the American stock and bond markets to gauge foreign demand for American assets and the dollars needed to buy them.
 In New York yesterday afternoon, the dollar edged up to 1.5598 marks from 1.5556 in New York on Wednesday. The dollar rose to 98.78 yen, from 98.47 yen on Wednesday.
 "There is some good demand for dollars" from American fund managers holding overseas stocks, Mr. Spence said. Holders of overseas equities are selling foreign currencies for dollars to lock in gains that the foreign currencies have achieved in the last several months, he said.
 With foreign stock prices having fallen during recent days in tandem with stocks in the United States, American fund managers have wanted to book profits on the currency conversion to compensate for losses they have suffered on their stock holdings, Mr. Spence said.
 For example, the dollar has fallen 10.4 percent against the mark since the beginning of the year, while the Frankfurt stock exchange's DAX index of 30 stocks lost 2.5 percent this week.
 The Italian lira, meanwhile, continued to slide against the mark and the dollar as a question mark hung over the Government of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi. Milan magistrates warned him this week that he was being investigated on corruption charges.
 The lira touched 1,037.70 lire to the mark in European trading, surpassing its previous record of 1,037.40 reached on Tuesday. In New York, the dollar rose to 1,616 lire, from 1,607.50 lire on Tuesday.
 In other currency trading in New York, the British pound fell to $1.5630, from $1.5705 on Wednesday. The dollar rose to 1.3207 Swiss francs from 1.3190 francs.

HEADLINE: Milton J. Shapp Is Dead at 82: Ex-Governor of Pennsylvania

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE 

 BODY:
Milton J. Shapp, former Governor of Pennsylvania and a Philadelphia industrialist who was the first Jew to mount a campaign for the Presidential nomination of a major party, died on Thursday at Lankenau Hospital in Wynnewood, a suburb of Philadelphia. He was 82.
 The cause was Alzheimer's disease, family friends said. 
 Mr. Shapp, a Democrat, served as Governor from 1971 to 1979 and instituted a state income tax and lottery. He ran unsuccessfully for the Democratic nomination for President in 1976.
 Before he became Governor, Mr. Shapp worked on John F. Kennedy's Presidential campaign and is credited with promoting the idea that eventually led to the creation of the Peace Corps.
Fresh out of the Army Signal Corps after World War II, during which he was a captain and served in North Africa, Italy and Austria, Mr. Shapp, an electrical engineer, founded the Jerrold Electronics Corporation in 1948. The company went public in 1956 and did $25 million annually in business. A decade later, when Mr. Shapp sold his interests, the corporation's business was up to $50 million a year.
 Born in Cleveland, Milton Jerrold Shapp attended the Cleveland public schools and earned a bachelor's degree in electrical engineering from Case Institute of Technology (now Case Western Reserve University) in 1933.
 He entered public life in 1960, when he became an early supporter of Mr. Kennedy. In the 1960 election, he served as chairman of the Business and Professional Committee for John Kennedy in the Mid-Atlantic States. During that campaign, Mr. Shapp suggested to Mr. Kennedy the idea of forming a Peace Corps. In a speech at Penn State University on March 9, 1961, titled "Peace and the Peace Corps," Mr. Shapp outlined for the first time the basic policies that were to serve as a guide for the operation of that organization.
 He returned briefly to business in mid-1963, but plunged very quickly again into politics. He made an unsuccessful bid for the Senate in 1964. After that effort failed, he worked in the campaign of Lyndon B. Johnson and organized businessmen in the East for him as he had done for President Kennedy.
 In his two terms as Governor, Mr. Shapp won national attention for his consumer-advocate policies and his innovative programs for elderly and handicapped people. He was largely credited with bringing Pennsylvania back from the brink of deficit.
 Mr. Shapp also instituted full financial disclosure for top officials, the most comprehensive of the so-called Sunshine Laws for open government in the nation and a strict code of ethics for all state employees. A violinist, Mr. Shapp made his concert debut as a soloist with the Erie Philharmonic in 1978.
 In an interview during his Presidential bid in 1976, he was asked why he was running.
 "I compare myself to the people who were talking about becoming candidates," he answered. "In knowledge of the economy, in ability to develop programs and get them implemented, and I couldn't see anybody comparable. I saw the caliber of these people and I said, 'What the hell.' "
 But he withdrew in March of that year after having picked up only one delegate. He blamed a late start and "putrid" news coverage for his poor showing in a crowded field of Presidential aspirants.
 In a 1981 letter to The New York Times, Mr. Shapp sharply criticized President Ronald Reagan's sale of Awacs electronic-warfare planes to Saudi Arabia.
 "It would be far more beneficial to America's future economy and to its security if the President would implement a major civilian Awacs program by beginning a war against city slums in our nation," he wrote. "Unless we soon start to cope realistically with our major internal problems, no amount of sophisticated weapons in our possession or in the hands of so-called allies will be able to stave off internal disruption."
 Mr. Shapp battled Alzheimer's for several years, said Richard Gross, a family friend.
 He is survived by his wife, Muriel; two daughters, Dolores Graham and Joanne Shapp; a son, Richard, and three grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Man In The News;
Soul Mate For Pataki -- Joseph Louis Bruno

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 25

 BODY:
With the ascension of Joseph L. Bruno as the presumptive majority leader of the State Senate, Governor-elect George E. Pataki has gained a political and philosophical soul mate at the top of state government.
 Mr. Bruno is, above all, a fiscal conservative who has argued relentlessly about the need to cut state spending and taxes during his 18 years in the Senate. And unlike the man he deposed, Ralph J. Marino, he is both a gregarious colleague in the Senate and an eager, sharp-tongued spokesman for his beliefs. 
 With his shock of white hair, his regal posture and his deliberate style of speech, Mr. Bruno has the bearing of a circus ringmaster. As he demonstrated with the coup he completed today, he is ambitious and capable of playing a mean brand of Albany politics. He lured Mr. Marino into complacency two weeks ago by issuing a statement saying he would not challenge the leader, then quietly reversed course and gathered the votes he needed before Mr. Marino could defend himself.
 "I think Joe moves quietly but effectively," said Thomas G. Cholakis, the Republican leader in Rensselaer County, where Mr. Bruno lives, across the Hudson River from Albany.
 The 65-year-old Mr. Bruno was one of the first Republican state senators to endorse Mr. Pataki, and he is close personally to Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and the state Republican chairman, William D. Powers. Mr. Powers, a former D'Amato aide whom Mr. D'Amato picked to lead the state party, lives in Mr. Bruno's district, and the two men are close friends.
 Several Republican senators said today that Mr. Bruno's selection, coming so quickly after Mr. Pataki's election and the strengthening of Mr. D'Amato's grip on the state party, was the death knell for New York's signature brand of moderate Rockefeller Republicanism. Mr. Bruno, perhaps even more than Mr. Pataki, hails from the upstate wing of the party that is both fiscally and socially conservative.
 He supports the death penalty, opposes abortion rights and opposes legislation to insure civil rights for homosexuals. A businessman who built a telecommunications company from scratch and became a millionaire, he abhors the state's policies on taxation and business regulation. During his first 13 years in the Legislature, he bucked the leadership of the Senate to vote against budget bills that included tax increases, as Mr. Pataki has done in recent years. In the last five years, he voted for budgets that included increases in taxing and spending in order to show support for Mr. Marino, he said.
 Mr. Bruno said in an interview today that he shares core beliefs with Mr. Pataki.
 "The things he believes and talks about," Mr. Bruno said, "are things I've been talking about for years and years: too much taxation, too much spending, mandates that aren't funded for municipalities, and over-regulation. We smother people. We smother business, and government has been too oppressive. That's got to change."
 Joseph Louis Bruno was born on April 8, 1929, in Glens Falls, on the southern border of the Adirondacks. His father, an immigrant from Italy who never learned to read English, worked as a laborer his entire life, most of it shoveling coal at a paper mill. His mother, who bore eight children, died when Mr. Bruno was 17.
 "We were about as poor as anybody can be," Mr. Bruno said, remembering that he spent his childhood in a six-room cold-water flat where it was common to wake up and find ice stuck to the inside of the windows.
 He graduated from St. Mary's Academy in Glens Falls and Skidmore College in Saratoga Springs with a bachelor's degree in business administration.
 In 1959, Mr. Bruno and a partner founded the Coradian Corporation, a company that sold commercial telephone systems in the Northeast and Midwest. The company flourished, at least in part because of business from state and local governments where Mr. Bruno had political influence. Those ties, and the possible conflicts of interest they posed, were investigated by the Governor's Commission on Government Integrity in the late 1980's, although the commission ultimately found more fault with the state's conflict-of-interest laws than with Mr. Bruno.
 When Mr. Bruno sold the company to Mitel Systems Integrators Inc. in 1990, it had 700 employees. The sale made Mr. Bruno a wealthy man, although he said today that "I don't live a wealthy life style."
 The Senator lives on a 50-acre farm in Brunswick, where he raises thoroughbred horses, which he rides in local parades.
 After serving as a campaign aide to former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, as an assistant to Perry Duryea, who was Assembly Speaker at the time, and as chairman of the Rensselaer County Republican Committee, Mr. Bruno first won election to the Senate in 1976. During his tenure, he has served as chairman of four committees, those on consumer protection; insurance; elections, and commerce, economic development and small business.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Governor-elect George E. Pataki, left, two months ago with Ralph J. Marino, deposed as Senate majority leader yesterday by Joseph L. Bruno. Mr. Bruno is known as a sharp-tongued spokesman for his beliefs. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Treasury Bonds Are Mixed In a Short and Thin Session

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed in thin post-holiday trading yesterday as some market participants decided that the recent selloff in stocks had subsided.
 The Treasury market had benefited from a flight of investors out of stocks and into bonds after the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 91.52 points on Tuesday. But stocks recovered some ground yesterday, with the Dow gaining 33.64 points. 
 James Hale, fixed-income analyst for MMS International, said he was surprised by the bond market's resiliency given the strength of stocks yesterday. "Under normal conditions, long bonds should have fallen at least a half-point," he said.
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond was up only 1/32 , to 95, leaving the yield unchanged at 7.94 percent from Wednesday.
 The financial markets were closed on Thursday in observance of Thanksgiving and the markets closed early yesterday after a recommendation by the Public Securities Association, a securities industry group.
 In overseas trading before the New York opening yesterday, Treasury securities gave back some of their gains from earlier this week and that set the tone for trading in the United States yesterday.
 Lawrence R. Rice, chief investment officer for Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, described yesterday's market as thin with little trading. "Technically, we've been due for a rebound in bonds," he said. "Whether this will continue depends on whether the economy is beginning to show signs of slowing down."
 Bonds surged on Tuesday and Wednesday, turning in their best performance in more than three months as investors sold stocks in favor of bonds because of attractive returns offered in fixed-income investment.
 But as stocks recovered somewhat yesterday it encouraged some unwinding of positions in the debt market.
 Bonds, however, could make further gains in the coming weeks if the prospect of an economic slowdown entices more investors to turn away from stocks.
 The economy is currently growing faster than the 2.5 percent pace Federal Reserve officials say can be sustained without the threat of inflation's picking up. According to the Government's first estimate, the economy expanded at 3.4 percent in the third quarter. On Wednesday, the Government is scheduled to make its first revised estimate of the gross domestic product for the third quarter.
 The revised G.D.P. number will be closely watched for evidence that the Fed's six increases in short-term interest rates this year are starting to slow the economy down.
 Other economic data scheduled next week include a report on October home sales by the National Association of Realtors on Monday. Economists surveyed by Bloomberg Business News expect that home resales fell three-tenths of a percent.
 The Conference Board on Tuesday will release its November index of consumer confidence. The economists surveyed believe the index will post a slight gain to 87.8 from 87.7 in October.
 Mr. Hale of MMS International said the two reports likely to move the market would be the national purchasing managers report on Thursday and Friday's employment figures
 "We're looking for some fairly healthy numbers from both," he said, "and that should squash the speculation of a slowing economy," adding, "Yesterday's diehards, which gave bonds some strength, could end up proving to be martyrs next week."

HEADLINE: Stores Say No to Sales Taxes, for a Day

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
For John and Tammy Guerriero, it was one of those pleasant little surprises at the mall. While jostling through the throngs of holiday shoppers yesterday -- the year's busiest shopping day -- they found a pair of shoes for their 4-month-old son, Michael, for exactly 8.25 percent less than they expected to pay.
 "Geez, we might come back for another pair," said Mr. Guerriero, a carpenter and Staten Island native, as the couple emerged from the Buster Brown shoe store in the sprawling, 200-store Staten Island Mall, Michael babbling happily in tow. 
 "If this kind of thing catches on, I won't have any reason to shop in New Jersey," he said.
 That, according to the organizers of yesterday's No Sales Tax Day on Staten Island, was exactly the point. They contend that the 8.25 percent sales tax shoppers must pay in New York City -- of which 4 percent goes to the state and the rest to the city -- is driving customers to New Jersey, where the rate is lower. In an effort to attract more shoppers and to protest the tax rate, the organizers said they persuaded 88 merchants, including 7 in the Staten Island Mall, to pay the sales tax themselves for a day, and pass the savings on to their customers.
 "We can't expect merchants to take this hit for an extended period," said Bob Cutrona, president of the Voice of Staten Island Business, a year-old merchants' group that organized the promotion. He said the day of tax breaks was not likely to be repeated soon.
 "But I'm confident we've made our point loud and clear," he added. By last evening, several of the participating merchants had reported higher than expected sales, in part, they said, because of the tax discounts.
 Perhaps a better measure of the event's impact was the publicity it attracted. At the Staten Island Mall, television crews and newspaper reporters darted between the seven "No Tax Day" stores, seeking expressions of tax outrage from shoppers and merchants alike.
 "Wouldn't it make sense for the state simply to eliminate sales taxes on the day after Thanksgiving?" wondered Amy Goldman, the manager of the Buster Brown Store, where the Guerrieros found their bargain baby shoes. "We are simply losing too many sales to New Jersey."
 Staten Island merchants are not the only ones with complaints over the wide disparity in sales taxes between New York and New Jersey. But it is here, on an island that has far more convenient bridges to New Jersey than to its home state, where merchants say the sales tax has taken its biggest toll in lost business.
 The disparity is greatest in purchases of clothing, on which New Jersey levies no sales tax. And on most other consumer goods, New York City's combined 8.25 percent tax rate compares with 7 percent in New Jersey.
 According to the Staten Island Chamber of Commerce, which worked with Mr. Cutrona's group to organize yesterday's promotion, Staten Island merchants should generate $3.7 billion a year in sales, but 30 percent of that amount, or $1.11 billion, is lost to New Jersey, largely because of the sales tax difference.
 Staten Island merchants can have little hope that yesterday's sales event, in itself, will lead to changes in New York tax policy. But there is some cause for encouragement -- Governor-elect George E. Pataki has said repeatedly that he hopes to reduce taxes, although he has not singled out sales taxes.
 Sheldon Silver, a Democrat and Speaker of the New York State Assembly, did refer directly to sales taxes two weeks ago, saying that they should be cut.
 Those involved in yesterday's Staten Island protest offered several proposals for tax reform. Mr. Cutrona said he hoped the state would eliminate its share of sales taxes in Staten Island and throughout New York City, since merchants in the city are hurt the most by competition with New Jersey.
Paul Ferrara, the chairman of the Staten Island Chamber of Commerce, offered another prescription: an state-designated Economic Development Zone, including all or most of Staten Island, in which sales taxes would be cut or eliminated. Several such zones already exist in New Jersey.
 Tom Keough, manager of the Easy Spirit shoe store, which opened in the Staten Island Mall in September, said the effect of the New York State sales tax had quickly become apparent because there is another branch of Easy Spirit in the Woodbridge Mall, 20 miles west in New Jersey.
 "Since we opened, their sales have not fallen off at all, and they should have because we know a lot of the people shopping at Woodbridge are coming from Staten Island," he said.
 Mr. Keough, one of the Mall's seven merchants participating in yesterday's event, said he thought there was little chance that the tide would turn soon in the long running interstate battle for retail sales.
 Nonetheless, he said the day had been a success.
 "We think this is a way for merchants to show their support for Staten Island, and that they are a strong part of the community," he said.

HEADLINE: Westin Hotel Co. to Be Sold To Starwood and Goldman

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
The Starwood Capital Group, a privately owned real estate investment firm, and Goldman, Sachs & Company announced yesterday that they had agreed to acquire the Westin Hotel Company from the debt-burdened Aoki Corporation of Japan in a deal valued at $561 million.
 The purchase price will include cash, seller financing and the assumption of mortgage debt. The percentages were not disclosed. 
 Westin, which has revenues of more than $2 billion, manages, franchises and represents 80 hotels and resorts in 19 countries. They include the Arizona Biltmore in Phoenix the Westin St. Francis in San Francisco, and a Westin hotel that recently opened in Providence, R.I.
 The Westin Hotel Company will be acquired by a joint venture formed by Starwood Capital and Goldman, Sachs, together with Goldman's partner, the Edward Thomas Companies, a hotel company based in Beverly Hills, Calif. Nomura Asset Capital Corporation will provide financing for the acquisition, which is expected to be completed in the first quarter of 1995.
 The deal will give the joint venture total ownership of nine hotels, 50 percent of the Arizona Biltmore and various interests in three other hotels. Among those involved are the Westin Hotels at the San Francisco Airport and Chicago's O'Hare Airport. Aoki will retain ownership of five Westin hotels in Canada and various interests in four Westin hotels in the United States; it will also retain the Westin trademark in Asia. The new owners will manage the nine hotels and hold a long-term license on the trademark in Asia.
 Barry Sternlicht, president and chief executive of Starwood, which has headquarters in Greenwich, Conn., said the new owners would focus not only on improving the hotel company's profitability but also on seeking rapid growth by adding franchises and buying hotels.
 "The expansion of the international trade and travel markets," he said, "coupled with the capital and resources of both Starwood and Goldman, Sachs, positions us to rapidly expand Westin as one of the premier hotel companies in the world."
 The sale occurs when the United States hotel industry is rebounding strongly from almost six years of depressed room rates, occupancy and revenues. Arthur Andersen & Company recently estimated that total revenues would increase 5 percent this year, to $64.8 billion, and an additional 4.8 percent in 1995, to $67.9 billion.
 Much of the improved performance results from increased business travel, and, Mr. Sternlicht said, "Most of our hotels are business oriented."
 Starwood, which was founded by Mr. Sternlicht in 1991, included in its original limited partners the Ziff publishing family and the family of Carter Burden, a former New York City Council member. In November, the Pritzker family of Chicago, which owns the Hyatt hotels, also became a limited partner.
 Starwood and its affiliates have acquired interests in more than 100 properties, costing more than $700 million. Among them are more than 30 hotels. It recently completed refinancing the Boca Raton Hotel and Club in Boca Raton, Fla., in which it has an interest. It is the second-biggest holder in the big multifamily real estate investment trust Equity Residential Properties Trust.
 Westin was founded in Seattle in 1930 and privately owned until 1970, when it was bought by a subsidiary of United Airlines. In 1988, the Aoki Corporation, a construction company with diversified businesses, purchased it for $1.53 billion.
 But Japan's economy has since gone into a tailspin, and Aoki's debt burden has mounted, prompting the company to look for a buyer for Westin. In February, Bernardo Dominquez Cereceres, whose Mexican construction company also owns a small hotel chain, accounced that he would buy 74 Westin hotels for $708 million -- hundreds of millions of dollars higher than other bids, and, in the opinion of analysts, too high for profitability.
 Then, last month, Mr. Dominguez said he and his investor group were withdrawing from the deal because of rising interest rates, volatility of high-yield bond markets and Westin's inability to achieve the rates of return they initially projected.
 Starwood Capital, which had been working with Mr. Dominquez, signed the deal itself and invited Goldman, Sachs in as a partner.

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Those Cyclical Stocks Are a Disparate Bunch

BYLINE: By Anthony Ramirez 

 BODY:
CYCLICAL stocks may wind up on top in the weeks ahead, some stock pickers say, especially now that the Federal Reserve has raised interest rates once again.
 There is just one problem: What are cyclical stocks? 
 What, for example, is the common thread between Caterpillar Inc., the Illinois-based maker of heavy equipment; Placer Dome, a Canadian gold miner; Knight-Ridder, a newspaper chain based in Florida?
 They are all regarded by stock-market professionals, in a fuzziness of terminology, as stocks that tend to move up or down in synchronization with the economy.
 But "in sync" rarely means the precision of the Navy's Blue Angels, but more often the scattering of a flock of geese. Yet even cyclical stocks, like geese, eventually go in one direction, as the Morgan Stanley Cyclical Index shows. And so far this month, the index has fallen 10.4 percent.
 Plotted against the gross domestic product since June 1991, when the economy started to expand in earnest, the stock price of Morgan Stanley's cyclical stocks have tracked the economy fairly well.
 The index consists of 30 stocks in 25 separate industries: groups traditionally thought of as cyclical, like aluminum, steel and chemicals, as well as groups that are not, like discount retailers, newspaper chains and computer-chip makers.
 No one cyclical stock mirrors the economy, said Thomas M. McManus, the Morgan Stanley investment strategist who devised the index. But the nontraditional stocks help, too, he said. In Knight-Ridder's case, help-wanted advertisements, especially in Miami, Detroit, and San Jose, Calif., reflect regional growth.
 Katherine R. Hensel, chief investment strategist for Lehman Brothers, said interest rates were the key to thinking about the economic cycle. In the early part of an economic expansion, autos, appliances and other big-ticket consumer durables thrive because the Fed is keeping interest rates low.
 But as the economy expands, the Fed raises rates, hoping to restrain consumer demand and therefore inflation. The most rate-sensitive industries, those with products likely to be bought by consumers on credit, peak in stock price first and then fall.
 Then, companies farther down the economic chain may be next in line to be hurt by higher rates. Capital-goods stocks, like Caterpillar, a heavy-equipment maker, thrive during the middle part of an expansion and, nearing the end of the cycle, basic materials like aluminum, paper and chemicals are the penultimate stars. Finally, at the very end of the cycle, when interest rates are high, oil and energy stocks, those with fewer products for the consumer, are the last to peak.
 Yet consumer durables, capital goods and basic materials tend to be called cyclical stocks as if they were identical. Prices for auto stocks and other durables, however, peaked in the last quarter of 1993, capital goods in the first quarter this year and basic materials performed well and may have peaked in the third quarter.
 Is the economy at the bottom of the hill or, as seems likely, at the top? And if it is at the top, is it about to go down? Or is the economy about to plateau and then climb again? Economists disagree.
 Still, many analysts think the economy is near the top and hence the stocks to avoid are aluminum, paper, chemicals and other basic-industries stocks that have peaked. Others disagree.
 Sung Won Sohn, senior vice president and chief economist for the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis, does not recommend oil. He prefers basic-materials stocks like the Aluminum Company of America, Reynolds Metals, Bethlehem Steel, ARCO Chemical and Monsanto.
 "We can still get more juice out of this orange," he said.
 For the most part, however, market strategists recommend oil and natural gas. Lehman Brothers, for example, likes Chevron, Mobil, Murphy Oil and Total Petroleum. Morgan Stanley likes Anadarko Petroleum, a Houston natural-gas company.
 But beyond recommending oil and gas, the consensus breaks down. Like Mr. Sohn of Norwest, even the stock pickers of Lehman Brothers think there is juice to come from some of the early-stage cyclicals like Ford, Maytag, Whirlpool, Deere, Johnson Controls and a homebuilder like Lennar.
 With steeply rising interest rates, Mr. McManus of Morgan Stanley recommends buying "stocks that act like bonds," utility shares like Unicom, Public Service of Colorado and Illinova, formerly Illinois Power.
 Douglas A. Kass, director of institutional equities with J W Charles in Boca Raton, Fla., recommends gold and silver stocks, the ultimate cyclical investments. Inflation will surge, he said, and investors will flock to gold miners like Newmont Mining, Placer Dome, and Battle Mountain, as well as silver miners like Hecla Mining. "They're for aggressive investors," Mr. Kass said. "But it may become necessary."

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES;
Tax Date Looms for Bullish

BYLINE: By Ellen C. Lesser 

 BODY:
To the short list of important dates in your relationship with the Internal Revenue Service -- Dec. 31 and April 15 -- this year add Nov. 29. The date is important for bullish investors who plan to "accelerate capital losses," or close out losing investment positions before the year ends.
 While all investors can gain tax advantages by selling losers before year-end, those who are bullish may want to act by Tuesday, the deadline this year for "doubling up." The strategy is to buy additional shares of losing securities now and sell the original shares for a loss on Dec. 30. In this way, investors can lower their 1994 tax bills while leaving themselves poised to catch any market run-up in January. 
 Such transactions must be initiated by Tuesday because the I.R.S. does not give investors the tax advantages of a capital loss if there's a "wash sale," an offsetting trade of a substantially identical stock or security within 30 days.
 "We are getting more questions this year than last year, mostly in relation to bonds, because interest rates have gone up and the bonds that clients held have gone down in value," said Anthony Ventura, a vice president of tax planning at Smith Barney.
 With bond swaps, "the I.R.S. has never defined how much different the yield and maturity must be," Mr. Ventura said. "You can go from New York City to New York State bonds and you won't have a problem, but if you go from one New York State bond to another New York State bond, the question is, 'How much should you change the yield and maturity?' "
 Unlike other capital losses, those created in a wash sale cannot be used to offset capital gains this year. The loss does not evaporate but gets added to the cost basis of the newly purchased shares.
 For example, if 100 shares bought for $1,000 are sold for $750, a capital loss of $250 occurs. Generally, the tax code allows this loss to offset $250 in capital gains, offset other income up to $3,000 or be carried into the next tax year. But, if within 30 days before or after the sale, the investor buys 100 shares of the same stock for $800, the loss will not be allowed in 1994. Instead, the basis for the new shares will be set at $1,050 (the purchase price plus the disallowed loss). Any tax benefit from the $250 loss will be realized only after the shares are sold for good.
 Instead of doubling up, Richard E. Cripps, the director of equity marketing for Legg Mason in Baltimore, recommends selling losing shares now and taking advantage of the unduly depressed prices that often hit smaller stocks and over-the-counter issues in the closing days of the year when others sell to meet their own tax goals.
 "The buyers of these stocks historically have good gains six weeks later," he said. "If you sell now, you can theoretically be a buyer in the last week of the year, which is generally a very attractive time to buy."
 The risk of selling now is that the stock could rise before year-end and you would have no benefit other than the tax loss.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Players Told to Expect a Unilateral Move

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Major league club owners are prepared to take one of three steps when they meet in Chicago on Dec. 5, players were told in a memo they received from the union this week, but management's most likely action will be a vote on implementation of a salary cap.
In the memo dated Nov. 22 -- a copy of which was obtained by The New York Times -- Donald Fehr, the head of the union, told the players that John Harrington, the owners' labor spokesman, stated the clubs' intentions at the last bargaining session last Saturday. 
 In his two-page memo, Fehr wrote that Harrington "told us that unless there was a settlement or a counterproposal from the players that the owners committee would recommend that the owners accept, a vote would probably be taken at the owners' meeting on 5 December to implement the salary cap."
Given that neither of the first two possibilities will become reality, the owners will be left with the decision to install a new economic system.
To implement the cap unilaterally, the owners would have to declare an impasse in negotiations. They are apparently prepared to take that step in spite of the presence of Bill Usery Jr., a mediator asked by the White House to work with the two sides, and the possibility that the union will formulate a counterproposal at its executive board meeting in Atlanta that same week.
Declaring an impasse on the eve of receiving a new proposal would seem to be a contradictory act, but a labor lawyer said the owners can do whatever they want unless their action is blocked by a court injunction. The union would ask the National Labor Relations Board to seek an injunction, but it is not easily achieved.
The two sides are scheduled to return to the Washington area on Monday, meeting separately with Usery that day, then resuming negotiations Tuesday. The bargaining, however, could be brief because the players are expected to reject the tax proposal and the revised salary cap proposal the owners made last week and they will not have the counterproposal the owners hope to see.
"It is apparent," Fehr wrote in his memo, "that the revised salary cap proposal we received is the proposal that we expected the owners to make before they unilaterally implemented the salary cap. The revised salary cap still includes virtually all of the objectionable features of the initial proposal."
The owners' proposals, Fehr also noted, include elements from a series of proposals the owners made last May 23 that represented givebacks. "Presumably," he said, "the owners intend to implement these proposals along with the salary cap."
Among those proposals, players called to the major leagues in September after rosters are expanded would not receive major league service credit and players could be released for any reason, or no reason.
Under the existing uniform players contract, a club can release a player if he fails "to exhibit sufficient skill or competitive ability to qualify or continue" as a member of the team.
Under the proposed contract, a club can release a player if he fails "in the opinion of the Club's management, for any reason or any combination of reasons, including economic considerations, to warrant a position" on the team. In other words, if a club decides on the last day of spring training that a player is making too much money, it can release him and owe him only minimal termination pay.
In another proposal, the clubs will establish a salary scale for players in their first four years in the majors, but a player in his fourth year could wind up earning the first-year salary of $115,000 instead of the fourth-year salary of $500,000. That would happen if, after his third season in the majors, a player were not tendered a contract by his team and he became a free agent. When he signed with a new club, he would receive $115,000.
The players don't like those parts of the proposals any more than they like the cap or the tax, which they feel acts as a cap.
The owners' negotiators, Fehr told the players, "made it clear that, ideally, no club would exceed the threshold," the limit over which clubs would have to pay tax on their entire payrolls. If clubs kept their payrolls at or below the threshold, that number, in practice, would become a cap.
The owners, though, never intended to make the tax proposal more attractive to the players than the cap. The cap is the system they want.
Despite the strike and the reduced revenues and payrolls, the clubs have informed the players that for purposes of determining cap-related figures, they will use 1994 projections. That means $1,743,296,000 in revenue would be divided 50-50 for the 1995 season, leaving the players with $871,648,000 for salaries and other costs.

HEADLINE: Reject the New Arms Guidelines

 BODY:
America has a rare chance to use its dominant position in the arms market to inhibit the international traffic in weaponry. Unfortunately, new guidelines governing American arms sales abroad, now on President Clinton's desk, would toss away that chance.
With the end of the cold war, global arms sales began to dry up and competition intensified to capture what was left of the market. The demonstrated prowess of American arms in the Persian Gulf war allowed the U.S. to dominate the market, accounting for well over half the world's sales. That would enable Washington to take the lead in restraining sales, especially to volatile regions like the Middle East. 
 The defense industry has resisted restraints. With the slowing of Pentagon procurement, the industry looked overseas to peddle its wares. Now the Pentagon wants to turn export promotion into a strategy for keeping the industry afloat, and Mr. Clinton is being asked to sign on.
The guidelines are pernicious in several ways. To win government approval for an arms deal under existing rules, arms makers have had to show that the sales would promote U.S. security, cooperation with a foreign government and regional stability. One unwritten purpose of the sales has always been to help domestic industries keep their production lines open. In the new guidelines, that purpose is explicitly stated, giving commercial considerations much higher priority than before.
The guidelines would also provide up to $1 billion in loan guarantees for arms exports, adding to the billions in subsidies the defense industry already receives to market its wares. That will only invite U.S. competitors to sweeten their own subsidies. As an added inducement to buy American, U.S. companies sometimes offer to co-produce arms abroad, leading to a loss of control over military technology. The guidelines do little to slow the diffusion of American know-how.
The guidelines would sacrifice long-term security for short-term economic advantage. Mr. Clinton should reject them.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Energy Efficiency Works, and It Saves Money

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"It Costs More to Save Energy" (Op-Ed, Nov. 20) by Herbert Inhaber and Harry Saunders strays far from the real-world experience we have analyzed in dozens of studies published in widely read, reputable journals and highlighted in the book "Energy Efficiency and Human Activity" (Cambridge, England). 
 Before 1973, energy use in the United States and Europe for homes was increasing more rapidly than the number of homes or appliances. Through the early 1990's, this growth was minimal or negative.
The average American home used 19 percent less energy in 1991 than in 1973, despite an increase in appliances used and area heated. Danish households used 30 percent less energy, despite a 25 percent increase in the number of houses.
It takes 55 percent less fuel to transport an air passenger one mile now than in 1973. Energy consumption in American and European manufacturing in the 90's was close to its 1973 level despite a wide increase in output because energy-efficiency industries increased 35 percent to 40 percent.
Thus efficiency works and has restrained energy use in Western economies by an average of 20 percent relative to production, travel, freight and the level of activities in homes and buildings.
Analyses show the main reason people saved energy was to save money. More important, longer term technological progress reduced the energy and material requirements of basic processes even in times of falling energy prices. Since the days of booming production of energy-gulping raw materials have passed, growth in energy use is restrained even more.
Now there are more of us with higher incomes, using more gadgets and traveling more, following long-established trends. There is little evidence that increased energy efficiency, which lowers energy costs, boosted energy-using activities significantly in recent years, as the article's authors maintain.
This is not surprising, since energy costs -- typically 5 percent to 15 percent of the total costs of owning things, moving about or production -- are seldom a deterrent to activities. Saving energy means saving money, very little of which is recycled into energy consumption.
Mr. Inhaber and Mr. Saunders worry about the trivial energy use of all those hot tubs. Perhaps they've been soaking for too long to understand the real dynamics of energy in our economy.
 
LEE SCHIPPER
Berkeley, Calif., Nov. 22, 1994
 
The writer is co-leader of international energy studies at Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory.

HEADLINE: New York's Business Districts Make the City Cleaner and Safer

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Nov. 20 article on New York City business improvement districts seemed to imply that the districts are devoid of accountability. Our accounting firm provides services to many of these districts, including auditing and consulting services, and I must say the opposite is true. 
 The New York City Department of Business Services, in addition to approving a district plan, reviews each district's annual audited financial statements and oversees delinquent assessments. A department member sits on each board and is consulted on major district activities.
Many of the larger business districts you mention have 20 to 50 board members. They also have numerous committees reviewing everything from personnel policies to annual budgets. In many cases the directors are overinvolved, rather than underinvolved.
Every business district has financial statements audited by independent accountants. The auditor certifies that the reports are in compliance with generally accepted accounting principles and confirms that the business district is complying with the district plan and all major contractual agreements.
Business improvement districts have cleaned up our streets, provided more security and made many areas more attractive to business. They have worked with the police, sanitation department and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to improve services. There is a good reason Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is so vocal in promoting their growth.
Let's not raise unnecessary fears because there are isolated cases of abuse.
 
LAURENCE SCOT
Senior Partner, Skody Scot & Company
New York, Nov. 21, 1994

HEADLINE: Energy Efficiency Works, and It Saves Money;
Costs of Inefficiency

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The indictment of policies to save energy by Herbert Inhaber and Harry Saunders (Op-Ed, Nov. 20) is at once defeatist and deficient. 
 In focusing on energy consumption in the United States, the authors overlook the health, economic and environmental consequences of energy inefficiency worldwide. As economies grow, they consume more energy. Inefficient consumption of fossil fuels generates greenhouse gases and other contaminants that impair the function of human and natural systems.
We invite the authors to visit rapidly developing regions of the world like Liaoning Province in China, where energy-profligate industrial policies are choking urban residents in coal soot, sulfur dioxide and other pollutants.
In a country like China, inefficient exploitation of fossil fuels has profound adverse health, economic and ecological impacts, including higher incidence of respiratory illnesses (resulting in lost workdays), acidified lakes (with economic losses to fishing) and toxification of agricultural soils (affecting the quantity and quality of grain harvest).
The closing remarks of the authors about the value of energy conservation seem more myopic. They argue that energy efficiency policies are useful, not because they save energy, but because they "stimulate increased economic activity."
Generally, increased economic activity warrants increased energy consumption. We contend that accelerated economic development is beneficial only if it is accompanied by technologies and practices that assure sustainable energy use.
The interdependencies between energy and environment, health and economic welfare leave society no choice but to promote energy efficiency.
 
MATTHEW AUER
XIAOLAN YE
New Haven, Nov. 21, 1994
 
The writers, graduate students at Yale and Nanjing universities, respectively, are collaborating on an energy audit of their schools.

HEADLINE: New York's Business Districts Make the City Cleaner and Safer;
Different Partnerships

 BODY:
To the Editor:
New York is a big city, big enough for more than one group called "Partnership." However, after receiving many phone calls following your Nov. 20 article on business improvement districts, we feel the need to distinguish the Partnership for the Homeless from the Grand Central Partnership, a business district whose work with homeless people is controversial. 
 The Partnership for the Homeless is a nonprofit service organization that operates more than 150 shelters in New York City. It has furnished more than 4,500 apartments for formerly homeless people and provides case management for homeless people with AIDS and H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. It finds permanent housing for homeless families and operates a drop-in center for frail and elderly homeless people.
Our organization also gets more than 650 homeless and formerly homeless New Yorkers into the job market each year.
 
JOEL SESSER
President
The Partnership for the Homeless
New York, Nov. 21, 1994

HEADLINE: For Holiday Shoppers, No Hurry

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
Beth Findlay and her mother, Joan Gorelick, spent yesterday morning browsing at the Stamford Town Center in Stamford, Conn.
 In Macy's, they picked up a couple of pairs of earrings that were already gift-wrapped and bought a sports shirt that was on sale for Mrs. Gorelick's husband, Dan. But mostly they just prowled the mall, trying to get into the holiday spirit. 
 "I'm still trying to figure out what to get people," Mrs. Findlay said. "I'm really just shopping for ideas."
 On what has traditionally been the busiest shopping day of the year, many shoppers seemed to be taking that tack, seeking inspiration. Others were simply whiling away a holiday weekend morning or afternoon. Even the early arrival this year of Hanukkah, which starts tomorrow night, seemed to bring no added urgency.
 But all were keeping an eye out for bargains and vowing to postpone at least some purchases until closer to the Christmas holiday, hoping that skittish retailers would slash prices.
 Despite abundant promotions intended to get people to shop early, "the notion that the day after Thanksgiving is the biggest sales day of the year has become myth," said Isaac Lagnado, principal of Tactical Retail Solutions Inc., a retail consulting firm.
 Mr. Lagnado said he expected Christmas Eve, which falls on a Saturday this year, to be the most lucrative for retailers, followed by Dec. 23 and Dec. 17.
 To visit stores yesterday was to see consumers practicing their skills at this game of chicken.
 "I'm not so particular about what I'm buying, so I always shop around until the week before Christmas because the prices just get better and better," said Susan McKinney, a secretary who works in Stamford.
Craig Donaldson, a business manager in Boston, brought his children to Manhattan on Thursday to see the Macy's Thanksgiving Day parade and the F.A.O. Schwarz store. But he was not planning to shop at either store. "We don't shop on Fifth Avenue," he said. "We shop at outlet malls in Kittery, Me."
 Most stores yesterday were offering discounts on selected merchandise, while some, like J. C. Penney, Sears and Wal-Mart, enticed shoppers with early-bird specials that began as early as 6 A.M.
 The discounts are likely to continue, because many retailers have slightly heavier inventories of apparel than they had anticipated for this time of year. Unusually warm fall weather had inhibited sales of sweaters, coats and other cold-weather gear, which must be cleared out by the end of January.
 The busiest stores yesterday were those selling items for the home. At the Williams-Sonoma store in Stamford Town Center, customers laden with goods waited in line 10 deep at each cash register, and Brookstone, which sells everything from basic tools and lawn and garden equipment to fancy gadgets, was full of people trying out leather recliners with built-in massaging mechanisms.
 Stores selling apparel were much less busy. Clerks behind the cosmetics counters at Saks Fifth Avenue were working hardest at applying makeup to their own faces, and in the Limited store, workers kept busy folding sweaters and straightening displays.
 Stores that sold gift items fared better. Banana Republic, which does most of its business in clothing, lured customers with prominent displays of satin scarves, velvet gloves and holiday party wear just inside the doorway.
 And Victoria's Secret was clearly the store of choice for men shopping for their wives. It even had two male employees on hand to answer questions from men who might be embarrassed about asking a female sales clerk about lacy lingerie.
 Retailers are not anticipating the sales bonanzas they reaped during the last two holiday seasons, when sales soared far beyond their expectations. Last year, holiday sales jumped 7.5 percent to 8.9 percent, depending on the definition of the season, and the increases were even greater the year before. Some analysts and economists measure holiday sales starting at the end of November through December, while others include the entire two months.
 The National Retail Federation is predicting a 6 percent sales increase this year, and most other analysts' estimates fall into that ball park. Tracy Mullin, president of the federation, said she expected retailers to ring up $425 billion in sales during the five-week period before Christmas, compared with about $400 billion last year.
 "Although last year was up about 7.5 percent over the previous year, we'll be very happy with a 6 percent increase," she said.
 Ms. Mullin cited a number of macroeconomic indicators that portend healthy holiday sales, including low unemployment, fairly stable consumer confidence and lower consumer debt.
 The personal financial outlook for many people out milling around in malls yesterday reflected those statistics.
 Last year, Jessie and Kevin Logan of Detroit limited their spending to practical gifts and basic needs because Mr. Logan had lost his job as a photographer for a Detroit advertising agency, forcing the young couple to rely on Mrs. Logan's income of $28,000 a year. "We had to be frugal," Mr. Logan recalled. "I got caught in corporate cost savings."
 This year, though, they were out shopping on Chicago's Michigan Avenue, in search of a Cartier watch for Mr. Logan and a new fur coat for Mrs. Logan. Mr. Logan has begun his own business and has landed several lucrative jobs making portraits of executives for annual reports. He expects his earnings as a freelance photographer to exceed his former salary.
 But even as they were splurging, the Logans were checking prices. Mr. Logan is prepared to spend as much as $4,000 for his wife's fur coat, "but we're looking around to seek what the different stores have to offer and get the best deal," he said.
 Some of the better deals in the country were available at I. Magnin stores, which are going out of business. At the store in Newport Beach, Calif., more than 100 would-be customers were waiting in line to buy designer merchandise at rock-bottom prices. "I got two Donna Karan outfits for dirt cheap," Elnora Dean boasted.
 She said she was spending less on presents this year because she and her husband, Donald, plan to travel to Australia after Christmas to visit one of their children. The outfits she bought were for her grandchildren.
 Jean Reineke of Downey, Calif., who was waiting in line at I. Magnin, said that she planned to spend about the same amount on presents this year as she did last year, but that she might spend more if she found bargains.
 "I feel secure, but you never know from one day to the next," she said, noting that her husband, a computer analyst with the Xerox Corporation, would not be getting a year-end bonus this year.
 "You never know" was a popular phrase among shoppers yesterday. Many had lost a job within the last three years or knew a close friend or relative who had. Glenn Bonner was laid off three years ago from his job as a production worker at a General Dynamics plant near Fort Worth.
 Even though his new job is more secure -- he works for his brother-in-law's company -- he is making less. Yesterday, he was looking for clothes for his two sons and hoping to pay for them with cash. "Nothing is ever a sure thing, so I try not to get too deep in debt in case something happens," he said. "You never know."
 Traffic at the Ridgmar Mall in Fort Worth, where Mr. Bonner was shopping, seemed less congested than last year, and at Stamford Town Center early yesterday, the pace was more like a busy Saturday than the first day of the holiday shopping season -- even though several strollers caused momentary gridlock near the lines of families waiting to visit Santa Claus. But at Roosevelt Field in Garden City, L.I., the vast parking lot was full and some cars were turned away.
 In midtown Manhattan, shopping areas seemed as crowded as ever for the Friday after Thanksgiving, with people waiting in line to get into F.A.O. Schwarz -- and also Nike Town and the Warner Brothers Studio Store.
 Mary-Beth Sherbo, visiting from Agawam, Mass., waited outside Planet Hollywood on 57th Street in Manhattan for an hour and a half at lunchtime. She had almost finished buying toys and games for her children, who are ages 5 and 6.
 For her friends, she said, she planned "more gift certificates," adding, "They are easier, and there are no lines."
 But for some people, the hustle-bustle is an immutable part of the holidays, like Hannukah gelt, gaudy ornaments and candy canes.
 "We come into Macy's every year on the day after Thanksgiving," said Ann Mason, who lives in New Jersey and was cheerfully elbowing her way through the crowd in Macy's flagship store on Herald Square. "It sort of gets you into the spirit, even if you don't buy anything."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 29, 1994, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption on Saturday about a Manhattan protest against the use of fur in fashion referred incorrectly to the protesters' attire in some editions. Their clothes were backless, not topless.
