HEADLINE: G. J. Feldman, 91, Ambassador And Leader in Space Effort, Dies

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
George J. Feldman, a former United States Ambassador to Luxembourg and Malta and a leading figure in the United States space effort, died Tuesday at the Bryn Mawr Terrace Nursing Home in Bryn Mawr, Pa. He was 91.
A native of Boston, Mr. Feldman received his law degree from Boston University and later alternated between private law practice in Boston, Washington and New York and government service. Among his corporate clients, Mr. Feldman represented the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, better known as A.& P. 
 He was also an author of numerous articles and books on business law, including "Business Under the New Price Laws" (Prentice-Hall, 1937), a study of the economic problems arising from the passage of New Deal fair-trade legislation.
During the 1930's, he became an administrative assistant to Senator David L. Walsh, a Massachusetts Democrat, and later served as a lawyer with the Federal Trade Commission and the National Recovery Administration. During World War II, he joined the Air Force, eventually attaining the rank of major.
After the war, he was a consultant to the legal counsel of the Department of State, chief counsel to the House Select Committee on Astronautics and Outer Space and, in 1959, a member of the United States delegation to the 14th United Nations General Assembly.
That same year, the House majority leader, Representative John W. McCormack, Democrat of Massachusetts, appointed Mr. Feldman as chief counsel of the newly formed House Committee on Astronautics and Space Exploration.
In that capacity, Mr. Feldman was a chief author of a study that recommended the establishment of a civilian space agency, later named the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, to take on the assignment of overtaking the Soviet Union in space, rather than giving the job to the military.
In 1962, President John F. Kennedy named Mr. Feldman one of the original directors of the Communications Satellite Corporation, the world's first commercial venture in space, which had been established by Congress to create a system of communications satellites.
In 1960, Mr. Feldman served as vice chairman of the Democratic Party's finance committee and, four years later, he was an adviser to the party's platform committee.
From 1965 to 1967, after being appointed by President Lyndon B. Johnson, he served as the nation's first Ambassador to Malta. Then President Johnson named him Ambassador to Luxembourg.
In 1976, President Gerald R. Ford named Mr. Feldman a member of his Democrats for Ford Committee in his unsuccessful campaign against Jimmy Carter. Mr. Feldman, wearing a "Ford-ocrat' button, said at the time that he was "baffled by Mr. Carter."
Mr. Feldman is survived by a son, George, of Bryn Mawr; a daughter, Margot, of South Kent, Conn.; a brother, Cabot, of Washington;, two sisters, Rose Adler of Washington and Gennette Stargatt of Wilmington, Del., and a grandchild. His wife, Marion, died in 1982.

GRAPHIC: Photo: George J. Feldman (The New York Times, 1965)

HEADLINE: Cost of Health Care in the United States Is Continuing to Grow

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26

 BODY:
The nation's health bill is still growing faster than the rest of the economy despite the third-lowest round of medical inflation in 33 years, Clinton Administration officials say.
The cost of health care for 1993 -- from aspirins to nursing homes to open-heart surgeries -- came to $884 billion, or $3,299 each for the 268 million residents of the United States and its territories. 
 The 7.8 percent increase was the smallest since 1986, when health expenditures rose 7.2 percent. The only smaller increase in recent decades was in 1961, when medical spending rose 7.1 percent.
In most years from the mid-1960's until the start of the 1990's, health expenditures climbed at double-digit rates. The increases slowed to under 9 percent in 1991 and 1992.
But Bruce C. Vladeck, head of the Health Care Financing Administration, said this week that it was too soon to consider high inflation for medical costs a thing of the past.
"It's not a real bad year, but it's right at the historical average," said Mr. Vladeck, who noted that health care claimed 13.9 percent of the gross domestic product, up from 13.6 percent in 1992.
Compared with overall inflation, which was about 3 percent for the 12 months ending in September, he said, "We're not doing that much better than in the past."
The health care total was lower than both the Health Care Financing Administration and the Commerce Department had estimated. It rose from $820 billion in 1992, when Americans spent $205 per capita less on their health.
President Clinton spent much of the past two years campaigning for sweeping changes in the health care system. Last year he and his wife, Hillary, contended that drug companies and insurance companies were profiteers.
While the Clinton proposal to overhaul the health care system failed to be considered by Congress, the health industry has been under heavy pressure to restrain prices. Many Americans now are in some form of managed care, and both the Government and private insurers have reduced what they pay hospitals and high-priced specialists.
Actuaries from the health financing agency, writing in the Health Care Financing Review, said: "It remains unclear whether the moderation in health spending growth is a temporary lull in the health care crisis spurred by the threat of government intervention or the beginning of a long-term restructuring of the private health care system, the full impact of which is only beginning to be seen in 1993."
The actuaries found that from 1990 to 1993:
*Growth in costs slowed in every personal health care category except dental services. The latter grew faster as "concerns over the spread of AIDS increased purchases of supplies" and pushed up prices.
*The increase in hospital expenditures slowed to 6.7 percent from 10.7 percent.
*The increase in doctor bills slowed to 5.8 percent from 10.3 percent.
*Inflation in retail drug purchases slowed to 6.8 percent from 14.5 percent. Americans bought $49 billion worth of prescription drugs and spent $26 billion on over-the-counter drugs and medical sundries in 1993.
*The Federal Government shouldered 32 percent of the nation's health bill, up from 28 percent.
Federal and state spending on Medicaid rose 9.2 percent in 1993, down from 15 percent in 1992 and almost 25 percent in 1991.

HEADLINE: FIGURE SKATING;
All of Those Triple Axels Are Leaving the Skating World Dizzy

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN 

 BODY:
With the attack on Nancy Kerrigan, figure skating has lost its innocence while experiencing unprecedented popularity, opportunity and chaos.
Ice wars have broken out this fall between so-called amateur or Olympic-style skating and professional skating, which features such familiar and accomplished stars as Kerrigan, Kristi Yamaguchi, Brian Boitano, Katarina Witt, Viktor Petrenko, Scott Hamilton and Paul Wylie. Promoters, television networks and big money have joined the fray. Even fans have become embroiled in a sideline skirmish. At stake is nothing less than control and legitimacy of the sport, the importance of the Winter Olympics and the direction of skating toward the future. 
 Gone are the days when elite skaters competed in the Winter Olympics, went on tour, joined the Ice Capades or coached and then faded gracefully into oblivion. Professional competitions have extended careers and hugely expanded earning power. On Nov. 19, Yamaguchi and Hamilton each won $200,000 for winning the prime-time Gold Championship, a competition among former Olympic champions in Edmonton, Alberta.
Earlier, Yamaguchi, Boitano, Kerrigan and Wylie each pocketed $100,000 -- plus appearance fees -- for the Ice Wars team competition, another prime-time event. Oksana Baiul, the reigning Olympic champion from Ukraine, has signed a contract reportedly worth $1.5 million with the promoter Michael Berg. Television ratings have been high, and so has the general level of skating. For the first time, fans are being treated to legitimate axel-to-axel duels between Olympic champions from the past decade.
 
Amateurs Are Still Unknown Quantity
 This explosion of professional skating comes at a time when amateur skating in the United States is stuck in a competitive recession and lacks the maturity or charisma of the former Olympic champions. Projections are that Michelle Kwan of Los Angeles will become a great skater, perhaps even an Olympic gold medalist, but she is only 14 years old. The other amateur skater causing a buzz, Tara Lipinski of Houston, is only 12.
"Like dancers and singers, skaters mature into artists in their late 20's and 30's," said Dick Button, the former Olympic champion who, along with Berg, is the most established promoter of professional competitions.
Brian Boitano, the 1988 Olympic champion said: "People want to see the skaters they know; people don't know the amateurs. I think the amateur world should be a little worried. This could become something like the professional tennis circuit."
A rare confluence of events has conspired to put figure skating -- consistently the most popular sport on TV outside of professional football -- in greater demand than ever.
First, under a one-time adjustment of the Olympic schedule, the Winter Games were held twice in two years -- 1992 and 1994 -- rather than once every four years. Second, Kerrigan was attacked by associates of her chief rival, Tonya Harding, who later pleaded guilty to hindering the police investigation. Third, CBS lost the rights to broadcast National Football League games to the Fox network and found itself with a yawning program vacancy on Sunday afternoons.
This fall, figure skating has popped up on television with the seeming frequency of "Cheers" reruns. Both CBS and NBC have aired prime-time professional competitions. ABC will follow suit with the United States championships for Olympic-eligible skaters in February. Between Thanksgiving and Christmas, CBS will insert skating into its weekend programming as a football replacement.
Christmas season tours -- featuring Kerrigan with the singer Aaron Neville, Baiul skating "The Nutcracker" with Petrenko and Boitano, and Hamilton, Yamaguchi and Witt headlining a 48-city extravaganza called Stars on Ice -- are lined up, like jets on a runway, ready for takeoff.
"This was inexorable, like professional basketball or tennis, where you develop as a professional and the people learn your name and start to follow you," said Wylie, the 1992 Olympic silver medalist. "Eventually, the Olympics may not be the only game in town in terms of bringing people a certain level of notoriety. In tennis, you don't have to wait four years to try to win Wimbledon or a Grand Slam. How unrealistic is that for skating?"
 
A Revolving Door Of Eligibility
 If this dizzying expansion has meant money for skaters and promoters, ratings for the networks and viewing opportunity for fans, it has also resulted in a byzantine, contradictory and confusing jumble of rules and eligibility requirements. Skating guidelines change from one professional competition to the next. The distinction between amateur and professional skating has been impenetrably blurred. Eligibility for the Olympics is restored and rescinded in a revolving-door manner that the professionals consider arbitrary and capricious.
"I would say it's confusing," said Yamaguchi, the 1992 Olympic champion. "People saw Nancy and Oksana in the Olympics and all of a sudden they're competing against me, a professional. I don't know if people really understand. They ask, 'Does this mean anything for the Olympics? Does this qualify for anything?' Maybe over the years, skating will start being a little more structured."
Feeling most threatened by this burgeoning professionalism is the International Skating Union, the worldwide governing body for amateur skating. The union sanctions skaters for the Winter Olympics and the annual world championships. The United States Figure Skating Association is a member of the union, and its president, Claire Ferguson, sits on the union's 12-member executive committee.
Ferguson calls the professional competitions "bogus" because they lack uniform rules, sanctioned judges, drug testing and grievance procedures. Without these controls, she said, figure skating could lose its legitimacy as a sport and devolve into theater, as professional wrestling has done. The association is also upset because promoters are harvesting athletes cultivated by the amateur ranks without giving any money back to the sport.
"We have to be credible with the audience, and I'm afraid this is going to erode that credibility," Ferguson said of professional competitions. "It's like the blond guy holding the championship belt; everyone knows it's not real wrestling."
True, the professional circuit has suffered some dents to its credibility this season. A women's event hastily became a men's competition after Baiul underwent knee surgery in September. No individual scores were posted at the Ice Wars team competition, at least in part, skating insiders said, because Kerrigan wanted to avoid the possibility of losing publicly to Baiul as she had done at the 1994 Olympics. Baiul, meanwhile, has continued to skate the lucrative pro circuit, where she has struggled, while pulling out of an Olympic-style pro-am competition this week in Philadelphia.
Some members of a group called Skating Fans of America, which claims to represent a network of 12,000 fans nationwide, have protested that the Gold Championship on Nov. 19 appeared to be less a competition than a promotional device for the International Management Group, which sponsored the event. Wylie and Kurt Browning, both I.M.G. clients, served as commentators, while first place was awarded to I.M.G.-represented skaters, Yamaguchi and Hamilton, who will tour soon with the I.M.G.-sanctioned Stars on Ice. Hamilton won over the crowd but did not display the technical skill of Boitano or Petrenko.
"We feel used," said Elizabeth Luhn of Kennedyville, Md., president of Skating Fans of America.
Button, who promoted the Gold Championship with I.M.G., defended Hamilton's victory, saying, "There is more to skating than triple jumps." He said that he welcomed discussion about judging. In interviews, neither Boitano nor Petrenko complained about the judges, six of seven of whom were former Olympic medalists. Boitano said he preferred to be judged by one-time skaters "because they know what they are seeing."
Most fans, too, apparently like what they see. The Gold Championship drew a double-digit rating on NBC, as Ice Wars had done on CBS. The level of professional skating remains Olympic-caliber. Boitano, his knees pain-free, is performing at his finest level in two or three years. Yamaguchi is, by all accounts, again the top woman skater in the world. Even the amateurs admit to the professional virtuosity.
"I don't think the level of skating is any lower; artistically, it's even higher," said Todd Eldredge, a former national champion who will seek a second Olympic bid in 1998. "Obviously, though, they don't have the pressure of the Olympics and the world championships."
As professionals, skaters have more control over their careers than do amateurs. They can vary their routines, avoiding the monotony of an entire season preparing for the Olympics or the world championships. They can use music with vocals instead of strictly instrumental pieces, and they can employ more artistry in their performances, rather than remaining beholden to required or expected jumps and spins.
What the professionals want is "open" skating, meaning the right to choose entry in any event from the Olympics to a made-for-TV competition. As it stands, neither talent nor the acceptance of money alone determines Olympic eligibility.
There is no such thing as a true amateur skater anymore. Since 1990, amateur skaters have been able to earn money directly from competitions, tours and exhibitions and retain their Olympic eligibility. What qualifies a skater for the Olympics is simply whether he or she has competed in certain skating union-certified events and avoided certain unsanctioned professional competitions.
 
Pro to Olympics And Back Again
 Such is the tangled nature of the sport that skaters pass in and out of Olympic eligibility the way hemlines pass in and out of fashion. Boitano was the Olympic champion in 1988, a professional for five years, an Olympian in February 1994 and a professional again immediately after. Baiul is competing professionally this season but has until April 1, 1995, to restore her Olympic eligibility for 1998. The rules shift so quickly and inexplicably that Yamaguchi declared for Olympic reinstatement this year, wanting to explore her options as a pairs skater, only to find herself ineligible again a few months later.
"It doesn't make sense, why a person is professional one day, then reinstated as an amateur the next," Wylie said. "What's the difference? It seems arbitrary, bogus."
If change comes in the form of open competition, it is likely to be glacial. Even among its members, the conservative International Skating Union is known as a reactive, rather than pro-active, organization. It is dominated by Europeans, who have not historically found it urgent to respond to the needs of the United States. Half of its executive board, as well as its Italian president, come from the discipline of speed skating, not figure skating.
Unless it changes, the professionals said, the union faces irrelevance, the possible mass defection of Olympic-eligible skaters to the pro ranks and even the remote chance of losing its Olympic sanctioning.
Ferguson disagreed. She said she believed this professional threat was temporary, that it would fade once the current set of champions such as Boitano and Witt retired from competitive skating or once television audiences wearied of see essentially the same performances week after week.
"The money will dry up," Ferguson said. "They're all milking the same cash cow."
Top amateurs such as Eldredge of the United States and Elvis Stojko of Canada, the world champion and Olympic silver medalist, have indicated they will maintain their Olympic eligibility through 1998. Baiul is also expected to be reinstated as an Olympian.
"It's tough to look at all that money being thrown around and not get in on it," Eldredge said. "But they've all medaled at the Olympics and the worlds, and I haven't. I feel I can. For competitive people in this sport, the Olympics and world championships are where it's at. The rewards are the professional competitions that come afterward."
But if Eldredge seems certain about the direction of figure skating, his coach, Richard Callaghan, does not.
"If you find out," he said, "let me know."

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Owners End Up on Opposite Ends of the Ice Over Solution to the Labor Dispute

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Nov. 26

 BODY:
Howard Baldwin and Ed Snider operate National Hockey League teams in the state of Pennsylvania, but they are coming from different directions in terms of the current labor lockout.
The postponement of the season passed through Day 57 today as talks recessed with no solution in sight. They could resume as soon as Monday. In separate telephone interviews recently, Baldwin of the Pittsburgh Penguins and Snider of the Philadelphia Flyers discussed the labor stalemate. 
 Baldwin, who cautioned fellow owners about the consequences of a lockout in September, is among those favoring a quick solution.
"We want to be playing over the holidays," Baldwin said. "I feel very strongly we should play over the holidays, and I'll have a much different attitude if we don't." He needs the cash flow.
"A lot of owners aren't Molson or Viacom, with deep pockets," he said, referring to the brewery that owns the Montreal Canadiens and the entertainment corporation that currently owns the Rangers. "We all have credit lines in place that we have had to use. If any of the 26 teams tell you they are not, they are not telling the truth."
In contrast, Snider is among the hard-liners. He said he hasn't changed his stance as more than a quarter of the 84-game season has been lost. Players will probably need about two weeks of training camp before games begin, so, even if the collective bargaining agreement is reached next week, the earliest start would be mid-December.
"To go through what we've gone through and have nothing you can sink your teeth into, I don't care if we never play," Snider said. "I don't want to come out of a painful lockout and not have anything to show for it."
The concept of a luxury tax on high payrolls has been the most divisive issue. The union calls it a salary cap and resists it. But in order to obtain the owners' desired "drag" on salary inflation, the two sides are discussing several other methods.
One is a reform of arbitration procedures by which a player's wage is determined by a neutral party. Owners argue that, by comparing his salary to others with similar statistics or experience, a player sometimes gets more than he deserves and forces up the wages of others. They want a system of "nonbinding" arbitration, but the two sides haven't yet agreed on what would happen to a player if his team chooses not to abide by the decision of the arbitrator.
"As long as arbitration is in, we'll have a disaster on our hands," Snider said. "Arbitration is a major problem in this league. Something has got to happen with arbitration. Eliminate all arbitration, and I can live with that."
Another major hurdle is entry-level salary. Rookie wages began to inflate greatly after Snider's Flyers signed Eric Lindros for $3.5 million in 1992-93. The owners want to hold down rookie wages by "slotting" draft choices to certain ceilings, exclusive of performance bonuses. A first-round draft choice might be held to $2 million over three seasons, including his signing bonus. He could get extra money, depending on performance statistics.
The owners also want a tightening of free-agency options for younger players in exchange for greater freedom for veterans at age 28. But the owners are demanding the exclusion of a veteran "franchise player" from this freedom, and the union is balking at this restriction. After meetings Friday and this morning, management bargainers seemed subdued.
"There was a sense of anticipation on our side that we'd have two big days here," Harry Sinden, president and general manager of the Boston Bruins, said. "The fact that we didn't get anything done at all leaves you a little frustrated."
The two sides have met 6 times in 10 days. Negotiations became more intense after the "luxury tax" concept was removed, at least temporarily. The union has said that this payroll penalty is a deal breaker. Management still hopes to include it in the final package. One way being considered is to structure it in a way that it would begin at a payroll trigger point that is much higher than the current average level.
That way, the owners would have the tax as insurance against a continuation of the rapid increase in average salaries. It would also serve to save face for Commissioner Gary Bettman, who has pushed the tax concept as the centerpiece of his demands.
Not only do the players oppose the tax, they have also said they don't believe the owners' contentions that they are losing large sums of money.
Baldwin said he got that message when he recently met with some of his players.
"The thing that impressed me most is the distrust," Baldwin said. "If we have a mandate, it is that we must overcome this distrust." He said financial disclosure, at this point, "doesn't matter."
"It's almost too late," he said. "Who's kidding who? We've got to make a deal."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Increased Free Agents Will Come With Cap

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
If major league clubs don't like the selection of pitchers currently available as free agents, they need only be patient. More are on the way.
When the owners, as expected, declare an impasse and implement their salary cap proposal, they will also eliminate salary arbitration, establish a salary scale for players in their first four years in the major leagues and create a new class of free agents -- players who have been in the majors at least four years but fewer than six. 
 Free agency for those players will not come easily. Their clubs will have the right of first refusal, meaning a club can retain a player by matching an offer from another club. With most of the best new free agents, offers from other clubs most likely only will drive up the price for their own clubs because their clubs will do what's necessary to keep them.
That's why they will be called restricted free agents, as opposed to the unrestricted, who are players with six or more years of major league service.
The best players in the four-to-six year category are signed to multiyear contracts: Frank Thomas, Ken Griffey Jr., Juan Gonzalez, John Olerud, Albert Belle, Robin Ventura, Travis Fryman, Gary Sheffield, David Justice and Randy Johnson. They won't be on the market.
But free agents in waiting include the starting pitchers Ben McDonald of Baltimore, Jack McDowell and Alex Fernandez of the Chicago White Sox, Kevin Appier and Tom Gordon of Kansas City, Scott Erickson and Kevin Tapani of Minnesota, Jim Abbott of the Yankees, Kenny Rogers of Texas, Steve Avery and Kent Mercker of Atlanta, Pete Harnisch of Houston, Ramon Martinez of Los Angeles, Ken Hill of Montreal and Andy Benes of San Diego.
Others include the reliever John Wetteland of Montreal; catcher Chris Hoiles of Baltimore; first baseman Hal Morris of Cincinnati; second baseman Delino DeShields of Los Angeles; shortstops Omar Vizquel of Cleveland and Jose Vizcaino of the Mets; third basemen Dave Hollins of Philadelphia, Jeff King of Pittsburgh and Todd Zeile of St. Louis, and outfielders Brian McRae of Kansas City, Sammy Sosa of the Chicago Cubs, Dante Bichette of Colorado, Marquis Grissom of Montreal and Ray Lankford of St. Louis.
Because the system will start late this year, the free agency dates will differ from those in the clubs' proposal. But if the impasse and implementation survive the union's challenge to the National Labor Relations Board, the system in future years will call for all eligible players to become restricted free agents Nov. 1 or three days after the World Series, whichever is later, and have a signing season that ends Feb. 1.
To reserve its right-of-first-refusal right, a club will have to tender a qualifying offer to the free agent for a nonguaranteed salary at least 10 percent higher than the previous season's earnings.
If a player receives an offer sheet -- he can sign only one offer sheet at a time -- it is presented to his former club, which then has 10 days to exercise its right of first refusal.
Under the proposed rules, one club cannot make a deal with another club in exchange for that club's decision to exercise or not exercise its right of first refusal. Nor can a club assign the right of first refusal to another club.
The rules also place restrictions on what a new team can offer a free agent. No property or investment opportunity, for example, can be offered. Nor can a team offer incentives based on a player's performance at a particular position. Attendance bonuses, too, will be prohibited.
But the clubs will not try to bar the new free agents from seeking employment in another league.
"There shall be no restriction or interference with the right of a restricted free agent to negotiate or contract with any baseball club outside the structure of organized baseball," the pending rules state.
 
Change in Free Agent Rules
 When free agency began 18 years ago, clubs drafted rights to players who had filed for free agency. First the draft disappeared, and now the filing period will follow it.
Under the rules the clubs will implement, eligible players no longer will have to file to become free agents. Both the new class of free agents and the old will become free instantly, either on Nov. 1 of each year or three days after the end of the World Series, whichever is later.
On the surface, the clubs seem to be simplifying the procedure, but that's not the reason for the change. The owners have two reasons for making all eligible players free agents automatically:
1. When players are free agents, their salaries are no longer protected by the maximum cut rule (20 percent over one year, 30 percent over two years). Some players have chosen to avoid a greater salary slash by opting to remain with their clubs. Under the new system, they won't have a choice.
2. Players won't be able to pass up the elective type of free agency and wait to become free when their teams don't tender them a contract. Players sometimes have used that strategy to free themselves of the bargaining burden of compensation, which doesn't apply in nontender circumstances.
 
Metrodome Frightens Pitchers
 Not that the Minnesota Twins would scour the free-agent list for the pitching they desperately need; they don't spend the kind of money needed to overhaul the staff whose 5.68 earned run average was the worst in the major leagues last season. But even if they wanted to, the Twins don't think they could lure the best pitchers available.
"It's very difficult to attract a pitcher to the Metrodome," General Manager Terry Ryan said.
 
Trebelhorn Tries Western Look
 After managing the Milwaukee Brewers and the Chicago Cubs, Tom Trebelhorn is about to manage the Tri-City Posse. That's one of eight teams that will form the independent Western League next year. Creating independent minor leagues has become the thing to do in baseball.
"What we're seeing is baseball going back more and more to independent teams," Trebelhorn said. "I see the strike as being a way for organizations to cut back on player development budgets, cutting scouting, instructors, managers and coaches. I think there's a void that independent baseball can fill."
Trebelhorn, who was let go as the Cubs' manager by the new general manager, Ed Lynch, said he was considering several opportunities -- in the minor leagues and in Australian baseball -- when the Tri-City owners called.
"They read an article that said I was entertaining anything and everything," Trebelhorn related. "They explained the league to me and said the job would be far more than field manager. I'll be involved in player procurement and putting the whole thing together. This is something I have never done before. It seemed intriguing."
The league has four teams in California, including Palm Springs and Long Beach, and four in the Pacific Northwest, including one in British Columbia. Stocked with 6 veterans, 6 rookies and 12 limited-service players, each team will play 90 games. Trebelhorn said the league probably would fit into a high Class A and AA levels of minor league baseball.
The league's other managers include Jeff Burroughs, Al Gallagher, Nate Colbert and Bill Sudakis, all former major league players but not, like Trebelhorn, former major league managers.
 
Buying Into Signing Bonuses
 Less than two weeks after their labor lawyers cautioned the clubs about giving players signing bonuses that would "help fund the continuing players strike," the Yankees gave Paul O'Neill a $2.2 million signing bonus, $1.2 million of it payable Dec. 15. Although the Yankees believed they had to do it to keep O'Neill from free agency, they were criticized nonetheless.
Since the strike began, only three other players have signed contracts with signing bonuses included, all since the O'Neill signing: Dan Plesac with Pittsburgh, $200,000; Jose Mesa with Cleveland, $50,000, and Jeff Bagwell with Houston, $3.5 million.
Plesac and Mesa will receive their signing bonuses upon ratification of a new collective bargaining agreement (it could be like Civil War money by then). Bagwell, whose bonus is being deferred with interest to maintain its value, will receive his $3.5 million if he is traded, if any of the three option years in the contract are not exercised or when the contract is terminated.
 
Astronomical Implications
 In signing Bagwell, the Astros provided the latest example of why the owners want the players to protect them from themselves. Claude Brochu, Montreal's managing partner, quickly criticized Drayton McLane Jr., the Houston owner, for the size of the signing, $27.5 million for four years.
"What concerns me is that when that kind of money is offered, it becomes the benchmark for players in that category," Brochu said in remarks to McGill University law students. "That, in my estimation, is a mistake by my friend Drayton McLane. It's his mistake, but now it becomes my problem, and that's not a fair economic system in my opinion."
The Astros, however, did what they felt they had to do to tie up Bagwell, the cornerstone of their franchise. Every team can't be expected to play on the Expos' penurious level. Teams like the Expos, on the other hand, have three alternatives: find wealthier owners, market their team better to attract more fans and revenue or move to a city that can support them.

HEADLINE: Coming Fiercely to the Defense of Social Security

 BODY:
A Post Office poster of the 30's, promoting the new Social Security system.
The Market Watch column on Nov. 6, "Social Security: The Issue They Chose to Ignore," drew a large, angry response from many readers. A sampling follows:
 
To the Editor: 
 It is indeed discouraging to see Floyd Norris blithely accepting political propaganda as a substitute for economic fact. He seems to think that reducing Social Security benefits will reduce the Federal deficit. Yet, the evidence is clear that Social Security is not adding one penny to the deficit and that reducing benefits will not reduce the deficit. As Senator Daniel P. Moynihan points out, Social Security will have a $60 billion surplus this year, a $70 billion surplus next year and a $100 billion surplus by 1999. All this excess revenue is invested in United States Treasury bonds and helps finance the deficit, not increase it. If, as Mr. Norris says, "many doubt Social Security will remain," writers like Mr. Norris share the blame with politicians who oppose Social Security in creating unjustified pessimism.
 
WILLIAM P. LUCE
Englewood, N.J., Nov. 7

HEADLINE: Coming Fiercely to the Defense of Social Security

 BODY:
A Post Office poster of the 30's, promoting the new Social Security system.
The Market Watch column on Nov. 6, "Social Security: The Issue They Chose to Ignore," drew a large, angry response from many readers. A sampling follows:
 
To the Editor: 
 Floyd Norris contributed substantially to my own gloom and despair by suggesting that market forces could solve the health care problem in this country. Health care is a social and political issue: there is no good evidence that market forces do anything but contribute to the problem. We have tried market forces and they failed in this area where few market driven conditions exist.
Mr. Norris depresses me further by stating that Social Security is not a pension plan. Although there is a safety net for the disabled and those at the bottom of the wage scale, a high percentage of people receive from Social Security according to the contributions made, provided they have worked and contributed for a long enough period. This certainly sounds like most of the pension plans I am familiar with.
The real problems with Social Security began in the Johnson administration when it was included in the annual Federal discretionary budget in order to conceal the cost of the Vietnam War. The problem was greatly exacerbated with the pillaging of Social Security funds in the Reagan-Bush years to hide the extent of the budget deficits and to pay for extraordinary military expenses and incredible stupid economic policies based on the belief that not levying taxes to pay for what one spends will somehow magically bring in more tax money.
Social Security is a well-funded program. Social Security money is "passed through" to pay for our national debt. As such it ought to be paid the going rate for long-term treasury bonds. If I calculate the accumulated amount I have contributed between 1950 and 1993 at the average annual long-term bond rate, less the amount I will withdraw with an annual 4 percent COLA, I will be 91 before I have exhausted my own monies. The calculation is similar for my wife (who collects considerably less than I do) based only on her contributions. Given that the life expectancy of American males and females is 72 and 79 years, respectively, there ought to be a lot of money available to pay for most of the unfunded things done with Social Security money.
It seems to me that the real solution is to raise taxes progressively, specifically to pay off the national debt as fast as possible. After that all the entitlement payments will be a piece of cake, as long as we don't continue to lie to our ignorant, greedy and gullible electorate, having them believe that they can have high military expenditures, subsidies of various forms, health insurance, etc., without paying for it.
 
JOHN J. BRUNO
Hilton Head, S.C., Nov. 8

HEADLINE: Coming Fiercely to the Defense of Social Security

 BODY:
A Post Office poster of the 30's, promoting the new Social Security system.
The Market Watch column on Nov. 6, "Social Security: The Issue They Chose to Ignore," drew a large, angry response from many readers. A sampling follows:
 
To the Editor: 
 After reading the "Market Watch" on Social Security, I am more convinced than ever that the media is engaged in a concerted effort to discredit the Social Security System and create a conflict between the young and the elderly. To its discredit, The New York Times has now joined in.
"Entitlements" has become a dirty word only because some in Congress and the media have attempted to corrupt its true meaning -- something to which one who has grounds lays claim. In that context, those who have contributed to the Social Security System, the Federal Employee Retirement System and the Railroad Retirement System have a legitimate right to the pensions they have been promised. Contrary to the views of the author of the column, attacking the above "entitlements" will not reduce the deficit by one penny. To the contrary, were it not for the surplus these systems run up each year, the deficit would be larger.
As an example, the annual Social Security surplus appears as an offset to the deficit in the Federal Budget, thereby masking the true deficit. In addition, those annual surplus by reason of legislation created by Congress, must be invested in special United States Government bonds, the interest on which is paid through the issuance of additional bonds.
This flim-flam created by Congress enables those who desire to confuse the public to claim that Social Security is close to running out of money. The truth of the matter is that the billions of dollars in bonds held by the Social Security Trust Fund constitute a reserve that will be available for many years. One day, these special bonds, which are a part of our total national debt must be paid off as will all other Federal instruments of debt sold to banks and the public.
Your column also attempts to discredit the system by implying that Social Security was never intended to be a pension plan, but a transfer program, by taking money from working people and giving it to the retired and the disabled. History shows that the Federal Insurance Contributions Act (Social Security) was designed as a pension system at a time when few if any employers provided pensions for their employees. Were it not for that system, many who receive Social Security today would be without funds and on welfare, or looking to their families for support.
Contrary to the views of the author of the column, those who contribute to the system have a right to receive payments and should not suffer the indignity of being portrayed as taking money from other working people. As for the doubt that the system will be there for those working today, that is an old saw that has been around since the inception of Social Security which is trotted out whenever the attempt is made to frighten the working class.
To believe that will happen, one has to believe that the United States Government will default on all of its debt obligations. Were that to happen, our entire economic system would collapse and the result would be anarchy. While many of those in Congress are not rocket scientists, it is unlikely they would stand by and let that happen since an event of that sort would cause them to suffer along with the rest of us for a change.
 
W. DAVID WATERS
Cherry Hill, N.J., Nov. 6

HEADLINE: The False Promise of Competition

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Now, It's the Rick Scott Health Plan" (Oct. 30) includes evidence usually overlooked by policy makers and the media -- your writer included -- especially with regard to the myth that competition drives down costs and prices. 
 Ira Magaziner, a senior health adviser to President Clinton, argues that competition among providers will reduce costs. Yet study after study has shown that too much construction of hospitals, the duplication of expensive high-tech equipment and the administrative spending providers incur in fighting with physicians combine to demonstrate that competition drastically increases costs. Having committed itself to a theory before studying the industry, the Clinton Administration remains trapped in a cobweb of confusion.
While contending that he does not seek monopoly status, Mr. Scott of Columbia/H.C.A. provides contrary evidence. His hospital in St. Petersburg, Fla., is "stealing patients" from another hospital, and his 14 hospitals and six surgery centers in and around Tampa, Fla., have left tax-supported Tampa General on the verge of disaster. Obviously, the cost of all this competition in the Tampa Bay area is much greater than health needs require.
Logically, competition-duplication should be reduced, not expanded, and health care ultimately must become something of a public utility. The near-term danger is that as Mr. Scott and his competitors expand, they must underbid each other to win contracts and, perhaps, offer services they cannot deliver as promised, thereby causing government to intervene, as a matter of public interest, to insure the availability of health care and medical training. It will not matter whether the facilities are operated by private or public organizations.
 
FREDERICK C. THAYER
Pittsburgh, Oct. 30
 
The writer is professor emeritus of public and international affairs at the University of Pittsburgh and the author of "Rebuilding America: The Case for Economic Regulation" (Praeger).

HEADLINE: An Embassy Job in Moscow Would Make Any American Testy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 We served at the United States Embassy in Moscow from 1988 to 1992 and believe that your Nov. 18 article about it reflects misunderstanding of embassies. 
 You refer to the Embassy as a single entity, when it is made up of representatives of various United States agencies that have responsibility for distinctive areas of policy.
 For example, American business people should direct complaints about support for their activities to the Commerce Department, which maintains a commercial office in Moscow away from the Embassy compound. Responsibility for reviewing visa applications is shared by the State Department and the Immigration and Naturalization Service, which have staffers working in Moscow. Many other agencies are represented.
 The Embassy does not set policy. Policies are set by the parent agencies in Washington, which send directions to their representatives in Moscow. State Department officers, who make up the political and economic officers at the Embassy among other sections, are primarily there to present United States policy to their Russian counterparts and be the eyes and ears of Washington. Frequently pulled into support for a parade of official visitors, they barely have time for their primary functions, much less to assist United States business people.
 You also leave an impression that all Americans at the Embassy live in a modern, fully equipped compound. Many live and work, as we did, in that small, enclosed space. Many others live in housing scattered through the city or in less than comfortable, or safe, hotel rooms. They rely for basic necessities on the facilities in the compound, which are supported by American taxpayers. The facilities were heavily strained when we were there, and it is not surprising that access has been limited to the expanding number of Embassy employees and families.
 As for complaints of rudeness: Visa application officials review hundreds of these a day. They often work much more than a 9 A.M. to 6 P.M. shift and then go home to a city apartment or hotel room. They are recognized on the street by visa applicants and harassed. They have all the problems of living in an overcrowded city like New York, plus the problems of finding decent food, coping with undrinkable water and doing without some basic services we take for granted. I would challenge any American to face these conditions and not get a bit testy from time to time.
 
SANDRA L. SCHMIDT
RANDY J. SETLOCK
Princeton, N.J., Nov. 21, 1994

HEADLINE: On Sunday;
'Old Sparky': It's Not Just A Punch Line

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

 BODY:
AT a time when David Letterman gets a pretty good laugh with references to the expected return of "Old Sparky," New York State's electric chair, Bob Gangi is not amused. He quoted Churchill: "The mood and temper of the public in regard to the treatment of crime and criminals is one of the most unfailing tests of the civilization of any country."
If so, then the public temper of our civilization is clearly for more of Old Sparky. And Mr. Gangi, as executive director of the Correctional Association of New York, one of the nation's earliest do-good watchdog organizations, can only groan in the minority with his risque insistence that felons are human, whatever problems of disposal they present to law abiders. Mr. Gangi talks of "the ignorance of history and the thirst for retribution" ruining all attempts at political debate about crime and punishment in America. 
 "We have seen the 'get tough on crime' phenomenon before," he said, looking back across 150 years of the association's history, recently to the Roaring 20's, when Speed Graphic portrayals of an uncontrollable crime wave of mad-dog felons fairly begged Old Sparky denouements, if only in the interests of popular entertainment.
"THERE are few areas where the public is more misinformed," Mr. Gangi contended. In the recent elections, he notes, candidates across the spectrum once again judged the nation "soft on crime," even though crime rates were declining and government already was underwriting the greatest nontotalitarian prison construction binge in history.
"Shameless politics," Mr. Gangi said. The way others smile at Old Sparky jokes, he smiles in amazement at how boom follows upon boom in the prison industry, recession-proof in the candidates' hands. In the last two decades, the state prison population in New York quintupled to 66,000 inmates as the Legislature, facing the voters every two years, promised crackdowns, mandated sentences in detail and crimped judges' discretion. Even so, the proportion of prisoners sentenced for violent crimes declined from 60 percent to 35 percent because, Mr. Gangi noted, it's easier for the police to bolster arrest statistics with drug abusers than with violent thugs.
An inmate now costs $59,000 per year, with more to come under a newly elected state government promising longer sentences, slower paroles and a taste of Old Sparky. "I thought the pendulum would begin coming back," Mr. Gangi said, speaking of the association's history of reform following crackdown. "But it's crashed through the side of its casing and is swinging wildly upward."
ON Dec. 5, the correctional association will celebrate its founding in 1844, a time when the highborn of society and the leaders of industry could indulge noblesse oblige ideals and debate prison reform without fear of attack commercials. Looking back, there was surprising public support for the association's being the first independent monitor to win authority to enter the prisons from a State Legislature remarkably fearless about being demagogued on the issue.
Initially, association volunteers visited Sing Sing and documented scandalous lashings of inmates, cold bath immersions and iron yokes. Critics quickly coined the term "coddlers" for those reformers and attempted to rescind their powers. This failed, as did the attempt 20 years ago when a crackdown mood arose after the 1971 Attica prison uprising in which 39 inmates and hostages were slain by authorities reseizing the prison.
On the association's anniversary, members are the first to note great progress beyond the 19th century, when wardens sold entertainment tickets for visitors to watch men and women behind bars and the courts prodded the state to release hundreds of inmates kept beyond their sentences. There were no paroles or Miranda appeals, and crime witnesses could be held along with the accused as a court convenience. People debated the two kinds of prisons: "silent," in which convicts were grouped in monkish, speechless obedience, and "separate," where each inmate was locked in solitude, a method that is back as the latest innovation in overwhelmed modern prisons.
Mr. Gangi celebrates the association's progressive history and hope with no apology for noblesse oblige ideals like rehabilitation. He begs politicians to question whether the $59,000 per prisoner might be spent earlier and more creatively on the same underclass that society is nurturing behind bars. He begs law abiders for something more than amusement at the return of Old Sparky.

HEADLINE: THE NEEDIEST CASES;
A Family Intact, a Promise Fulfilled

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH

 BODY:
In Rebecca Anderson's corner of the South Bronx, families are fragile in the face of poverty and crime. But despite illness and need, Mrs. Anderson has fulfilled a promise to keep her family intact.
 Just before Mrs. Anderson's mother died in 1983, she begged her oldest daughter to watch over their growing family. Now, 30 years after her only child was born, Mrs. Anderson is a full-time mother again. At 54, she shares her cramped apartment with five nieces and nephews who otherwise would be in foster homes. 
Mrs. Anderson took in Zihrah, 18, and Cameca, 16, after their mothers died of heart disease in the 1980's. The girls have lived with Mrs. Anderson ever since, and they look to her as a parent and confidante. In 1991 she took custody of a great-niece, Mimi Smith, now 3, whose mentally disabled mother could not keep her.
 Last month brought two unexpected additions to the family: Mrs. Anderson's nephews Calvin, 1, and Omar, 8 weeks. Both were frail and underweight when they arrived, and Calvin has not learned to chew because his mother fed him only strained baby food. About her, Mrs. Anderson would only say, "We don't keep in touch."
 "There are so many children in the foster system, floating from home to home and being mistreated," she said last week, standing near a steel-barred window in her apartment in the Melrose section of the Bronx. "I couldn't let that happen to these kids."
 The cost of Mrs. Anderson's generosity has been steep. Her husband, Alton Anderson, does not live with the family, and she has sole responsibility for the children's welfare. She has lupus, a potentially life-threatening disease that causes arthritis, high blood pressure and painful skin lesions. After two operations this spring, Mrs. Anderson was overwhelmed by the burdens of second motherhood. She became exhausted, and she stopped cooking and cleaning.
 "If I tried to do housework I would get tremendous pains in my hands," she said. "The girls had jobs and lots of homework, so they couldn't help much. I honestly didn't believe I could keep it up."
 But thanks to a program run by the Children's Aid Society, one of seven charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, Mrs. Anderson was able to keep her nieces and take on her infant nephews.
 Like Mrs. Anderson, these charities are struggling to supplant misery with hope. Today, the fund begins its 83d annual appeal for contributions to help thousands of poor and sick New Yorkers.
 This year, private charities are financing a disproportionate share of social service programs because of state and city budget cuts. Even though the recession is finally ending, donations aren't keeping pace with the demand for services.
 Charity officials also say that indifference toward the poor is more widespread than ever.
 "There's no sense of alarm about what's happening to the most vulnerable people in our city," said Stephen D. Solender, executive vice president of the UJA-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, which receives help from the Neediest Cases Fund. "There's a general acceptance of government cuts, but nobody realizes the devastating effect they will have on the poor."
 As in recent years, charities are trying to aid growing numbers of newly unemployed New Yorkers while also caring for the chronically poor. They say they are especially worried about children and the elderly, who are the most likely to live in poverty.
 In 1992, the latest year for which statistics are available, nearly 20 percent of elderly New Yorkers lived below the poverty level. While 13,500 elderly New Yorkers receive government-subsidized, home-delivered meals, an additional 1,000 are on a waiting list, according to the city's Department for the Aging.
 Meanwhile, 38.5 percent of New York children were poor in 1992, and many of them did not receive public assistance. Charity officials say the need to increase day care and child abuse prevention programs is urgent. They also need to help growing numbers of older women like Mrs. Anderson, who take in relatives' children because of family problems.
 The Neediest Cases Fund dates to Christmas Day 1911, when Adolph S. Ochs, the publisher of The Times, met a man who asked for money and a place to sleep. Mr. Ochs gave him several dollars and a job.
 The encounter inspired Mr. Ochs to have a reporter write about the city's 100 neediest cases in the winter of 1912. That year, 117 contributors gave $3,630.88. Last year, nearly 13,500 people donated $4,590,568.69, the second-highest amount in the campaign's history.
 The Times Foundation pays the costs of running the appeal, so all contributions are given directly to the seven charities. This year's campaign ends on Feb. 28.
 For Mrs. Anderson, relief came when her doctor put her in touch with the Children's Aid Society. The society provided her with a professional homemaker who spends five days a week in the apartment, helping with housekeeping, errands and child care.
 "This was an overwhelmed aunt who wanted to do the right thing but took on more than she could handle," said Mary Hutson, director of the Children's Aid Society's homemaker program. "Now she has the support of a trained professional who can help maintain a level of normalcy in the household."
 Cathy Tillman, the homemaker, became even more invaluable when Mrs. Anderson's nephews came along. She takes Calvin for walks in a stroller, cradles Omar in her lap for hours and gives Mrs. Anderson tips about infant care, something she hadn't thought about in years.
 "I don't even know the word for what I feel about her," Mrs. Anderson said, touching Mrs. Tillman's arm. "I am simply happy to have her help."
 The halls of the Andersons' apartment building are grimy and dark, and the smell of garbage hangs in the air. But inside their homes, constant chatter and activity create a protective barrier. One rainy night last week, Mimi toddled around with a tattered copy of "Peter and the Wolf" as Cameca talked about her coming school trip to Washington. While Mrs. Tillman rocked Omar, Zihrah danced Calvin around the toy-strewn living room. As television cartoons buzzed in the background, Mrs. Anderson talked about the serenity she felt when children were around.
 "Kids mean everything to me," she said. "If I had to do it again, I'd make the same choices. People ask me how I get my peace and quiet, but I would be lonely without them."
 Clearly, though, life could be easier. Money is scarce, and Mrs. Anderson can barely afford to feed her family, let alone buy them shoes and jackets. She lost most of her possessions in a fire three years ago, and is slowly accumulating new furniture. She never knows what effect her illness will have from day to day.
 "I try not to plan ahead and I don't like promises, because they can hurt a lot," she said. "We just take one day at a time, and with the Lord's help we're doing fine." NEXT SUNDAY: Poverty's growing toll on elderly New Yorkers.

HEADLINE: 2 Days From Pilgrims to Maccabees;
Jews Do a Lot of Celebrating in a Season of Multiple Holidays

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
Somewhere between the time she popped her turkey in the oven and the time she wiped the crumbs off the table, Suzanne Farber managed to whip up a few latkes and freeze them.
"It's annoying," she said. "But you do it." 
 Many Jews found themselves squeezed last week. Between Thanksgiving and Hanukkah, which begins tonight -- the first time the two holidays have fallen so close together since 1918 -- there were only two days to make the transition from cooking and eating to cooking and eating, with candles.
There have been Hanukkah parties to plan. There have been presents to buy. And there have been parking places to find at that pit of fire and brimstone, the mall -- all on Thanksgiving weekend.
Some people have proclaimed this a good thing.
"This is much better than being mixed up with Christmas," said Richard Hyfler, who lives on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. "We get a jump on all the shopping and have no problem getting what we want."
In fact, there are other reasons people find the juxtaposition pleasing.
For one thing, it gives a year's hiatus to the often unintentional linking of Hanukkah to Christmas, which many say has always undermined the fact that the two celebrations have nothing to do with each other.
Hanukkah celebrates the victory 2,000 years ago of the Jewish Maccabees in their battle to regain Jerusalem from the Syrians. The menorah used to cast light as they rebuilt the temple there had only enough oil to burn for one night but instead lasted for eight; hence the lighting of the menorah today. Latkes, applesauce and parties with booty are modern additions.
Jews have often complained that a perfectly nice little miracle, albeit one not even mentioned in the Old Testament, should not be compared with the Christian celebration of the birth of Jesus.
They argue that the two are usually folded together largely as an accommodation, with menorahs in holiday store-window displays and songs that give a nod to Hanukkah traditions in elementary-school pageants.
This year Hanukkah shares the limelight with a different kind of holiday, when a fruitful landing in New England by European settlers in the 1600's is commemorated with overindulgence and good cheer. In fact, some Jews do not celebrate Thanksgiving at all because it is a secular holiday.
But Shira Dicker, a columnist for several Jewish weeklies, believes that in fact Thanksgiving and Hanukkah are close in spirit. "Hanukkah is a festival of lights," she said. "The gratitude that is awakened during Thanksgiving serves as a catalyst for us to put light in other people's lives."
Because Thanksgiving and the beginning of Hanukkah fall on the same weekend this year, families who might not otherwise be together have gathered to celebrate both holidays. Every 10 years or so, Hanukkah falls in early December, but very rarely -- only once or twice a century -- does it overlap with Thanksgiving weekend.
"It fits in perfectly," said Rabbi Judith Lewis of Temple Israel in Manhattan. "On Thanksgiving the family is together anyway, so they get a chance to light candles together."
(On the flip side, those who find family gatherings only slightly less stressful than, for instance, angioplasty can get two for one without feeling guilty about their lunar luck.)
Even retailers, who over the last few years have only been able to gripe and groan about the economy, are cheerful. They got a few extra days of gift-buying out of the bargain, they reason, and can better accommodate early shoppers.
"When the two were close before, I think about seven years ago, it was very good for us," said Joseph Siegel, the vice president of retail services for the National Retail Federation in New York.
"You get a buying pattern that starts a lot earlier, and it gives us an even flow. When people have time, they will buy 12 items; when they don't, they'll settle for eight. Then we'll be out of what they wanted anyway, so they'll just give money instead."
Sylvia Weiser got one such jump on the masses by doing all her shopping early last month. 'It puts a little pressure on you," Mrs. Weiser said. "But I learned that I just had to do it all early."
By the time her entire family gathered together in her home in Manhasset Hills, L.I., for turkey and stuffing, all the Hanukkah gifts were wrapped and ready. 'I have to wrap right away," she said. "Everyone in this house cheats."
Saul Zabar, an owner of Zabar's, said there were even some favorable gastronomic implications.
"I talked to some of my religious customers," he said on Wednesday. "I asked them, 'What are you going to do different this year, guys?' They told me, 'We're going to eat our regular thing on Thanksgiving, our regular thing on Hanukkah, and if there is any cranberry sauce left, we will put it on our latkes.' "
Ah, the adaptable American palate.
There is truth, there is light and then there is convenience. And so an early Hanukkah is beloved by many, if for no other reason than it seems to fit well into the Filofax.
Richard Kahn, a part-time student and part-time research assistant, is squeezing in a Hanukkah party between Thanksgiving, work and his final exams. "This is great for party-planning because when Hanukkah is close to Christmas, people have a much busier party schedule," he said.
So everybody who is anybody in his world will show up at Mr. Kahn's apartment in Washington Heights next weekend. But his wife, Robin Gillespi, sees another silver lining. They are an interfaith couple, and so, "this way, you can get presents all month long," she said
A final thought: it's better not to marvel aloud that Hanukkah "came early" this year. It annoys the people who already feel bullied by the solar calendar.
"Hanukkah is never early, and it's never late," insisted Rabbi James Rudin, the director of inter-religious affairs at the American Jewish Committee. "Jews and Muslims use the lunar calendar, and so the holiday always falls on the 25th day of Kislev. That's that."
 A picture caption on Nov. 28 about Hanukkah misstated part of the traditional account of the holiday's origin. According to tradition, the menorah oil used by the Jews as they rebuilt the temple in Jerusalem lasted for eight nights though it was only enough for one night; the story does not say it was just one drop.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 13, 1994, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Nov. 27 about preparations for Thanksgiving and Hanukkah overstated the rarity of the holidays' occurring so close together. Since 1896, there have been 10 instances when the two holidays came as close together as they did this year; in 9 of those, Hanukkah overlapped the Thanksgiving weekend.

HEADLINE: A Thing About Men, and a Thing About Women

BYLINE: By Walter Kendrick; Walter Kendrick, a professor of English at Fordham University, is the author of "The Secret Museum: Pornography in Modern Culture."

 BODY:

D. H. LAWRENCE
The Story of a Marriage.
By Brenda Maddox.
Illustrated. 620 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $30. 
 WAS D. H. Lawrence homosexual? His fiction abounds with overheated evocations of male beauty and male bonding; his men love to give each other rubdowns, as George and Cyril do in "The White Peacock" (1911), or wrestle naked on the library carpet, as Rupert and Gerald do in "Women in Love" (1920). At the end of that novel, Rupert has won Ursula, with whom he looks forward to a perfect marriage. But he has lost Gerald, which leaves him unsatisfied.
"I wanted eternal union with a man too: another kind of love," he tells Ursula. Despite her high tolerance for Lawrentian rhetoric, she balks at this: "You can't have two kinds of love," she declares.
"It seems as if I can't," he said. "Yet I wanted it."
"You can't have it, because it's wrong, impossible," she said.
"I don't believe that," he answered.
"Women in Love" ends on this oddly querulous note, as if Lawrence were annoyed at himself for failing to settle the matter.
The issue of Lawrence's homosexuality haunts Brenda Maddox's "D. H. Lawrence: The Story of a Marriage," and in the end she never quite settles it either. If David Herbert Lawrence (1885-1930) had sex with a man, she tells us, he had it only once, with a Cornish farmer. But Lawrence's homosexuality may have been of the repressed variety, which can turn nasty. He often found himself powerfully attracted to other men, from whom he violently recoiled. He could also be a virulent misogynist, both in fiction and in life; his hatred of women may have expressed fear of the feminine in himself.
But Lawrence loved women too; his fiction also abounds with extravagant praise of womanhood and the eternal union of two sexes. There is no grander paean to carnal heterosexuality than "Lady Chatterley's Lover" (1928), which crowned Lawrence's career, although the unexpurgated version wasn't sold publicly until 30 years after his death.
Besides, in 1912 Lawrence ran away with one of literary history's most womanly women, the formidable Frieda Weekley (1879-1956), nee von Richthofen, who got him into bed 20 minutes after meeting him, and who left her husband and children for Lawrence. From their marriage in 1914 until Lawrence's death from tuberculosis in 1930, they loved and warred across four continents, usually with violence and often in public. Lawrence was, as Ms. Maddox says, "above all -- as he saw himself -- a married man."
Ms. Maddox's title, "D. H. Lawrence," and her subtitle, "The Story of a Marriage," make a strange pair -- almost as strange as Lawrence and Frieda. This is not, however, a dual biography, nor is it an attempt to rescue the forgotten partner, as Ms. Maddox did with Mrs. James Joyce in "Nora: The Real Life of Molly Bloom." Except for two chapters, Lawrence stands always at the center of "D. H. Lawrence." The 26 years Frieda lived after his death are summarized in as many pages.
But Ms. Maddox also hasn't written a full-fledged biography of Lawrence. Though she often seeks to explain his odd adult behavior in terms of childhood influences, she spends very little time on his actual childhood and next to none on his parents. For Ms. Maddox's purposes, Lawrence's life properly began when he was 26, the day Frieda pounced. "He never had a chance," Ms. Maddox quips. But she shows clearly that he wouldn't have wanted one.
For the next 18 years, Lawrence remained, except for two brief lapses, utterly faithful to Frieda. She, meanwhile, pursued her cheerfully promiscuous way, bestowing her favors as freely on other men as she had on him. By 1926, she had taken up with Lieut. Angelo Ravagli, an Italian infantry officer, with whom she consorted intermittently throughout Lawrence's last years and whom she married in 1950. Lawrence knew all about Frieda's peccadilloes and more or less tolerated them, though he exacted a sort of revenge by treating her horribly at every opportunity.
Throughout their marriage, he flailed at her physically; his tubercular frailness, however, prevented him from doing much harm to the robust Frieda. His verbal abuse was unstinting: "you sniffing bitch!" counts among his gentler salutations. But that, too, seems to have left no scars. Frieda could give as good as she got -- less cleverly than the famous writer but with appropriate effect -- and she was not above hurling a few dishes at his head. Time and time again, Ms. Maddox tells us, their friends (in whose company these battles often took place) believed that the marriage had to be at an end, but hostility seems only to have reinforced it. Half an hour after an especially savage clash, Katherine Mansfield was astonished to encounter Lawrence and Frieda strolling amiably arm in arm, discussing macaroni and cheese.
APPALLING though the Lawrences' behavior must have been to witness, in Ms. Maddox's able hands it makes highly amusing reading. She tracks Lawrence and Frieda around the globe and in and out of innumerable friendships with the famous and nearly so. She also accounts provocatively for the unflagging stream of novels, stories and nonfiction that Lawrence managed to crank out between bouts with illness and with Frieda.
Some of Ms. Maddox's attempts to link Lawrence's fiction with his life are a bit overingenious, and she turns several handsprings attempting to refute the charge of misogyny that feminists have leveled against him. Despite dozens of valiant attempts, she does not succeed in accounting for the bizarreries of Lawrentian sexuality; indeed, she left this reader wondering what was supposed to be so compelling about that distinctly unappetizing subject. On the whole, however, "D. H. Lawrence" is a pleasure. It is a thoroughly absorbing, satisfying treatment of Lawrence's life, his work and his mysterious marriage.
 
 
 
A BALANCE OF EXTREMES
 Five years ago, Brenda Maddox's publisher suggested she write a biography of D. H. Lawrence. "I said, 'Anybody but Lawrence!' " recalled Ms. Maddox, whose "D. H. Lawrence: The Story of a Marriage" received Britain's Whitbread Award for biography earlier this month. "I'd never enjoyed reading him," the Massachusetts-born Ms. Maddox explained during a recent visit to New York from London, where she has lived since 1960. "I like economy, brevity, precision. He's very purple and over the top."
But as she began to read the existing Lawrence biographies, she discovered affinities to James Joyce, whose life she knew well. "They were English and Irish sides of the same coin," said Ms. Maddox, whose biography of Joyce's wife, Nora, was published in 1988. "They both have reputations as libertines because they wrote about sex, but they both had these mostly monogamous marriages to strong, earthy women."
Ms. Maddox has been asked repeatedly how she feels about her subject, whose racism, anti-Semitism and misogyny have incurred criticism in recent years. "I certainly try not to flinch from the bad side of his character," she said. "But it's always balanced by the exact opposite."
She said she considered only "for about 20 minutes" writing a solo biography of Lawrence's wife, Frieda. "She wasn't that interesting as a character in her own right," Ms. Maddox explained. "She dramatized herself so much -- told her own story and prettied it up. She was no Nora Joyce." MARGALIT FOX

HEADLINE: Counting the Contribution of the Arts

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
WHICH statement is true? Support for the arts comes at the expense of economic development. Or, the arts are an industry that provides jobs that generate substantial revenues to local, state and Federal governments.
"The first statement is definitely false," said Janet T. Langsam, executive director of the Westchester Arts Council. "For almost five years we have been researching the role played by the arts in community development, and our findings emphatically dispel any misconceptions about the value of the arts." 
 The arts in Westchester, Ms. Langsam continued, represent a growing industry, one that employs 310 people full time and provides part-time jobs for 813 more people. "And 40 new jobs were created this year, which may not seem like a tremendous number," she said. "But if every industry in Westchester showed such an increase we'd all be sitting pretty. Far from being a drain on the community, the arts are part of the solution to our economic woes."
And if it was a business, the arts would be a big one. Nonprofit arts in the United States are a $36.8 billion business supporting 1.3 million full-time jobs. Last year in Westchester, nonprofit arts generated $28 million for the local economy. "That was up by 6 percent from the year before," Ms. Langsam said. "And some of that money is funneled directly back to the state. Last year the state's coffers were enriched by $2.2 million, which was returned in the form of sales tax and income taxes paid by the people who work for Westchester arts organizations."
And when the $28 million is scrutinized more closely, its value quadruples to $112 million, which is the estimated amount that is spent on ancillary items like restaurant meals, baby sitters, gasoline and parking by the 1.1 million people who attend arts events in the county.
Tourism, Ms. Langsam said, is the most measurable economic return on the arts dollar, with 12 percent of the 1.1 million-member audience coming from outside the county.
The council's findings are based on information from the applications of 150 arts organizations that sought grants from the council in 1990.
"The number of grant applications has risen steadily since then," Ms. Langsam added. "We had 182 this year, which makes it difficult for our committee to make the dollar decisions as to who gets what in face of the $150,000 we've lost in donations from area corporations over the last three years."
Organizations receiving grants this year include the Town Wall Muralists, a team consisting of Francesca Samsel and Mariah Fee. The two artists are doing a large mural depicting the history of Peekskill for the newly revived downtown art district in Peekskill. "They initially applied for $2,500, but we were only able to give them $1,000," Ms. Langsam said. "The largest grant we made this year was to the Neuberger Museum of Art at the Purchase College, and that was for $45,000."
In an attempt to increase financial resources available for arts organizations and artists, the council has changed its fund-raising methods, Ms. Langsam said, adding: "We work with a $1.6 million budget but financially it's hard to stay even today. We're running harder than ever just to stay in place."
In order to make up the shortfall, the council is using different ways to get more individuals and foundations involved. "Individuals give more than 80 percent of all charitable donations," Ms. Langsam said. "So we're trying to appeal to individuals by scheduling a lot of small events throughout the year such as wine tastings and theater parties. We hold something every other month, and the results are beginning to show. But our major fund-raiser is our gala benefit, which we've been holding for 17 years now. Last year the gala raised $175,000. This year we hope to hit the $200,000 mark."
Ann F. Peterson, the general manager of the Holiday Inn-Crowne Plaza in White Plains, is this year's chairwoman of the gala, to be held Dec. 10 at the County Center in White Plains. "This year our theme is 1930's swing," Ms. Peterson said. "And what better place is there for such an event than the County Center? It has been at the hub of the county's cultural and social life since it opened in 1930."
For the fourth consecutive year, seven member hotels of the Westchester Hotel Association will collaborate on a menu for the gala, with all food and service contributed by the hotels. "We go all out to show our wares to the gala audience, and we expect 500 people," Ms. Peterson said. "We will also be donating staff. All of us in the hospitality industry are very aware of how much the arts contribute to our individual economic well-being. Attendance at arts events brings business to hotels and restaurants."
And attendance at cultural events is up in Westchester, Ms. Langsam said. "We have so many good new theater companies and so many more high-caliber musical groups in Westchester communities that what's happening is that families are going to New York less and less, finding there are considerable attractions much more affordable and more convenient."
The council's role in the community extends to enlisting a core of business volunteers who give managerial hands-on help to different arts groups. "Texaco sponsors what we call the Business Volunteers for Arts Programs," Ms. Langsam said. "The volunteers are business people who work directly with the staff of the different arts organizations."
One example of how the program works, she said, was what was done when Lyndhurst recently decided to open its carriage house for outside profit-making events like weddings.
"Phyllis Barron, a marketing executive at American Express, met with the Lyndhurst staff and worked with them, showing them how to make their events profitable," Ms. Langsam said. "So far we've made 14 similar successful marriages."
And when a Hudson Valley writers center wanted to conduct an audience-marketing survey, it was another business volunteer, Judy Miller, who runs a marketing concern in Millwood, who donated her services to the project.
"It is another way we are able to add value to our arts organizations," Ms. Langsam said.
