HEADLINE: PRESIDENT STAGES SHOW OF SUPPORT FOR TRADE ACCORD

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28

 BODY:
President Clinton opened the White House this morning to a delegation of Republicans for the first time since Election Day to rally support for the global trade pact whose fate will be the first test of the bipartisanship on which he now must rely.
With the lame-duck Congress back in town to vote on the trade agreement, opponents of the accord were waging last-ditch efforts to block it, contending it could harm American workers and undermine United States sovereignty. But they conceded that they lacked the votes in the House, which takes up the measure on Tuesday. And Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, predicted that the measure would win a comfortable victory in the Senate as well when that body votes on Thursday. 
 Mr. Clinton's declared purpose in gathering the lawmakers, as well as former Cabinet members and five Nobel laureates, was to call attention to the number of prominent Americans from both parties who support the accord. But the East Room pageant also served as a remarkable window on Washington and its new ways.
There in the front row where members of Congress were renewing acquaintances, the broad grins on the faces of men like Representative Dick Armey of Texas, who is likely to be the next majority leader, distinguished Republican from Democrat. At Mr. Clinton's side on the stage was James A. Baker 3d, the Republican lawyer, diplomat and strategist, who appears to be preparing his own bid for the White House.
And among the crowd, all that had changed could be measured in the stoic expression worn by Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington as he stood to acknowledge an ovation offered in tribute to a career that ended with his defeat at his constituents' hands on Nov. 8.
Now that Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, has given the trade agreement his blessing, it appears almost certain to clear Congress, and the President and his Republican guests were plainly enjoying their chance to show common cause on an issue that Mr. Clinton said "bulldozes differences of party, philosophy and ideology."
Among those who spoke before Mr. Clinton, James C. Miller 3d, the budget director in the Reagan White House, said that "if there's anything we Republicans and Democrats ought to be able to agree on," it was the trade accord.
But behind the White House's trumpeting today of trade-pact endorsements from two former Treasury Secretaries, three former Presidents, four former Commerce Secretaries and all 11 former budget directors was a recognition that opportunities for future collaboration may be rare.
Aides said today that, to help guarantee that the agreement was not sidetracked again, Mr. Clinton had invited 75 House members from both parties to join him for breakfast at the White House on Tuesday. They also said that as early as Tuesday he may hold his first post-election meeting with Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the Republican who will be the next Speaker of the House and who has given his support to the accord.
Even though Democrats still hold majorities in both Houses of the lame-duck Congress, the large number of liberal Democrats opposed to the trade pact means that to get the measure approved, the White House must rely on the same kind of support from Republicans that it will need beginning in January, when that party takes control of Congress.
Apart from an expected joint effort to give the President the power to veto budget items one by one instead of rejecting an entire bill, White House officials acknowledged that they were hard pressed to identify an issue on which the President and Republicans were likely to work hand in hand.
Mindful of the discord that may lie ahead, Mr. Clinton injected a hint of urgency into his comments today as he warned lawmakers against postponing action once more on the agreement, whose benefits he said would include an increase in the income of the average American family. "We have to do it now," he declared. "We can't wait until next year. We don't want to litter it up like a Christmas tree and risk losing it."
The pact would expand the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to include farming and lower most tariffs by an average of one-third.
In addition to Mr. Armey, the Republican members of Congress who joined the President, half of his Cabinet and several Democrats this morning included two prominent conservatives, Representatives David Dreier of California and Jim Kolbe of Arizona, who beamed almost constantly as they greeted one another and accepted Democratic congratulations.
And beyond Mr. Baker and Mr. Miller, the more than a dozen former Republican officials who filed in to show their support for the accord included Carla A. Hills, the trade representative under President George Bush; Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser under Mr. Bush and President Reagan, and even veterans like Herbert Stein, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Nixon.
The Nobel prize-winning economists in the audience were Wassily Leontief, Paul A. Samuelson, James Tobin, Lawrence R. Klein and Robert M. Solow. And while they did not attend, Mr. Bush and former Presidents Jimmy Carter and Gerald R. Ford all proclaimed their support for the pact in a letter that was read aloud by Vice President Al Gore. Ronald Reagan, the fourth surviving former President, is suffering from Alzheimer's disease, and White House officials said his aides had decided not to ask him to get involved in the issue.
Among the opponents of the accord who were working to block it today, Senator Byron L. Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota, asked at a news conference whether it was fair to make American workers "compete against a 12-year-old working 12 hours a day for 12 cents an hour."
But proponents like Mr. Baker used their appearances at the White House to compare such doomsaying to what the former Secretary of State called predictions from "the misguided and misinformed," including Ross Perot, the former Presidential candidate, that the North American Free Trade Agreement would lead to a major loss of American jobs.
Like the other Democrats and Republicans who exchanged pleasantries this morning, Mr. Baker and Mr. Clinton appeared gracious toward one another as they sat side by side. But after Mr. Gore noted how happy he and the President had been to see "how much Secretary Baker is enjoying life outside Washington," the Republican could not resist a retort.
"It's always fun to come back to the White House in November," said Mr. Baker, who is trying to decide whether to run for President in 1996.

With them at a private reception in the East Room was James C. Miller 3d, former director of the Office of Management and Budget.; Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, predicted at the White House meeting yesterday that the pact would be approved easily. HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Strong Economic Signs Drive Bond Prices Down

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were down across the board yesterday, as the bond market, having benefited from investors' shifting money out of stocks last week, reversed course.
Kevin McClintock, manager of fixed-income portfolios for Aeltus Investment Management Inc. in Hartford, cited reports of October home sales growth and strong Christmas sales as a troublesome twosome for bonds yesterday. 
 In the first of a batch of economic reports expected this week, the National Association of Realtors said sales of existing homes rose an unexpectedly strong five-tenths of 1 percent in October to an annual rate of 3.91 million, after dropping a revised 1 percent in September to 3.89 million. Originally September sales were reported as a 1 percent gain.
The 30-year bond declined 14/32 of a percentage point, to 94 18/32 , for a yield of 7.98 percent, up from 7.94 percent on Friday. Shorter maturities also fell in price.
Early reports of a healthy start to the pivotal Christmas retail shopping season put pressure on the market because they were consistent with a moderate upward trend in consumer spending.
"Both confirmed that the economy is still very, very strong," Mr. McClintock said. To bond investors a strong economy translates to a pickup in inflationary pressures, and those pressures point to higher interest rates.
Also, Mr. McClintock added, consumer confidence was strong. "If people have jobs, they will continue to spend money on homes," he said. "They may be smaller, but they're still buying homes."
Last week, with the stock market on the skids, many people shifted money to the fixed-income market. Analysts speculate that economic data coming out this week will be strong, and that will mean interest rates will have to go higher to slow the economy. "I personally think the peak in yields still lies ahead," Mr. McClintock said. He sees the long bond somewhere between 8.5 percent and 9 percent, with the yield curve -- the difference in short- and long-term rates -- flatter than it is now before the Fed is satisfied. A flattening of the curve is generally regarded as a sign that the economy has started to slow.
Yesterday the Treasury sold $27.2 billion in new three- and six-month bills, as the average rate at auction rose a bit. The three-month rate was up two basis points -- or hundredths of a percentage point -- from the previous weekly auction, to 5.40 percent, while the six-month rate was up one basis point, to 5.86 percent.
The early signs of holiday sales matching or even surpassing last year's 6 percent gain helped put a crimp on speculation of a slowing economy. Providing evidence of the strong Christmas retail start, data from Telecheck showed check volume on the Friday after Thanksgiving up 5.7 percent from a year ago, while Mastercard reported charge volume up a sizzling 36.2 percent, in part a reflection of the increased use of credit cards this year.
Traders expect the long bond to top 8 percent this week, with several economic reports due.
Today, the Government will release revised data for third-quarter gross domestic product, or the total output of goods and services.
On Thursday, the National Association of Purchasing Management will publish its November survey of business conditions. And on Friday the key employment report is expected to show the economy added 240,000 jobs in November, up from 194,000 in October.
In the municipal bond market, prices were lower, with investors looking toward higher yields on this week's $2.7 billion of new issues. Yesterday's biggest offering was by Pennsylvania's Intergovernmental Co-op Authority, a $124 million sale of bonds negotiated through Smith Barney Inc.
The bonds were initially priced to yield as much as 7.20 percent for an issue due in 2024, but because of good investor demand the yield was lowered to 7.13 percent. Serial bonds with shorter maturities were priced to yield from 4.20 percent in 1995 to 6.85 percent in 2009.
Because the issue is insured by the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company, the financing is rated triple-A by the major rating agencies.
The following are the results of yesterday's three- and six-month bills auction:

HEADLINE: Visa Card Use Sets a Record

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 28

 BODY:
Visa U.S.A., the credit card company, said today that consumers in the United States charged a record $1 billion worth of goods on their Visa credit and debit cards on Friday, surpassing the $800 million in charges on the corresponding day last year.
The day after Thanksgiving is traditionally the holiday season's busiest shopping day. 
 Visa said that for Friday and Saturday combined, the total amount charged by card holders was $1.9 billion, a record for the two days and 24 percent over 1993's total.
Thomas Layman, chief economist at Visa U.S.A., attributed the larger numbers to lower unemployment and increased personal income, which in turn improve consumer confidence.

HEADLINE: Existing-Home Sales Manage Gain

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28

 BODY:
Sales of existing homes rose a slight five-tenths of a percent in October, the National Association of Realtors said today in a report that economists hailed as proof of the economy's resilience in the face of higher interest rates.
The real estate group said sales of existing homes last month reached an annual rate of 3.91 million, up from a revised 3.89 million units in September. 
 "This is remarkable stability considering that 30-year fixed-rate mortgages have risen by 200 basis points, and one-year adjustable-rate mortgages have risen by 150 basis points," said Sung Won Sohn, senior vice president and chief economist at the Norwest Corporation.
Although sales were up from the previous month, October sales were off 3 percent from the annual rate of 4.03 million units a year ago.
Also, the October figure was below Wall Street economists' forecast of a 3.92 million annual rate.
Despite October's relative stability, John Tuccillo, chief economist for the realtors' group, said home sales were bound to be affected by the Federal Reserve's most recent interest rate increases.
"Adjustable-rate mortgages will be affected more than long-term rates, but increases in both can be expected," he said.
The Fed engineered a rise of three-quarters of a percentage point in short-term rates on Nov. 15, the sixth increase in short-term rates this year.
The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said the average rate on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages was 8.93 percent in October, compared with 8.68 percent in September and 6.83 percent in October 1993.
Economists said a strong job market had partly offset the higher rates; consumers who feel secure in their jobs are more willing to make a major purchase such as a home.
"Higher interest rates are working against the fixed-rate mortgages, but you get some relief from that because people are taking on adjustable-rate mortgages," added Darwin Beck, money market economist at CS First Boston.
The Mortgage Bankers Association of America reported that the share of applications for adjustable-rate mortgages was 34 percent in the week of Nov. 18.
Mr. Sung said that some demand was driven by borrowers who rushed to buy housing before interest rates moved even higher. "When we get numbers for November, I would expect a more meaningful slowdown in existing home sales," he said.
The real estate group previously reported September sales at a 3.97 million annual rate.
The median price of homes -- the midpoint at which half sold for more and half for less -- fell to $107,900, from $108,400 in September. But it was up from $106,600 a year ago.
The supply of homes in October was 5.1 months, down from 5.2 months a month earlier, the group said. In October last year, there were 5.9 months' worth of homes available.
The South led in the number of homes sold last month, at 1.43 million, unchanged from September but down from 1.47 million a year ago. Sales were slowest in the Northeast, where 560,000 homes were sold, unchanged from September.
Average prices were highest in the West at $139,900, down from $146,500 in September and $143,400 a year earlier. They were cheapest in the Midwest, at $86,700, down from $87,100.

HEADLINE: Faster Growth Is Predicted

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28

 BODY:
The economy is expected to grow more quickly this year than previously predicted, according to a survey of 30 forecasters, the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia said today.
The quarterly survey of 30 economic forecasters compiled by the Philadelphia Fed predicted that the gross domestic product will grow 3.9 percent in 1994, up two-tenths of a percentage point from their forecast in the last survey. That compares with G.D.P. growth of about 3 percent in 1993. 
 For 1995, the forecasters see G.D.P. growing at 2.9 percent, up four-tenths of a percentage point from the last survey.
The outlook for inflation this year, as measured by the Consumer Price Index, is little changed in the current survey. Forecasters see inflation averaging 2.9 percent this year, unchanged from the previous survey. For 1995, inflation is expected to be 3.4 percent, up a tenth of a percentage point compared with the last survey.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Players Set to Stay Off Owners' New Pitches

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LEESBURG, Va., Nov. 28

 BODY:
If this were a lottery, the winning number could be $34,243,314. Or $34,865,920. But major league baseball players won't play either one. They think both are losers.
The players' labor representatives are expected to deliver that message to the owners' negotiating team on Tuesday when they resume bargaining in the dispute that first wiped out the last seven weeks of the regular season, then erased the post-season and now has created chaos in the clubs' off-season planning. 
 They will meet at the Lansdowne Conference Resort in this Washington suburb, a site selected by Bill Usery Jr., the mediator who has been directing the talks at the request of the Clinton Administration.
Members of the owners' committee, who knew the players would not accept either of the proposals they made the last time they met, arrived here hoping the players would have a counterproposal, but the players were not expected to present one. If they formulate a new proposal, they most likely would do it at their executive board meeting in Atlanta next week.
The owners are scheduled to meet next Monday in Chicago, where they are expected to vote on the next step in their labor strategy: declaring an impasse in negotiations and unilaterally implementing their salary-cap proposal as baseball's new economic system.
The owners ideally would like that system in place by Dec. 7, the deadline under the existing system for clubs to offer their free agents salary arbitration to retain rights to them, and if not by then, certainly by Dec. 20, which is the deadline for clubs to tender contracts to all unsigned players. More than 80 percent of the 1,087 players on major league rosters are unsigned.
In the last round of bargaining, 10 days ago, the owners presented the players with a revised salary-cap proposal and a new, alternative plan that would tax total payrolls when they exceed a designated threshold. That the two proposals have the same effect should not be surprising considering the owners' goal: to create a "drag" on salaries and regain control of their player costs.
In a memo to all players last week, Donald Fehr, the head of the union, told his members that the owners' negotiators, in discussing the tax plan, "made it clear that, ideally, no club would exceed the threshold."
Under the revised proposal for a salary cap, the payroll limit for each team in 1995 would be $34,243,314. Under the alternative proposal, the tax-triggering threshold for next season would be $34,865,920. The players believe the tax would be so onerous that clubs would reduce their payrolls to avoid paying it. Thus, they argue, the tax would serve as a cap.
The figures differ slightly because of the way the proposals compute them. Both use a defined gross revenue, based on prestrike projections for 1994, of $1,743,296,000, and the players would receive 50 percent of that sum for all of their costs, including salaries for all of the players on 40-man rosters, bonuses, daily meal allowances and pension and benefit plan contributions.
For the salary cap, the maximum payroll would be determined by taking 50 percent, dividing by 28 for the 28 clubs and multiplying the result by 110 percent. The tax threshold would be determined the same way, except the percentage figure would be 112 percent.
For each $500,000 up to $5 million a club exceeded the tax threshold, it would pay a 1 percent tax. Beyond that level, it would pay 1 percent for each $250,000 increment, with the aggregate tax -- the sum of all of the 1 percents -- being limitless.
A team would pay no tax up to the threshold. But once it went beyond the threshold, the resulting tax would be applied to the entire payroll.
In other words, if the Mets had a total payroll of $34.5 million, they would fall under the tax threshold and pay no tax. But if they then acquired Ken Griffey Jr. in a trade for a collection of minor league players not on their 40-man roster, the addition of Griffey's $6 million-a-year contract would force them to pay a 13 percent tax on their entire $40.5 million payroll, or $5,265,000. Griffey, then, would cost the Mets not $6 million but $11,265,000.
Members of the union's staff spent several days of the past week asking questions about both proposals to make sure they understood all of the nuances and ramifications of the plans. Their increased understanding didn't figure to lessen their dislike for the plans.
The more knowledgeable staff members briefed the other members of the players' negotiating committee this evening ahead of the joint session scheduled for Tuesday.
Members of the owners' negotiating group arrived at the conference center today and met separately with Usery, who also planned to meet separately with the players' committee.

HEADLINE: Astronomy Crisis Deepens As the Hubble Telescope Sees No Missing Mass

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD 

 BODY:
IN their audacious reach for understanding of the universe, cosmologists often draw back hands that are maddeningly empty. They know, for example, there is more out there than meets the eye. But hard as they try, they are unable to grasp the nature of what lurks in the blackness enfolding the luminous stars and galaxies, that shadowy substance whose gravitational pull must be the organizing force for the evolution and overall structure of the universe.
The abundance of this invisible mass, whatever it is, could dictate the fate of the universe. Unless there is more mass than scientists so far have been able to measure or infer, that fate would appear to be bleak indeed. 
 Over the last two decades, evidence for this missing mass has become overwhelming and always perplexing. The stars and gas that are visible are quite inadequate to produce most of the gravity needed to account for the observed shapes and motions of galaxies. If it were not for huge quantities of some unseen matter, galaxies would not be clustering, as they tend to do, but would be flying off in all directions.
By most estimates, this missing matter constitutes more than 90 percent of the universe's total mass. Scientists call it dark matter, descriptive not only of its invisibility but also of their own mystification.
"It's a fairly embarrassing situation to admit that we can't find 90 percent of the universe," sighed Dr. Bruce H. Margon, an astrophysicist at the University of Washington at Seattle.
Identifying the nature and amount of dark matter is the central problem in cosmology today. It is an obsession of everyone concerned.
Astronomers, for all their sensitive new telescopes looking into the visible and invisible, are dismayed by their continuing failure to observe anything more than a tiny fraction of the total cosmic mass. They keep hoping that a significant portion of dark matter is made of giant planets, faint or failed stars or those powerful gravitational sinks known as black holes -- all the stuff they deal in.
But two surveys by the repaired Hubble Space Telescope, announced two weeks ago, appeared to rule out a favorite explanation of astronomers for the dark matter. They had thought that dim small stars, red dwarfs, might be plentiful enough in galaxies to constitute much of the missing mass. And yet the orbiting telescope, able to detect faint stars 100 times dimmer than those seen from the ground, found that red dwarfs are actually quite sparse, a negligible component of cosmic mass.
This setback has shifted more of the burden of the search from observational astronomers to particle physicists, increasingly important players in cosmology. They seek to explain the universe in terms of concepts drawn from theory, studies of cosmic rays and atom-smashing experiments in gigantic accelerators. They strain to think of solutions to the dark-matter problem beyond the realm of ordinary matter.
Some of the cosmic mass, particle physicists suggest, could be in the form of fast-moving neutrinos, subatomic particles that pervade the universe. They are known byproducts of the Big Bang, the theorized explosive event of cosmic creation, but no one yet is sure if neutrinos have any mass. Much more of the missing mass, physicists think, could be something more exotic and sluggish, which they call cold dark matter. For various theoretical reasons, such weakly interacting massive particles, dubbed WIMP's, could exist in great abundance. But they have never been detected.
This line of investigation could have profound philosophical implications. If most of the universe is discovered to be composed of exotic material never before seen and absolutely unlike the "ordinary" matter of stars, of Earth and of all life, cosmologists point out, the effect on human thinking could be more startling and diminishing than the Copernican revolution, which almost five centuries ago revealed that Earth was not the center of the universe or even the solar system.
For theorists, this is a time of high anxiety. As long as dark matter eludes astronomers and particle physicists, they cannot be comfortably sure of the validity of their most cherished theories. The dark matter question, said Dr. David H. Schramm, a University of Chicago astrophysicist, is "perhaps the greatest mystery remaining in the Big Bang picture of the universe."
By learning the type and abundance of dark matter, theorists could finally solve the vexing problem of explaining how a universe that began as smooth and uniform in all directions, according to the Big Bang theory and some supporting observations, evolved into the large-scaled clumpiness of galaxies and clusters of galaxies. There has never seemed to be sufficient time or mass for such a radical transformation.
But recent maps of the heavens clearly show clusters of galaxies bigger than anyone imagined possible a few years ago. These galactic walls stretch across half a billion light-years. Compounding the problem, the Hubble telescope recently gave a measure of the expansion rate of the universe that implied its age could be as young as 8 billion years, in contrast to previous estimates that ran as high as 20 billion.
Theorists would also like to resolve the dark-matter problem because the ultimate fate of the universe will be determined by how much mass there is.
If there is sufficient mass spread over the universe, the force of gravity will eventually bring the post-Big Bang expansion to a halt and even reverse it, causing a cataclysmic collapse sometimes described as the "big crunch." Or if there is too little mass, the weaker gravitational force would allow the universe to expand forever. Such an open universe would become vanishingly thin, populated only by gas, dust and dark cinders of dwarf stars and gripped by temperatures falling toward absolute zero -- a future characterized as the "big chill." (Not to worry; such dire fates are billions of years off.)
Between these two extremes, there is a more attractive possibility, a condition called critical density. In this case, the mass would be precisely what is necessary to keep the universe in balance between expanding forever and eventually collapsing. Such a critical density, an average throughout space of one hydrogen atom per 10 cubic meters, is usually expressed by cosmologists as omega equals one.
For theoretical and perhaps esthetic reasons, cosmologists have long been partisans of critical density. The bulk motions of galaxies on extremely large scales, associated with unseen masses known as the Great Attractor, and the measured rate at which the universe's expansion appears to be slowing down, cosmologists argue, indicate the cosmic mass is near critical density. And the Big Bang theory seems to demand critical density.
Writing in the October issue of Sky and Telescope magazine, Dr. Schramm asserted: "In the most straightforward Big Bang model, even a microscopic deviation from omega equals one would have had disastrous results early on, at least without some special selective tuning. The newborn universe would have either recollapsed immediately into a Big Crunch or expanded and dissipated so fast that stars wouldn't have had time to form."
In the inflationary model, a 1981 modification of the standard Big Bang thesis in which a brief but dramatic expansion occurred in the beginning, the universe has to have precisely the critical density. Since the inflationary Big Bang is widely supported by scientists because it so neatly explains much else about cosmic history, cosmologists want to believe its predictions of critical density. Otherwise they would have lost even more than their struggle to understand dark matter.
But so far, all measurements of cosmic mass fall well short of critical density, presumably indicating an open universe on its way to the big chill. At best, said Dr. Jeremiah P. Ostriker, a Princeton University astrophysicist, combinations of visible and likely dark matter add up to no more than 20 percent or possibly 30 percent of critical density.
"A lot of people don't think omega equals one," said Dr. Craig J. Hogan, a University of Washington astrophysicist. "They are the empiricists, the observers. They have discovered that there really isn't any evidence for high omega."
Dr. John N. Bahcall, an astrophysicist at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J., whose research on red dwarfs seemed to limit dark-matter possibilities, put it more bluntly. "I have a feeling that we just need to admit to ourselves that the emperor has no clothes," Dr. Bahcall said of the lack of observational evidence for critical density.
But like many specialists in the dark-matter hunt, Dr. Joel Primack, a theoretical physicist at the University of California at Santa Cruz, is not throwing in the towel. He and colleagues are developing new recipes combining neutrinos and cold dark matter like WIMP's that they say overcome previous objections to such hybrid solutions. Recent Japanese experiments, Dr. Primack noted, provided "wonderful clues" suggesting that neutrinos could well have detectable mass and so could account for some of the missing mass required to add up to critical density.
In simulations by supercomputers, the models with neutrinos alone or cold dark matter alone failed to lead to the construction of a universe looking like it does today. Neutrinos are "hot," in that they zip about rapidly, and could not have coalesced soon enough to have helped form galaxies. Cold dark matter, moving slowly and clumping easily, would have produced too much galactic clustering.
Even mixing the two, usually with about one-third neutrinos and two-thirds cold dark matter, has not passed computer-simulation tests; the hybrids still produce galaxies later in cosmic history than recent observations suggest. Some such mixed dark matter could finally pass the test, but many scientists are uncomfortable with such recipes, which smack of being cooked just for the purpose of crawling out of an observational and theoretical hole.
One of the most encouraging developments, astronomers say, is the growing conviction that neutrinos do have a finite mass. But will the mass be sufficient to account for a major fraction of dark matter?
Astronomers have not given up on finding more ordinary matter that could be part of the dark matter. They continue to search for low-mass stars, Jupiter-size planets and other faint objects, which they think may be littering the outer edges of galaxies. They are taking a closer look at the possibility that lower-mass black holes could play a more significant role in cosmic mass than had been thought.
"If nothing works and omega is not very close to one," Dr. Hogan said, "then we've got to find some way out."
That raises once again the issue of the cosmological constant, a concept invented by Albert Einstein in 1917 and later rejected by him as his "greatest blunder." The idea assumes that energy in empty space might serve as a brake on cosmic expansion. If the value of the constant is reasonably low, scientists point out, it could make up the difference between the observed density of matter in the universe and the critical density so devoutly sought.
Physicists, in this their hour of need, have been re-examining the cosmological constant, finding no known principle that forbids it. Still, it makes them uneasy to be introducing such fudge factors. It reminds scientists too much of the practice of medieval astronomers to correct their Earth-centered view of the solar system by devising more and more complicated celestial mechanisms to explain the motions of planets and preserve conventional wisdom according to Ptolemy, the second-century astronomer.
The turmoil of clashing concepts and the continuing failure to find what most of the universe is made of might be cause for some to question science's faith in the optimistic assumption, first espoused by the ancient Greeks, that the universe is comprehensible. The Greek word for universe became cosmos, meaning order.
But cosmologists insist there is no reason to despair. "It's not frustrating," Dr. Ostriker said of the seemingly intractable problem of dark matter. "It's exciting."
With the greater capacities of telescopes and other instruments, Dr. Bahcall said, "our theories are being asked to fit so much more data than 25 years ago." It is a good sign, he added, "that our simplest models are being stretched and strained -- it means we're going to have new ideas."
The Greeks said the universe was comprehensible; they did not say it was simple.

MASSIVE COMPACT HALO OBJECTS
 Very faint low-mass stars and planet-size objects (known as Jupiters) made of ordinary baryonic matter (protons and neutrons).
 Found in halos of matter surrounding galaxies, or in clusters of dust and gas coasting through intergalactic voids.
 Baryonic matter should be detectable by existing means. Limited sightings suggest this type of dark matter accounts for no more than 10 percent of the Universe's "missing mass."
 
Black holes
 Collapsed remains of massive stars. Gravitational force so great that no light can escape. Optically invisible but detectable by gravitational influence on nearby matter.
 
EXOTIC

HOT: Fast-moving
 
Neutrinos
 Electrically neutral subatomic particles produced prolifically in theBig Bang. Ultra-smallj in mass, perhaps as small as a trillionth oif a proton. Traveling at about the speed of light, they are found just about everywhere, inconcentrations of about 500 per cubic centimeter.
 
COLD: Slow-moving
 
Wimps
WEAKLY INTERACTING MASSIVE PARTICLES
 Believed to exist, but never "seen"; they interact so weakly with matter that their mass has not been measured. Theoretically, they move at a slow pace and exist in very high concentrations - hundreds per cubic centimeter - and may account for a substantial chunk of the universe's mass, if they are ever shown to have a mass of their own.
 
Axions
 Wispy, superlight particles; slow-moving and highly concentrated (400 per cubic centimeter.) Very tiny mass, but measureable; plentiful enough to contribute significantly to the missing mass.

HEADLINE: Redefining Diversity: Biologists Urge Look Beyond Rain Forests

BYLINE: By NATALIE ANGIER 

 BODY:
BETWEEN the ever-lengthening menu of Rain Forest Crunch snack foods, the Rain Forest Action Network booths at rock concerts and street fairs, and the ubiquitous jungle-themed coffee mugs, T-shirts, place mats, tote bags, wall clocks, umbrellas and jewelry, the American public has been saturated with the message that tropical rain forests are among the greatest and most endangered of the world's natural wonders.
As the generic eco-lecture has it, tropical rain forests like the Amazon shelter enormous numbers of species, bristling with a variety of life forms so rich that science has barely begun to tally up the multitudes. Tens of millions of species of plants, insects, fungi, amphibians, lizards, fish, snails and more remain to be discovered in the Edenic bosom of the tropical rain forests, and yet the forests are being turned into so much kindling and cow pasture before anybody has had a chance to know what is out there. 
 Environmental activists have succeeded in adding the term biodiversity to the common lexicon, and it has been identified above all with the tropical rain forests. Save the rain forests, the reasoning goes, and you will save a bigger proportion of the earth's biological offerings than if you preserved any other habitat or stretch of terrain. As a result of such arguments, the tropical rain forests receive a leopard's share of conservation dollars.
Now, however, a growing number of ecologists and biologists are suggesting that there are other ways of calculating biodiversity than through a simple species score card. They argue that many of the species in rain forests are closely related to each other and hence not as indicative of true diversity as it appears on first blush. By their reckoning, ecosystems like deserts, temperate forests or high-altitude grasslands may house comparatively fewer species but offer more genera, families or phyla -- broader categories for grouping organisms. And in the end, a habitat with more families or phyla may be a locale of greater genetic diversity than the tropical rain forests in all their chlorophyllic, speciated abundance.
"The lowland, wet tropical forests have held sway as the dominant prom queen of biodiversity," said Dr. Kent Redford, who is in charge of Latin American scientific studies for the Nature Conservancy, an environmental group based in Arlington, Va. "But levels of genera, families and orders as measures of genetic information are better represented in habitats outside rain forests." He rephrases the ecologists' familiar dictum "the imperative of the tropical rain forests" as "the tyranny of the tropical rain forests."
Dr. Melanie Stiassny, an expert in freshwater habitats and in taxonomy at the American Museum of Natural History in New York, said: "Scientists are obsessed with numbers. If you have a bigger number and more species, therefore it makes a place very important. Well, yeah, it does in one sense, but if you follow the numbers argument too strictly, you're going to talk about basically insects."
There are many ways, it turns out, to define diversity. Scientists suggest that a region might be considered biodiversified if the scenery and organismic composition changes dramatically from one spot to the next. By at least one estimate, the greatest changeover in species types from hectare to hectare occurs not in rain forests but in deserts.
Alternatively, the most precious biological diversity may be said to lie in places claiming the greatest number of evolutionarily ancient species. Dr. Stiassny cites as an example several small freshwater lakes in Madagascar that contain about 10 species of cichlid fish. These fish are thought to be the evolutionary link between the founder cichlid fish, the mother of the entire, wildly diverse family, and the thousands of cichlid species found worldwide today. "If we were to lose those 10 Madagascan species," she says, it would be far worse than "losing 10 from the mainland of Africa. The information they contain is qualitatively different." All species, she declared, "are not created equal."
In reassessing biodiversity, scientists are tossing out a few ecology verities. For example, old assumptions about an interlocking diversity are not necessarily correct: The fact that a region is diverse in beetles or orchids does not mean it offers up a farrago of birds and frogs. The greatest diversity of insects over all is found in lowland tropics, as is the diversity of small primates. But bees, spiders and reptiles are most diverse in dry regions, as are large mammals -- think of the African savanna. As a general rule, lower altitudes are more species-rich than higher ones, but birds and butterflies, in fact, become more various as one climbs from sea level; there is an enormous diversity in both groups along the eastern slopes of the Andes.
Another general rule, said Dr. Norman I. Platnick, a biodiversity expert at the American Museum of Natural History, is that the Southern Hemisphere is more biological wealthy over all than the Northern Hemisphere, largely because land there has been divided more times by changes in rivers, glacial flows and mountain growth, thereby subdividing populations of plants and animals and setting the stage for their speciation. In a given temperate region of the Southern Hemisphere, for example, there may be five times as many spider and termite species as in northern temperate zones.
The law of southern assets is far from immutable, however. In astudy published recently in the journal Evolutionary Ecology, Dr. Samuel M. Scheiner of Northern Illinois University in De Kalb and Dr. Jose M. Rey-Benayas of the Council for Scientific Research in Madrid, analyzed plant diversity at 94 locations from the Equator to the poles, the first study to consider the global-scale diversity of any group of organisms. They learned that plant diversity is just as rich in the north as it is at an equivalent latitude in the south.
They also found that one of the most critical factors determining the concentration of diversity is seasonality. While plant diversity in tropical rain forests is high, owing to the abundance of moisture, heat and light, it also turns out to be surprisingly high in temperate places. Dr. Scheiner proposes that variations in temperature promote specialization among plants, with some blooming early in the spring, others arriving in summer and still others making their appearance in early fall, when competition has dropped off a bit.
The scientists who are discussing new methods of calculating what constitutes biodiversity in no way advocate a neglect of the tropical rain forests. They emphasize that tropical rain forests possess many unique features, among them an exceptional degree of so-called mutualism, in which a particular species of, say, wasp and a particular species of fig tree are entirely dependent on each other for survival; this sort of intercontingency is thought to have evolved as a result of the relatively constant conditions in the tropics. Nevertheless, scientists are asking for a greater balance and more equitable distribution of the meager conservation dollars available. They ask that closer attention be paid to the biological complexity of ecosystems that may not have the cachet or exotic allure of the jungle.
For example, Dr. Redford said that the Gran Chaco of South America, a mostly arid lowland plains region spanning about 400,000 square miles across Paraguay, Bolivia and Argentina, is the second largest ecosystem in Latin America, after the Amazon. "It's disappearing at a much faster rate than the Amazon, but there's been virtually no international attention paid to it, and most people have never heard of it," he said.
Recently, the advocates of a big tent approach to conservation captured the attention of the United States Agency for International Development, which invests about $100 million a year in biodiversity programs around the world. Over the last several years, much of that money has been spent on regions with the greatest number of species, which means the tropical rain forests. But at a workshop held last month in Miami, the agency asked conservationists to figure out how best to "diversify the biodiversity portfolio," as one participant put it.
The conferees focused on Latin America and the Caribbean, said Glenn T. Prickett, chief environmental adviser for the agency. These are regions where biological diversity is thought to be high and yet, given recent Federal budget constraints and an emphasis on regions considered more politically important, like Russia, Europe and Africa, the overall American Government investment in conservation projects there is relatively constrained -- hence the need for the best diversity deal for the dime.
In all the new thinking about biodiversity, ecologists acknowledge several uncomfortable truths. One is that not all species are going to make it. "We have to admit that there's a state of triage, and that we have to pick and choose where to focus our energies," said Dr. Stiassny.
In dealing with questions of biological diversity, ecologists and biologists must also confront their staggering ignorance. They know only a tiny percentage of what exists in nature. Dr. Russell Mittermeier of Conservation International in Washington points out that 1.4 million species have been described, and by current estimates there may be at least 100 million species of organisms alive. Scientists also confess that they lack the hard evidence they covet to persuade the world that preserving biological diversity is necessary for the good of the species people care most about: themselves. Arguments that species and biological diversity should be preserved for their own sake are not sufficient to counter claims of human primacy, lost jobs or hamstrung development. Dr. Thomas Eisner of Cornell University in Ithaca, N.Y., has pressed consistently for the importance of conserving biodiversity to conserve nature's chemical factory and pharmacopeia.
But for all their benightedness, scientists are beginning to piece together a portrait of what constitutes biological diversity and how to think about keeping it around for posterity. Dr. Jonathan Coddington, an entomologist who specializes in biodiversity at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, said that while science knows little about individual species, it has identified nearly all the major families of living organisms, about 7,000 in all. (The family that includes humans, for example, is Hominidae, of which Homo sapiens is the only surviving species). He suggests that if efforts focus on preserving at least a few members of all extant families, then a great deal of the earth's genetic diversity would end up aboard the conservation ark.
In the end, the conservation of biological diversity will depend not so much on scientific or academic considerations as on political, social and economic variables that move to their own whims and rhythms. The preliminary guidelines emerging from the Miami meeting said that apart from biological calculations of a particular landscape's diversity, the United States Agency for International Development must consider such factors as whether a nation is willing and able to make the effort to conserve its biodiversity.
The United States' own record on this score is not quite exemplary. Scientists may be gathering tantalizing evidence that places like the Great Lakes, the Appalachians, the Pacific Northwest and elsewhere are bursting with vast and taxonomically disparate natural assets. But a proposed effort to assess that wealth, called the National Biological Survey, is now bogged down in the Senate, with no sign of passage any time soon.

HEADLINE: CHRONICLE

BYLINE: By NADINE BROZAN 

 BODY:
Ever wonder if people give those dinners, cocktail parties and other festive events that they buy at auctions for worthy causes?
CAROLEE FRIEDLANDER, founder and president of a jewelry firm, was the high bidder for a tea party at the Washington home of the French Ambassador, at an auction more than a year ago. Never able to actually give the tea, which was auctioned to benefit the Vincent T. Lombardi Cancer Center at Georgetown University, she passed it on as a gift to her friend ADRIENNE ARSHT, a banker in Washington. 
 "This is the gift that keeps on giving," Ms. Arsht said yesterday, and explained that she had asked guests at the tea, to be held tomorrow, to bring Hanukkah gifts for children in Russian refugee families.
Among those who plan to attend are Tunky Riley, wife of Richard W. Riley, the Secretary of Education; Bess Abell, a former White House social secretary, and Ann McLaughlin, former Secretary of Labor.
Ms. Arsht also invited Tony Williams, whom she described as "the hot weekend weatherman on Channel 9," and Erik Tarloff, a screenwriter who is married to Laura D'Andrea Tyson, head of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. Ms. Tyson is not coming, Ms. Arsht said, because "I try not to invite couples."
She did, however, invite her own husband, Myer Feldman, who was a White House counsel to Presidents Kennedy and Johnson, but he will be out of town.

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 730 words

HEADLINE: For Freer Trade -- and Better Jobs

 BODY:
Senator Bob Dole, who once threatened to bury the global trade agreement signed by 124 nations, has now put America's interests first. He has signed onto the accord after extracting innocent side agreements from the White House. Mr. Dole, whose threats were harshly criticized on this page, deserves full credit for rising above politics to rescue an agreement fashioned over seven years of tortured negotiations. His leadership has made it likely, barring last-minute defections by Democrats, that the Senate will approve the agreement on Thursday after the House does so today. Countries around the world will quickly follow suit.
Though Mr. Dole's approval removed much of the drama, the importance of the votes should not be overlooked. The trade accord will deliver a shot of economic adrenaline that few other government policies can match. By some estimates, it will raise living standards in the U.S. by $1,000 or more per family. Rejection of GATT would not only squander these gains, but would also prove diplomatically calamitous. 
 For 50 years the world has looked to the U.S. to lead it through a series of trade-opening agreements that have knocked down tariffs and other trade barriers. The measures have contributed mightily to worldwide growth. Had GATT's opponents won over Congress, the U.S. would have abandoned its leadership role and inflamed protectionist pressures abroad, eventually threatening living standards everywhere.
Like previous agreements, the latest GATT accord will also remove tariffs and other trade barriers. Unlike past agreements, it will cover agriculture and many services and insure that countries honor copyrights, patents and trademarks. It will also create the World Trade Organization, which, as Congress demanded in the 1980's, will impose tougher procedures to resolve disputes. All this amounts to a big victory for American exporters of everything from corn and pharmaceuticals to computer software and legal services. Most developing countries also win. Their exports will gain access to industrialized countries, and the World Trade Organization will protect them from any bullying tactics of wealthier trade partners.
An odd coalition of conservative Republicans and Democrats allied with consumer advocates like Ralph Nader oppose GATT. They make three arguments, none frivolous but none sufficiently important to turn down the accord.
First, critics say the W.T.O. threatens U.S. sovereignty because it can rule that U.S. environmental and safety laws are forms of backdoor protectionism. In one sense, the criticism has to be true: any agreement with other nations necessarily restricts U.S. action. But the danger is grossly exaggerated. GATT panels can rule against U.S. laws even under existing rules. These rules would survive even if the new accord were defeated.
There is one difference. Under existing rules the U.S. can veto an adverse ruling; under the new accord it cannot. But in practice this is a minor distinction. Even though countries can now retaliate against the U.S. for such a veto, most do not do so out of fear that the U.S. would retaliate in turn. That is likely to be the case under the new GATT; in that sense, the accord poses no new threat. Indeed, it includes language that protects U.S. environmental and safety laws that are based on scientific principles and are not deliberately aimed at blocking imports.
Second, critics object to GATT's secret deliberations and skimpy legal protections. They have a point, but again, current dispute panels proceed under even worse rules so nothing important is lost. Finally, critics like Ernest Hollings of South Carolina are understandably upset that textile manufacturers in their states would be subjected to low-cost foreign imports. But that is a reasonable price for the country to pay to rack up huge gains nearly everywhere else.
Proponents and critics alike tend to misstate GATT's impact on jobs. Trade neither creates nor destroys jobs. Employment in the U.S. is primarily determined by the Federal Reserve Board' s efforts to push the economy as close to full employment as possible. What open trade does is steer workers into export industries, which on average pay high wages. That is what the votes this week are all about. Barring catastrophe, the U.S. will once again launch the world on another wave of growth.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1148 words

HEADLINE: THE LAME-DUCK CONGRESS: THE VOTE;
HOUSE APPROVES TRADE AGREEMENT BY A WIDE MARGIN

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29

 BODY:
The House of Representatives tonight overwhelmingly approved American participation in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the most ambitious world trade accord put forth in more than two generations.
The issue now moves to the Senate, where its fate in a vote on Thursday is still uncertain. 
 After five hours of frequently heated debate, the House passed the accord 288 to 146.
The agreement would slash tariffs by a third and subject American laws -- from worker safety regulations to environmental controls -- to review by a new international trade court, the World Trade Organization.
House passage today moved the Clinton Administration closer to a crucial legislative success at a time when it is eager to prove that it will be able to work with the Republican majority in both houses of the 104th Congress.
It was also a bipartisan endorsement of one of the key underpinnings of President Clinton's economic strategy: that free trade with all of the country's trading partners, even low-wage, developing countries whose laborers make less than a dollar an hour, will ultimately enrich American workers even if it costs jobs in some noncompetitive American industries.
But many Democrats abandoned the Administration, contending that 40 years of free-trade agreements, including the North American Free Trade Agreement, which squeaked through Congress last year, were costing their constituents jobs and resulting in lower salaries for blue-collar workers.
Today's vote was the first of a lame-duck session called after a Democratic Senator, Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina, blocked passage of the trade agreement earlier this fall.
Senate leaders said they were still uncertain whether the accord, the eighth expansion of GATT since 1948, would pass. But the margin of victory in the House -- where Republicans voted for GATT 121 to 56, Democrats favored it 167 to 89 and 1 independent voted against -- seemed bound to work in the Administration's favor. Because the bill would add to the national deficit, at least 60 votes will be needed under Senate rules.
Aides to President Clinton said they expected to win a narrow victory in the Senate, but they were taking no chances. Tonight, they were assembling a list of about two dozen wavering senators from both parties who were to be invited to breakfast at the White House on Thursday morning for one last dose of cajoling from Mr. Clinton and the Senate's Democratic and Republican leaders.
Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the outgoing Democratic leader, and Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican who will soon become majority leader, were expected to join the President in making final appeals to the assembled senators, White House officials said.
In an effort to sustain the sense of momentum behind the trade accord, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen and Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, will hold a news conference on Capitol Hill on Wednesday at which Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, and Senator Barbara Boxer, Democrat of California, will declare their support for the agreement.
Negotiations on the accord that passed today began under the Reagan Administration, and the Clinton Administration found itself leaning on Republicans to assure its passage. That support came at a cost. Republican leaders repeatedly made it clear that the White House owed its GATT victory to them, and particularly to Senator Dole, who endorsed the treaty after striking a deal with President Clinton just before Thanksgiving that seemed designed largely to demonstrate what kind of power Mr. Dole now wields.
"While a few members are concerned about giving President Clinton a victory," Representative David Dreier, a California Republican, said before the vote, "we're going to do that because President Clinton is right on this issue."
Proponents of the bill argued that with the end of the cold war, the United States had to take the lead on free trade to maintain its influence abroad. "This is perhaps one of the most important decisions to be made in the latter half of the 20th century," said Representative Sam M. Gibbons of Florida, a Democrat who is the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee.
"We should not isolate ourselves from the rest of the world," he said. "We did that in the 1930's." He was alluding to the Smoot-Hawley legislation, which began an era of isolationism before the outbreak of World War II -- "with disastrous results," Mr. Gibbons said.
But the opposition cast history differently. Representative Marcy Kaptur, an Ohio Democrat, argued that 47 years of past incarnations of GATT had hardly enriched Americans workers. "Real wages for America's workers have gone down," she said. "You don't have to be a mental giant to figure out that there is a relationship between declining living standards for our workers and our families, and our massive trade deficits."
This year, that trade deficit is expected to top $150 billion, including a $60 billion shortfall with Japan.
If passed by the Senate, and then by more than 100 nations that have been awaiting Washington's action, GATT will dramatically lower tariffs and expand basic trade protection to intellectual property, including movies, computer software and copyrights. It would slowly bring an end to national subsidies for many industries. President Clinton has argued that the result will be a "massive worldwide tax cut" that will lower the price of imported goods and of the domestically produced goods that compete with them.
It was clear from the debate today, however, that even supporters of the accord have only the vaguest views of what it would mean for the nation's economy. While most experts agree that world income would rise because of the liberalization of trade, the estimates vary from a low of $100 billion a year to more than $500 billion by 2005. Advocates of the accord say the American economy would expand by $122 billion a year because GATT would lower barriers for American exports, but opponents call those figures wildly inflated.
Moreover, the vision of an ever-increasing pie has been attacked by environmentalists, consumer advocates and others who argue that the new agreement places trade above all other values, including minimum worker standards and environmental protection.
Both Democrats and Republicans rose to attack Mr. Clinton's premise that, by opening new markets, free trade would create more jobs than it would cost in increased imports.
The pro-GATT voices today focused not on economics, but on the more fundamental objection put forth by opponents: that the new World Trade Organization would become the tool of scores of developing nations. Those nations, opponents argue, would take advantage of their overwhelming numbers in the one-country, one-vote organization to force changes in American law.

HEADLINE: Traders Seek Direction As Stocks Close Mixed

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The stock market, after rising for two days, closed mixed but essentially unchanged yesterday, as long-bond yields again climbed past 8 percent. The real test for equities will likely come today with the release of third-quarter gross domestic product figures that may confirm or dispel traders' fears of an overheating economy.
As in Monday's trading, the number of advancing stocks -- 1,155 -- almost equaled the number of decliners -- 1,075. The narrow division underscores traders' indecision about the direction of the market. But 107 stocks established new lows and only 11 set new highs. 
Yesterday was another seesaw session. The Dow rose a few points in the first half-hour of trading but then suddenly dropped 25 points in the next half-hour or so. In all, the Dow reversed field four times in the day.
The big news was the 10 A.M. release by the Conference Board, a private business research group, of its November consumer confidence survey. The group's index reading of 101.3, up an unexpectedly high 12.2 points, was the biggest one-month gain in more than two years and the highest reading in more than four years. The survey sent bond prices plunging, and the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose to 8.03 percent from 7.98 percent.
The surge in consumer confidence dovetailed with strong retail sales over the weekend and confirmed many traders' concerns that the economy was overheating enough to produce inflation.
The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 1.01 points, to 3,738.55 yesterday, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 rose 1.01 points, to 455.17. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index, rich in high-technology stocks that have fallen in price recently, rose 5.75 points, to 751.48.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was roughly normal, with 286.6 million shares changing hands, or slightly less than this year's average of 289 million shares.
But the bigger news today will be the Commerce Department's second of three estimates for third-quarter gross domestic product. Private economists expect it to show a slight increase to 3.5 percent from the initial estimate of 3.4 percent. That compares with 4.1 percent in the second quarter. Such revisions are closely watched by traders for clues to future inflation.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.44 point, to 248.90, and the American Stock Exchange market value index fell 0.50 point, to 433.09.
Among stock groups, long-distance telephone carriers saw their shares fall enough to set new 52-week lows for a second straight day.
The MCI Communications Corporation was the day's most active stock, with 20.6 million shares changing hands in Nasdaq trading. MCI's share price fell as low as 1813/16 , before closing at 19, down 1 1/2. An analyst at Merrill Lynch and Company said MCI's market-share growth was falling slightly. In Monday intraday trading, MCI set its previous 52-week low of 20 1/4.
Shares of the AT&T Corporation dropped to 48 3/8, a new low, before closing at 49 1/8, down 3/8. On Monday, the shares fell to 48 3/4, the previous 52-week low. The Sprint Corporation fell to 29 3/4, a new low, before closing at 30, down 5/8. On Nov. 21, Sprint established its previous 52-week low of 30 1/4.
Eleven of the Dow industrials' 30 component stocks fell, led by Caterpillar Inc., which lost 3/4, to 53 1/4. Of the S.& P. 500 component stocks, 257 rose, led by Northern Telecom Ltd., a maker of telecommunications equipment whose shares gained 1/8, to 32 5/8.

HEADLINE: Cordially if Not Enthusiastically, Mayor and Governor-Elect Meet

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
After all the bitterness and political comedy of manners, George E. Pataki and Rudolph W. Giuliani met for the first time yesterday as governor-elect and mayor, offering a display of cordiality, if not a heartfelt pledge to make up and be friends.
Exactly three weeks after Election Day, the Mayor and the Governor-elect, both Republicans but otherwise at odds since Mr. Giuliani crossed party lines to endorse Mario M. Cuomo, emerged from their meeting promising to put campaign nastiness behind them and work together for New York City and State. 
 And yet, despite the niceties couched in the measured language of diplomats, there were indications that the coolness between them would not go away in a day. Appearing together before reporters for only a few moments, they were asked if the meeting signaled the start of "a warm relationship." Mr. Pataki sidestepped gingerly as Mr. Giuliani stood silently beside him.
"We will work together professionally in the interests of the people of this city and state," said the Governor-elect, who, people close to him said, approached the meeting with a residue of disdain for the Mayor.
The two men met for 70 minutes over breakfast at the Union League Club, the elite bastion of Republican business leaders in midtown Manhattan. They were accompanied only by their senior aides, Deputy Mayor Peter J. Powers and Michael C. Finnegan, who was named yesterday as counsel to Mr. Pataki in the Governor-elect's first administrative appointment. [Page B2.]
As the meeting ended, Mr. Pataki and Mr. Giuliani also met alone for a few minutes for a private discussion, the contents of which were not disclosed.
Speaking to reporters outside the club, Mr. Pataki and Mr. Giuliani said they had a substantive talk on several topics, including the Governor-elect's proposed tax cuts; pending legislation in Albany; the economy; the city's watershed; prisons, and Yankee Stadium.
Almost everything came up, it seemed, except Mr. Giuliani's pointed campaign attacks on Mr. Pataki and Mr. Pataki's subsequent refusal to return Mr. Giuliani's congratulatory telephone calls or, until yesterday, to meet with him one on one.
"The election is over," said Mr. Giuliani, who the day before had refused to attend a meeting that Mr. Pataki had with eight of the city's other elected officials, saying the meeting was an attempt to diminish his standing and that of the mayoralty. "We both have very, very big responsibilities."
Mr. Giuliani also finally had the chance to offer Mr. Pataki the congratulations the Governor-elect had seemed unwilling to accept over the phone after the campaign. "I wished him the very best of luck," he said, "and told him we wanted to work very, very closely with to accomplish his objectives."
The two men went to great lengths to keep their meeting time and place secret, the better, they said, to have a serious discussion and avoid the press. An initial plan to meet at the Yale Club was scrapped on Monday night after reporters learned of it, aides said, and rescheduled for 8 A.M. at the Union League Club, at East 37th Street and Park Avenue.
Mr. Giuliani had said he wanted to avoid a media circus, but the result of all of the secrecy was, naturally, a media circus. A gaggle of reporters gathered outside Gracie Mansion around dawn to stake out the Mayor. When his motorcade emerged before 8 A.M., the six vehicles split up and went in different directions, leaving the press corps, including a photographer who chased on a motorcycle, scrambling to keep up. At one point, the motorcade sped past the car of Mr. Pataki, who was on the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Drive on his way to the meeting.
The Mayor's press secretary, Cristyne F. Lategano, said that the departure from Gracie Mansion was not diversionary, but that the Mayor's children had simply left for school at the same time. She also said the Mayor's driver did not run any red lights but that his aides took down the license plate numbers of the reporters who did. "For once," she said, "the press will contribute to reducing the deficit."
Once inside the Union League, Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Powers met Mr. Pataki and Mr. Finnegan in the Seward Room, sitting at a round wooden table beneath a chandelier for what those on each side described as a businesslike discussion of issues.
During the campaign, Mr. Giuliani had complained that he could never talk to Mr. Pataki without aides to Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Mr. Pataki's patron, being in the room. Mr. Finnegan, however, is a longtime friend and associate of Mr. Pataki with no special link to Mr. D'Amato. His role has been not unlike that of Mr. Powers for Mr. Giuliani; in fact, Mr. Finnegan and Mr. Powers established the first lines of communication and set up yesterday's meeting, the final location of which was suggested by Mr. Pataki's camp.
In a sign of how time can change all in politics, it was not the first meeting ever between Mr. Pataki and Mr. Giuliani. The two had met in 1990, when the state Republican Party sent Mr. Pataki as an emissary to ask Mr. Giuliani to consider running for Governor against Mr. Cuomo.
Mr. Powers said that yesterday, the two men seemed to want to establish a professional rapprochement, and that neither brought up the Mayor's endorsement of Mr. Cuomo or the campaign attacks on Mr. Pataki. "George Pataki wants to be a great Governor," Mr. Powers said. "And Rudy feels the same way about being Mayor. They want to work together to achieve those ends."
The meeting came as some in Mr. Pataki's camp sensed that the flurry of attention surrounding the dispute with the Mayor was a distraction at a time Mr. Pataki faces the enormous task of putting together a government long controlled by Democrats.
Afterward, Mr. Pataki said he and the Mayor were "on the same wavelength" on many issues. Presumably those issues included two pieces of legislation they have agreed to oppose together in Albany: one that would increase pension payments to public employees and another that would prevent large cities from using state education aid to fill budget shortfalls.
Mr. Pataki offered warm words for New Yorkers, who overwhelmingly supported Mr. Cuomo, even as he appeared to signal to his upstate supporters that nothing to which he agreed would favor the city alone. "Working with the Mayor, working with the people of the city in the best interests of all the people of this state, is what we will do," he said.
He left after a few moments, and the Mayor described the issues covered. Mr. Giuliani also said he told Mr. Pataki, who is considering reducing the state's work force, about the city's severance programs, which so far have cut 11,000 jobs from a payroll of 216,000 without having to resort to layoffs.
"There are a lot of areas of agreement, and in essence we've done a number of the things that he is going to be about doing," he said. "I offered our help in any way that we could help, either with the things that were successful for us, or the things that didn't work as well."
Mr. Pataki, joined by his wife, Elizabeth, and the Assembly minority leader, Clarence D. Rappleyea Jr., a member of his transition team, later met for lunch with John Cardinal O'Connor, the leader of the Archdiocese of New York. A spokesman for the Cardinal, Joseph G. Zwilling, said the discussion was informal and private.

HEADLINE: Comptroller Backs Council In Budget Fight With Mayor

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS 

 BODY:
City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi sided yesterday with the City Council in its legal battle with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, saying he believed the Council had the power to pass its own version of budget changes intended to keep the city's spending plan in balance.
But with the Council poised to override Mr. Giuliani's veto of its spending plan, Mr. Hevesi questioned some of the Council's proposed cuts and urged the two sides to compromise rather than let the courts resolve their impasse. 
 "I'm not saying that the Council's action is good or bad policy," Mr. Hevesi said between meetings with the Mayor and after briefing the Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone. "I'm certifying that it is legal.
"I got the clear sense that both are willing to resolve this, but there is a positioning that has to play out."
Yesterday, it was the Comptroller's turn to position himself on the budget dance floor. He chose Mr. Vallone, his fellow Democrat, as his partner but also conspicuously stepped on the Council's toes by warning that the economies it proposed as an alternative to the Mayor's could be too risky, to the tune of $55 million.
Abraham M. Lackman, the city's Budget Director, expressed hope last night that the Council would postpone the scheduled override vote and instead offer alternatives that both Mr. Hevesi and Mr. Giuliani could embrace.
Without such alternatives, the Mayor sounded disinclined to budge. He said he reserved the right to impound spending approved by the Council without the revenue to pay for it, and he again argued that the City Charter provision from 1975 invoked by the Council does not apply.
"If you are a comptroller and not a politician, you don't entertain irresponsible legal arguments that could lead to fiscal chaos," Mr. Giuliani said. "Why wouldn't I resist an action by the City Council that adds $55 million more to the budget?"
Mr. Hevesi seemed to suggest that after the Council vented its anger at Mr. Giuliani, the two sides would find common ground, rather than engage in a protracted legal and political showdown.
Otherwise, he warned, possible confusion over who is empowered to spend what could degenerate from a problem into a crisis that could imperil the city's credit rating, cost it more to borrow money and even trigger the re-emergence of the state Financial Control Board as the arbiter of city budget making.
Mr. Hevesi and others said that any crisis was still weeks or months away, though, a judgment shared by Richard P. Larkin, managing director of the Standard & Poor's bond rating agency.
"If there's a real impasse, that could be cause for concern, but that's not what I think is happening here," Mr. Larkin said.
For more than a month, the Mayor and Council have been wrangling over how to bridge a projected $1.1 billion gap in the $31 billion budget for the current fiscal year, which ends June 30. Last week, the Council overwhelmingly rejected the Mayor's budget changes, then approved its own by a veto-proof margin. Mr. Giuliani vetoed the Council's version.
Yesterday, Mr. Hevesi maintained that because the Mayor's changes included an increase in projected revenue, the Council votes were legally valid under the City Charter. To be legally certified, a budget requires the signatures of the Mayor, the Comptroller and the City Clerk, who works for the Council.

HEADLINE: Apache To Buy Fields From Texaco

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
Texaco Inc. agreed yesterday to sell some 300 domestic oil and gas fields to the Apache Corporation for about $600 million.
The sale would be one of the largest transactions in a trend that has been sweeping the oil industry in recent years. Major oil companies have been increasing their attention abroad, investing billions of dollars in such areas as Russia and China, while leaving domestic fields to smaller and more nimble independent oil companies like Apache. 
 The smaller companies have been adept at wringing more production and profit out of the older fields, and when Texaco put the fields up for sale in July, Raymond Plank, Apache's chairman, said the fields would be a "laudable transaction for Apache to be involved in," Bloomberg Business News reported. He said yesterday that the properties "can be incorporated quickly into existing operations and will provide economies of scale."
The fields, scattered throughout 15 states, contain the equivalent of more than 100 million barrels of oil, according to Texaco, which said the fields contributed no profits and less than 10 percent of the cash flow it earned from American properties. Apache said they would increase its reserves, which are at about 270 million barrels of oil, by 44 percent.
Clarence P. Cazalot Jr., president of Texaco Exploration and Production, said that "the proceeds from this sale will be redeployed into growth opportunities across the company, including major expenditures on core producing properties in the U.S."
The large oil companies consider many domestic fields less economical to run, particularly with oil prices at $17 to $18 a barrel. But the independents see the fields as opportunities to increase their reserves and production vastly.
"We can run with fewer people and be more efficient," G. Steven Farris, senior vice president of domestic exploration and production for Apache, said in a recent interview.
He also said that the majors had to look for bigger targets in seeking to replace their reserves and were at a disadvantage managing widely scattered fields in the United States.
Texaco said that the sale was expected to be completed in the first quarter of 1995.
The fields are located primarily in producing regions where Apache has existing operations -- the Permian Basin, the Gulf Coast of Texas and Louisiana, western Oklahoma, East Texas, the Rocky Mountains and the Gulf of Mexico. Current average daily production from the properties is approximately 21,000 barrels of oil and 90 million cubic feet of natural gas. Apache will operate some 68 percent of the production and hold an average 70-percent working interest in the operated properties.
Texaco also said that because of low oil prices it would eliminate 2,500 jobs representing 7.7 percent of its worldwide workforce, and it also plans to sell properties in California and North Dakota in addition to those that that Apache plans to buy.
The transaction, which was announced after the close of the stock market, is subject to a definitive agreement, and to the approval of both companies' boards.
Texaco closed on the New York Stock Exchange at $62, unchanged; Apache ended on the Big Board at $25.125, down 12.5 cents.
