HEADLINE: Confidence Index Has a Surge

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
One of the nation's two major consumer confidence indexes, which are intended to measure the optimism of Americans about their own financial situations, shot up in November to the highest level in more than four years.
The sudden surge in the index compiled by the Conference Board, to 101.3 from 89.1, might be an aberration. But many pollsters and economists agreed on one point: Even without November's jump, the index shows that Americans feel better today about their circumstances than they did in 1993. And they are not bracing for a recession -- although they might be expecting a slowdown next year. 
 The generally optimistic Conference Board report issued yesterday helped to send bond market prices lower and push the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond back over 8 percent. [Page D5.].
"You would not want to get too wound up in trying to explain this one-month blip in the Conference Board's index," said John Lipsky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers. "But in broad terms, the two major consumer confidence indexes reflect optimism about job growth and income gains."
This sort of optimism often develops in the late stages of an economic recovery, and the current one will be four years old in March. The real issue raised by the indexes is whether the recovery is past its peak. The Conference Board index suggests that the best days might still be ahead, while the index compiled by the University of Michigan's Institute of Consumer Surveys suggests that the peak came last winter, although the economy is still quite strong.
"The current level of confidence foretells an expanding economy in the immediate period ahead," the Conference Board said.
The Michigan pollsters do not share that view. "We reached what we think was the peak of the recovery in January, and it has really been quite flat since then," said Richard T. Curtin, director of the Michigan surveys.
The Michigan index hit 94.3 in January and was at 91.6 in November, having settled at that level during the summer. The Conference Board's index, on the other hand, rose to 92.5 in June and then slowly fell, until this surprising jump.
The Republican election victory does not explain the surge, said Fabian Linden, director of the monthly survey by the Conference Board, an organization supported by corporations. Most of the nearly 4,000 replies to a mailed questionnaire were completed before the election.
Whatever the case, the indexes are saying that jobs are easier to find and more likely to last than was the case a year ago, and a low inflation rate has not eroded the small wage gains that have been achieved. In addition, rising interest rates -- the Federal Reserve has raised rates six times this year -- have not yet inhibited consumer borrowing.
These conclusions are evident, economists and pollsters say, in the responses to the questions that the Conference Board asked in November about each respondent's current situation. Some 25.3 percent said their situation was good, compared with 20 percent in September and 22.4 percent in October. More than 50 percent reported no change.
As for jobs, 20.7 percent said in November that jobs were more plentiful, up from 15.8 percent in September and 16.1 percent in October. Again, more than 50 percent reported no change. The Michigan survey's findings for the current situation are similarly strong.
What gets emphasized in such data is how people feel compared with a year or two ago. What gets lost is how they feel in the 1990's compared with their levels of optimism in earlier decades, when jobs were more secure, layoffs were far fewer and wages regularly rose faster than the inflation rate.
The Conference Board's index, at 101.3 in November, is at its high for the current recovery. But in the 1960's the reading went above 140 and it broke 120 in early 1989, before the beginning of an economic slowdown that produced the last recession. Even in July 1990, the first month of the last recession, the reading was 101.7, a figure that had not since been surpassed until yesterday's report.
"We once asked ourselves how much we could improve our standards of living," Mr. Curtin of the Michigan survey said, "and now we concern ourselves with avoiding problems and catastrophes. It is a different perspective."
The Conference Board's consumer confidence index is composed of two subindexes, one measuring the current situation and the other what the households surveyed think will happen over the next six months or so. The subindex about the current situation rose a spectacular 17.4 points in November, to 108.3, accounting for most of the rise in the overall index.
The subindex covering expectations went up only 8.8 points, to 96.7. In effect, the households surveyed were far more optimistic about their present situation than they were about their jobs and their incomes in the future.
The Michigan index is similarly constructed, and its two subindexes are behaving in roughly the same fashion as the Conference Board's, although the Michigan index rarely rises or falls in a single month by as much as the Conference Board's index. Some experts consider the Michigan index more reliable, and the Federal Government monitors it.
"The Conference Board's index is based on a weaker methodology and is more volatile than Michigan's, and my impression is that it is probably less accurate," said Thomas Smith, director of the University of Chicago's National Opinion Research Center. "The Conference Board's panel of households is not as representative of the nation as Michigan's."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Government Securities' Prices Fall

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The government securities market was clearly settled in a bearish pattern yesterday, as prices fell after a report showed that consumer confidence had surged to a four-year high.
But the decline was tempered by a move by the Federal Reserve to inject money into the banking system. As part of its regular operations, the Fed buys various notes and bonds, usually about $3 billion to $5 billion worth, for the purpose of tempering interest rates, particularly during the holiday season when money may be in tight supply. 
 Traders said the Fed was buying maturities beginning in 1995.
 Some market participants said many dealers were able to sell the Fed securities at fairly high prices, which would explain the prices in afternoon trading.
Although the Fed action supported prices yesterday, the rise in the Conference Board's confidence index should not be minimized in terms of its lasting impact on market psychology. James Hale, a fixed-income analyst for MMS International, said the coupon pass "was the only thing that prevented a massacre today."
The price of the 30-year Treasury fell 16/32 , to 942/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 8.03 percent from 7.98 percent, or about where the yield was a week ago.
The Conference Board, a New York research group, said yesterday that its index measuring Americans' confidence in the economy surged to 101.3 in November from 89.1 in October, the highest level in more than four years. The market had expected the index to be about 89.
The confidence report was very negative for the market because it suggested that higher interest rates were not slowing down the economy, increasing the prospects for accelerating inflation, which erodes the value of fixed-income investments like bonds. The Fed has raised short-term interest rates six times this year in an effort to keep a lid on inflation.
"The market has to be thinking that the Fed is coming at the end of January 1995 or sooner" to raise rates, said George R. Mateyo, chairman of the Carnegie Capital Management Company in Cleveland. He noted that it had been four to six years since consumer confidence has been over 100.
Comments by several Fed officials yesterday suggested that the Fed might soon act again.
The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, Cathy E. Minehan, who will become a voting member of the Fed's policy-making committee when it meets on Jan. 31, indicated in a speech in Randolph, Mass., that the Fed might not be finished raising rates. She noted the strong consumption data leading up to yesterday's report and near full employment.
And the vice chairman of the Fed, Alan S. Blinder, said at a conference in Jacsonville, Fla., that "the economy is looking extremely strong."
Today, the Government will release its third-quarter revision to the gross domestic product and will report on production and capacity utilization for November.
In the municipal market, Pennsylvania, in the largest sale expected this week, sold $290.6 million in general obligation bonds yesterday through competitive bidding won by J. P. Morgan Securities.
The bonds were priced to yield from 4.40 percent in 1995 to 6.30 percent in 2005. Some of the issue is insured by the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company and rated triple-A by the rating agencies, while the issues are rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and AA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Gains on Hints Of Another Increase in Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose broadly yesterday, bolstered by strong United States economic news and hints from a Federal Reserve official of further interest rate increases.
Traders said the dollar also benefited from some resilient weakness in the German mark, which fell after Norway's vote to reject membership in the European Union. 
 The dollar's recent strength has been seen as a sign by some currency brokers that the dollar may have snapped out of its prolonged slump. The rally yesterday was broadly based, and came amid declines in the United States stock and bond markets.
"There's a perception that the dollar might have seen its lows for the year," said Jerry Gleason, a foreign exchange trader at the New York branch of Banque Indosuez, a French banking company.
A catalyst for the dollar's strength was a report by the Conference Board, a New York business research group, that showed Americans' confidence in the economy surged in November to its highest level since July 1990.
"There's been a change in sentiment," said Jay Wertheimer, senior foreign exchange trader at the New York branch of Banco di Sicilia, an Italian bank. "We're just faced day after day with good fundamental economic news. I think this ghost of inflation that's scaring us seems to have subsided."
In trading in New York late yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.5703 German marks from 1.5670 marks on Monday. The dollar also rose to a six-week high of 99 yen in intraday trading, before settling at 98.97 yen, up from 98.67 yen on Monday.
Traders said remarks by the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan S. Blinder, in Jacksonville, Fla., also inspired some dollar buying.
Mr. Blinder hinted that the Fed might raise interest rates further, saying, "The economy is looking extremely strong." The Fed has increased short-term interest rates six times this year in an effort to slow the pace of inflation.
Rising interest rates, coupled with low inflation, can attract investors to dollar-denominated assets. Such a trend creates demand for dollars and raises their value in relation to other currencies.
"At some point, this has got to make the dollar more attractive," said Curtis Perkins, a foreign exchange trader at the New York branch of Chemical Bank.
In other currency trading, the dollar was unchanged at 1.3285 Swiss francs. The British pound was steady at $1.5625.

HEADLINE: Victor Seen In Santa Fe Bidding

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
The Union Pacific Corporation, once considered a long-shot spoiler in a bidding war to buy the Santa Fe Pacific Corporation, has emerged as the likely winner.
Union Pacific won a crucial agreement yesterday from Santa Fe officials to meet for the first time to share financial information and discuss terms of a merger of the railroad companies. 
 Santa Fe had been resisting such a meeting, saying that a lower offer of $3 billion from Burlington Northern Inc. was more attractive because it stood a better chance of being approved by Federal regulators than Union Pacific's $3.2 billion offer. But yesterday Santa Fe said it would meet with Union Pacific's advisers "in an effort to clarify and improve Union Pacific's offer."
 "In essence, Union Pacific has won," said James M. Higgins, an analyst at Brown Brothers Harriman. He said that unless Burlington Northern raised its bid or a glitch emerged in the talks with Santa Fe, Union Pacific appeared to have taken care of many of the main objections to its offer.
"This is a railroad that is trying very hard to answer the skeptics," Mr. Higgins said.
After Union Pacific made a surprise bid in October, some analysts did not give it much hope. Many said such a merger probably would not be approved by Federal regulators because the heavy overlap of routes between the two railroads would raise too many anticompetitive concerns. Many analysts have been saying that Union Pacific was just trying to break up a Santa Fe-Burlington Northern combination, which, if approved, would have surpassed Union Pacific as the largest railroad in the country.
But the Interstate Commerce Commission gave informal approval on Monday for Union Pacific to establish a voting trust, a crucial strategy intended to shift the uncertainty of the Federal approval process from Santa Fe shareholders to Union Pacific.
The takeover effort is by no means over. Santa Fe, for instance, said yesterday that it wanted Union Pacific to improve its offer. Santa Fe officials have previously said that Union Pacific executives made statements about a possible $20-a-share offer. Burlington Northern officials declined to comment yesterday, but last week they said that they would "stand pat" on their offer.
Santa Fe, based in Schaumburg, Ill., said yesterday that it was postponing a shareholder vote on Burlington Northern's offer by two weeks, to Dec. 16. Santa Fe said it wanted to give its board and stockholders more time to consider alternatives to the offer.
Union Pacific's two-part bid, which consists of $17.50 a share in cash for 57 percent of the company and the remainder in a stock swap, is taxable. Some analysts said Santa Fe might ask Union Pacific to structure the deal to be nontaxable, as is the offer from Burlington Northern.
Union Pacific, based in Bethlehem, Pa., has complained for weeks that it did not have the same access as Burlington Northern to confidential financial information about Santa Fe. Those numbers -- projected earnings and the like -- will help shape negotiations and determine whether it raises its bid, a Union Pacific official said.
By not raising its bid, Burlington Northern, based in Fort Worth, may be hoping that the Interstate Commerce Commission will ultimately rule against a Union Pacific-Santa Fe merger, said Steve Lewins, an analyst at Gruntal & Company.
If that occurs, Union Pacific might be forced to sell Santa Fe to Burlington Northern, giving Burlington Northern a chance to renegotiate its offer without having to compete against Union Pacific.
Their high-profile bidding war, played out in full-page newspaper ads recently, is the most visible evidence of the trend toward consolidation in the railroad industry.
After cutting costs through the 1980's, many railroads have been seeking to improve profitability through economies of scale. Shippers are also increasingly demanding efficient and timely service from railroads, which are also trying to expand their range of services by acquiring competitors.
Santa Fe's board also approved a shareholder rights plan yesterday that would entitle holders to buy stock at half price once a hostile buyer acquires 10 percent or more of Santa Fe. But if the board approves of the acquisition, then Santa Fe may redeem the rights at one cent each.
Santa Fe's shares rose 50 cents, to $16.875 yesterday. Union Pacific's climbed 75 cents, to $46.50, and Burlington Northern's stock rose $1, to $48. Stocks in all three railroad companies trade on the Big Board.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Selloff Fails to Shake Stock Fund Investors

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
American investors may be growing more nervous about their stock market investments, but they keep putting money into equity mutual funds. Even last week's sharp fall in stock prices produced only a relatively small amount of withdrawals, fund managers said yesterday.
That reluctance to get out no doubt helped to stabilize stocks, which recovered part of their losses after the Thanksgiving holiday. At least since 1988, individual investors have shown a willingness to buy on dips, and that behavior continues. 
 Bond fund investors, however, are another story. November may be the worst month ever, in terms of cash flow, for bond funds, which have been hurt by rising losses stemming from higher interest rates.
The comments by fund managers came as the Investment Company Institute, a trade group, reported that stock funds continued to pull in money at a rapid rate in October while bond funds saw cash pour out at near-record rates.
The industry's figures for October showed a net inflow of $9.3 billion, including $3.3 billion that went into international and global funds. Bond funds, including both taxable and municipal bond funds, saw a net outflow of $7.9 billion, the largest since $8.7 billion flowed out in October 1987. With several groups reporting increased withdrawals this month, it is possible that record will fall.
Fidelity Investments, the nation's largest mutual fund group, reported that its investors withdrew about $100 million from stock funds this month, the first such month for that group since March. But other fund groups reported that money continued to come in, albeit at slower rates. Neal Litvack, an executive vice president at Fidelity, said that domestic stock funds took in a net $100 million for the month, a flow offset by $200 million withdrawn from international stock funds.
At Vanguard, equity cash flow was positive, but down from October, John Woerth, a spokesman, said. He added that while there were substantial outflows from equity funds last Wednesday, the day stocks hit their recent lows, money returned later. T. Rowe Price reported similar results, with stock fund cash flows positive but down from the previous month.
At fund groups that sell through brokers, rather than directly to the public, the stock fund outlook appears brighter. "Investors aren't running for the exit," Joan Miller, a spokeswoman for State Street Research group of funds, said. She reported that her company's stock fund cash flows were up this month compared with October.
A similar trend was reported at the New England Funds. "Equity flows are surprisingly resilient," Bruce Speca, an official with the group, said. He added that stock flows were up about 25 percent from October and that international funds were doing well.
For municipal bond funds, which had managed to avoid big withdrawals earlier this year, the news is getting worse. In October, investors took out $2.6 billion, the most for any month since April 1987, when $3.3 billion was withdrawn. Prices for muni bonds have recently declined much more sharply than those for taxable bonds, a fact that seems to have scared some investors.
Still municipal bond funds have held up much better than some other types of bond funds, at least in terms of retaining assets. Total assets of all state and national muni bond funds were $236.4 billion at the end of October, down 9 percent from the peak set in January. Government bond funds, by contrast, have $91.5 billion in assets, down 28 percent from the peak set in July 1993.
And municipal bond fund managers are getting quite nervous. Having sold more bonds than were needed to meet redemptions in October, the level of cash in national muni bond funds rose to 5.1 percent of assets, the highest level in several years.
On the other end of the spectrum, the managers who run precious metals stock funds were evidently surprised by the fact their investors withdrew $172 million in October. Undeterred, those managers were net buyers of stocks, and the cash levels in their portfolios plunged to $201 million, less than half of September's level and just 3.4 percent of assets. That is the lowest percentage in more than three years.
The cash flow figures include new purchases and redemptions, as well as transfers between different types of funds. But they exclude reinvested dividends.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Replacement Players May Play Ball Next Year

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LEESBURG, Va., Nov. 29

 BODY:
Barring a 180-degree change in baseball's labor negotiations, the owners not only are headed for implementation of their salary-cap proposal next Monday, but they are also hurtling toward the use of replacement players next summer, their chief labor spokesman said tonight in his clearest comments on the controversial weapon in the clubs' bargaining briefcase.
The remarks by John Harrington came -- almost as an afterthought -- at the end of a long, unproductive day in talks between negotiators for the owners and the striking players at the Lansdowne Conference Resort 15 minutes from Dulles International Airport. 
 The negotiators, after holding separate meetings, spent most of four hours discussing the owners' revised cap plan and new payroll tax proposal, then adjourned for dinner. Instead of returning to the bargaining table afterward, they went to their rooms for the evening, instructed by Bill Usery Jr., the mediator, to return Wednesday morning.
Before going to his room, Harrington, the Boston Red Sox's chief executive, was standing in a corridor speaking socially with reporters when one began asking questions about the day's meeting. The questioning eventually got around to the subject of replacement players, which had been raised earlier in the day by Jerry McMorris, owner of the Colorado Rockies.
"If we have to do that, it will be with a great deal of reluctance," Harrington said. "What Jerry is saying is in the minds of all the baseball owners. We want to make a commitment to the fans that we're going to play the 1995 season with some caliber of professional baseball player.
"We believe it will be entertaining and we believe that's what the fans want. The fans want baseball with the best quality player we can put out there. Our preference is to put major league players out there, but if they're unwilling to play, then we'll have to go with someone else who's willing to play. It's something we don't want to do, and we're working in every respect away from that.
"We don't want to implement on Monday. That's a very reluctant step we want to take. It's our last resort."
Donald Fehr, the union leader, said Harrington has said the same thing about replacement players in negotiating sessions. "Such comments do not make the process more simple," Fehr said. "They have the opposite effect."
Gene Orza, a union lawyer, said the idea of replacement players is "internally inconsistent because only major league baseball players can play major league baseball. In the absence of an agreement on opening day 1995, major league players will be on strike."
The owners are scheduled to meet in Chicago next Monday, and they are expected to vote to declare an impasse in negotiations and implement the salary cap. Harrington said they had to act by then because of the Dec. 7 deadline clubs face for offering salary arbitration to retain rights to their free agents.
Harrington said the possibility of mutually postponing that deadline was discussed briefly today. He said the owners would consider a postponement "under certain conditions." Not discussed, he said, was the Dec. 20 deadline for tendering contracts to the more than 80 percent of the 1,087 players on major league rosters who are unsigned.
The owners want their new economic system in place before they reach these deadlines.
"It could be chaotic," Harrington said of implementation earlier in the day. "But we're trying to tell the players that once you go past the point of implementation, it's difficult to put the yolk back into the egg."
Further indication of the owners' plan to act next Monday was the summoning of the clubs' general managers for a briefing on the new system on the same day at the same place.
Harrington said the owners had hoped at least to have a counterproposal from the union that they could present at the meeting.
"I'm a little disappointed that we didn't get a counterproposal," he said. "We came here with a great degree of expectancy in that regard."
He noted that the tax proposal the owners made 12 days ago was a counterproposal to a players' tax proposal, but he didn't say that it took the owners two and a half months to make it.
The players are expected to reject both the tax proposal and the salary cap, but they did not do that today. Instead, they asked questions about the proposals and received further information from the owners' negotiating team.
The salary cap the owners plan to implement would provide the players with 50 percent of the clubs' designated gross revenue, but in actual practice, the players would receive only about 38 percent of the clubs' operating revenue for their salaries and bonuses.
That ratio of reality would leave the clubs with more than one-fifth less money to allocate for salaries and bonuses than they would have spent this year if the players' strike had not abbreviated the season.
The figures emerged from a breakdown of management economic data in a study made by The New York Times of the proposal that the owners are on the verge of implementing unilaterally.
The proposal, which replaced the original cap proposal made June 14, diluted the revenue to be shared by eliminating the clubs' product-licensing income. The owners removed it because the players didn't want their licensing money included, which the owners had done in their original proposal.
The owners' licensing money is estimated at 5 percent of the clubs' operating revenue, or about $85 million. Without that money, the clubs are left with $1,743,296,000 to divide in half with the players.
But the players' share, $871,648,000, does not go for salaries and bonuses alone. The clubs subtract $133,819,000 for "other" player costs.
That figure includes $65 million for the clubs' contribution to the players' benefit and pension plan and the rest for other expenses, such as meal money and spring training allowances.
The players' share also includes termination pay and salaries for players who aren't in the major leagues but who are on clubs' 40-man rosters. Termination pay this year, according to the owners' labor relations committee, was $30,783,861. No official figures were available for 40-man roster players, but one person familiar with such salaries estimated them at $500,000 a team, or a total of $14 million.
By the time those amounts are subtracted, the clubs would be left with $693 million to spend on salaries and bonuses for major league players, or 38 percent of projected operating revenue. This season, according to management figures, clubs spent $878,564,089, or 48 percent of their pre-strike projection, for operating revenue.

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 567 words

HEADLINE: Don't Rush to Expand NATO

 BODY:
During the cold war there was no disagreement between America and its allies over NATO's purpose: It was Europe's shield against a common enemy. The Serbs' war on Bosnia has exposed deep divisions among the Western powers over NATO's role and the question of European security. Some U.S. policy makers believe that the way to revive NATO is to enlarge it by offering membership and the military guarantees that membership confers to a few countries in Eastern Europe. Their rallying cry is "Expand or die."
That is a questionable idea. If Washington continues to move in this direction, it is sure to generate more trans-Atlantic divisiveness. It will burden NATO's existing members with risky new obligations. Moreover, inviting Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic to join will affront those who are likely to be left out, like Ukraine and the Baltic republics. Worse yet, expansion could strengthen Russian nationalists opposed to Boris Yeltsin and his Western-oriented reformers. The net result is that a larger NATO could diminish rather than strengthen European security. 
 The scheduled public unveiling of an American proposal to expand NATO was delayed yesterday by internal disarray over the Bosnian crisis. But if it goes forward in its present form, and is not derailed, the proposal will raise some tough questions. Will the U.S. extend its nuclear umbrella to Eastern Europe? Will allied troops be based farther east? How will Soviet-trained Eastern European officers be integrated into the NATO military command? Above all, how can Russia be included -- or be reconciled to being excluded?
That last question is certain to prove troubling to a shaky German governing coalition. Some Germans want to expand Germany's influence in the East; others do not want to set off renewed rivalry with Russia. Moreover, giving a pre-eminent security role to an American-led NATO is certain to arouse resistance from France and others that would like to strengthen intra-European security arrangements.
The U.S. proposal does not identify who the new members will be. Nor does it set a timetable for admission. The actual mechanics of enlargement will be left to a special NATO study.
But the biggest question of all is this: Why rush to decide now about bringing Eastern Europe into NATO? The region faces no imminent threat of attack. If, despite Western efforts, aggressive nationalists do seize power in Russia, it will be years before they can raise an army capable of destabilizing Ukraine and threatening Poland. That is time enough to bring Eastern Europe into the alliance.
A rancorous debate about expansion is likely to distract NATO members from confronting the main causes of Eastern Europe's insecurity -- the political, economic and ethnic tensions arising from the end of the cold war. As a purely military alliance, NATO is ill equipped to ease those tensions before they explode as they did in Bosnia.
Rejiggering NATO is not necessarily the right answer to these more complex problems. Yet as presently conformed, the alliance still provides a useful venue for coordinating U.S. and Western European military strategy and an insurance policy against the revival of aggressive Russia. Why expand it to the breaking point? It would be far better for President Clinton to join his European counterparts in seeking more creative solutions for Europe's problems.

HEADLINE: In America;
Business Beats Brooklyn

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
Final approval of the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade will tear a large hole in the Federal budget. But this breach of the budget is not considered a major problem by Government leaders in Washington because the new GATT agreement will be a bonanza for big business, and that is something favored by Democrats and Republicans alike.
When benefits for working people or the poor are involved, the budget deficit is seen as an insurmountable problem. There is no money for investments in ordinary Americans. But the specter of $42 billion in lost tariff revenues over the next decade is met with a shrug by the movers and shakers in Congress and the White House. As long as it's for business -- well, then, that's all right. 
 Brownsville, a desolate and mostly forgotten neighborhood in Brooklyn, is light years from Washington. Its residents will never be mistaken for the champagne-drinking, limousine-riding lobbyists who are swarming all over Capitol Hill in a gaudy display of corporate muscle on behalf of GATT. A glimpse of this crippled neighborhood was provided in Senate testimony last spring by Anne Kohler, who runs a soup kitchen in a tiny storefront that once housed a bakery:
"Our clients consist of the working poor, single mothers with children, long-term unemployed single men (part of the blue-collar work force, where many jobs have disappeared), married families with children, senior citizens, the mentally ill, the disabled and the handicapped. Some are illiterate, some are college-educated, some are chemically dependent, some worked all of their lives only to find that in old age the safety net has begun to crumble beneath their feet."
What these soup kitchen clients have in common is an economic predicament so dire they cannot be sure from one day to the next that they will eat. This is not easily understood by Congressmen, senators and Presidents who have trouble buttoning their jackets over their ample midsections. Hunger is alien to them.
Ms. Kohler's soup kitchen is called Neighbors Together and is the second-largest in Brooklyn. It serves a simple lunch (canned meat, a starch, canned vegetables) to 500 people a day, five days a week.
"I think most people are unaware of the tremendous poverty that exists in this country," said Ms. Kohler during an interview on Monday. "I see the suffering in the eyes of these people. Some of them are frail and old. There are women who are retarded. They can't work. I get sick to my stomach when I hear the stereotypes about how lazy the poor are, how they're living such great lives at the taxpayers' expense."
One evening Ms. Kohler took a boy from a desperately poor family home to spend the night with her and her husband in a different part of Brooklyn. "I told him he could sleep on the sofabed, or on a makeshift bed on the floor, beside our bed."
A stricken look crossed the boy's face. "Do you have mice?" he asked.
Ms. Kohler said the boy was afraid because his experience was that children who slept on the floor would have mice running over them.
GATT is about power and money and influence. Brownsville is about survival. Some of the very same Government officials who are going to the mat for GATT are also trying to cut the food stamp allotments of the poor. If there is equity in that kind of governing -- not to mention a sense of humanity -- Ms. Kohler has been unable to find it.
"Food stamps!" she cried, her eyes angry. "Can you believe they want to cut food stamps? A monthly allotment of food stamps provides about 88 cents per meal. I'll take you shopping and you see if you can buy a meal for 88 cents. Now they're going to give them less?"
The fine restaurants of the nation's capital are heavily booked for tomorrow night as corporate representatives prepare to celebrate the Uruguay Round's final passage. If the Senate gives the thumbs up, there will be toasts and laughter and triumphant applause, the kind of exuberance that accompanies a sudden acceleration of wealth and worth.
It's the kind of celebration that's as alien to Brownsville as hunger is to Capitol Hill.
